211.input:
time: null 
 author: Damian Paletta 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/rudy-giuliani-says-defeating-isis-to-be-early-focus-of-donald-trumps-foreign-policy-1479174875 
 text: WASHINGTON<U+2014>Former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani said<U+00A0>Monday<U+00A0>that President-elect Donald Trump would likely focus much of his initial foreign-policy strategy on destroying Islamic State, setting aside more vexing problems in the Middle East and elsewhere. The comments came shortly after The Wall Street Journal reported that Mr. Giuliani is one of the leading candidates to become Mr. Trump<U+2019>s first secretary of state . During an appearance<U+00A0>Monday<U+00A0>evening at The Wall Street Journal CEO Council gathering, Mr. Giuliani suggested several times that he would be interested in the post, going into great detail about how he views foreign policy and how his views overlap with Mr. Trump<U+2019>s. <U+201C>ISIS, short-term I believe, is the greatest danger and not because ISIS is in Iraq and in Syria, but because ISIS did something al Qaeda never did<U+2014>ISIS was able to spread itself around the world,<U+201D> he said. Mr. Giuliani didn<U+2019>t say, however, what specifically the Trump administration would do to combat Islamic State, also called ISIS or ISIL. Mr. Trump has repeatedly said he wants to keep this strategy secret so that the terror network can<U+2019>t prepare for it. Mr. Giuliani also said that the Trump administration would work to reset relations with both Russia and China. He said the Obama administration had made Russia into an adversary and said Russian President Vladimir Putin didn't respect President Barack Obama. Messrs. Trump and Putin spoke on the telephone on Monday and pledged to work together on a number of issues. The Obama administration does have a complicated relationship with Mr. Putin, and they have been at odds for several years over the Syrian civil war. The White House tried to reset relations with Russia several years ago, but Russia<U+2019>s annexation of Crimea from Ukraine and its support for rebels in Eastern Ukraine has pushed the U.S. and Russia further apart. Mr. Trump has repeatedly said he wants to work more cooperatively with Mr. Putin, but Mr. Giuliani gave a slightly more confrontational view of how that relationship could develop. <U+201C>Russia thinks it<U+2019>s a military competitor, it really isn<U+2019>t,<U+201D> Mr. Giuliani said. <U+201C>It<U+2019>s our unwillingness under Obama to even threaten the use of our military that makes Russia so powerful.<U+201D> On China, Mr. Giuliani said the Trump administration would prefer to engage with that country on economic issues such as trade. Mr. Trump plans to label China a <U+201C>currency manipulator<U+201D> shortly after taking office, a move that will likely escalate tensions between both countries, economic analysts have speculated. In the Middle East, Mr. Giuliani painted a picture of a collection of countries that are at odds with each other and on the brink of spilling into a broader regional war. He said that Iran had exerted its control over Iraq and Syria, though he didn<U+2019>t offer specifics on how Mr. Trump would work to address ongoing problems in the region. On Iraq, Mr. Trump has said the U.S.-led invasion in 2003 was one of the greatest foreign policy mistakes in U.S. history, but Mr. Giuliani had a different take. <U+201C>I think the way we exited Iraq was the worst decision made in American history,<U+201D> he said, saying it allowed Islamic State to flourish in the vacuum that was created. This is a common criticism from Republicans of the White House<U+2019>s foreign policy. Mr. Giuliani is well known for his tenure as New York mayor, his work as a federal prosecutor and issues like counterterrorism and homeland security. He is less well-known for his foreign-policy views. Write to Damian Paletta at damian.paletta@wsj.com

212.input:
time: null 
 author: noauthor 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/submit-the-iran-deal-for-senate-confirmation-1480365312 
 text: In your editorial <U+201C> Mike Pompeo<U+2019>s Iran File <U+201D> (Nov. 22) about Mike Pompeo<U+2019>s nomination to lead the CIA and the Iranian nuclear deal, you raise <U+201C>the larger question of how the incoming Administration should treat the nuclear deal.<U+201D> The answer is simple: Present it to the Senate for a ratification vote. This would restore the Senate<U+2019>s constitutional role in treaty-making and force Democrats, including Sen. Chuck Schumer, to go on record. When the vote fails, President Trump can withdraw with broad and bipartisan Senate backing. Separately, Iran<U+2019>s serial violations warrant the onerous <U+201C>snapback<U+201D> sanctions that President Obama famously and deceitfully claimed would ensue. Congress can impose new sanctions, and countries around the world can be put on notice that they can trade with Iran or with the U.S., but not both. If a nuclear Iran is truly among the most dangerous threats globally, and if we mean to take all nonmilitary measures to prevent it, there should be no qualms about this tough approach. Our security demands it. Jonathan Rothenberg Scarsdale, N.Y. Your editorial makes the classic mistake that has plagued the Democratic Party for years. You take note of the pervasive Iranian failure to honor critical provisions of President Obama<U+2019>s Iranian nuclear deal, and then you suggest that, along with enhanced monitoring, we <U+201C>honor the deal<U+201D> and <U+201C>resume enforcement of current U.S. sanctions on Iran.<U+201D> If you really believe that well-meaning policies resulting in unintended adverse consequences are a good idea, we need to look no further than North Korea to reflect on the negligible results of U.S. sanctions. Instead of encouraging policies that have repeatedly failed, shouldn<U+2019>t President-elect Trump initiate new pathways which have a higher chance of success in preventing the Iranians from ever developing nuclear weapons? This potential for a fresh perspective is one of the prime reasons Donald Trump was elected<U+2014>America will never be <U+201C>great again<U+201D> if Iran begins to threaten its neighbors and the world with a nuclear Armageddon. The recycling of failing policies from the past isn<U+2019>t the answer. Roger C. Dunham Santa Barbara, Calif. You mention aspects of the Iranian nuclear deal that, due to President Obama<U+2019>s penchant for secrecy, the American public knows nothing about. One of them is the <U+201C>economic snapback<U+201D> of sanctions in the event of any Iranian violations. Mr. Obama has always presented that option as all inclusive, when in reality it appears that the agreement calls for previous sanctions to apply only to any new contracts scheduled to begin after the verification of any Iranian violations. That is far different from the impression the Obama administration has tried to convey. Any contracts in place before the violations would be unaffected. There is no way the European nations involved in the nuclear agreement would ever cooperate to allow an interruption of the flow of money now coming to them from Iranian business contacts. Lynn Parana Los Angeles

 text: Tuesday 8 November 2016 by Lucas Wilde Jeremy Vine already tripping his tits off 
Veteran election reporter Jeremy Vine has embarked on his usual pre-election broadcast ritual by taking a load of drugs and hallucinating maps of the USA, pie-charts and various other election-themed visages. 
The least-funny of the Vine brothers usually waits until the polls close before cracking open his thermos flask full of hallucinogens, but has decided to get on it early this year. 
<U+201C>I can<U+2019>t say I blame him<U+201D> said Lucy Millwall, Head of CGI for BBC News. 
<U+201C>This election has been impressive only for sheer scale of mind-numbing awfulness. 
<U+201C>Honestly, you try pretending to give a shit about what Gary Johnson is up to without yawning. 
<U+201C>It<U+2019>s actually intriguing watching him dance around an empty green room, imagining he<U+2019>s kicking a football marked <U+201C>Florida<U+201D> between Trump and Clinton. 
<U+201C>We just computer-generate images around whatever he<U+2019>s imagining. Technically we are <U+2018>enabling<U+2019> him but fuck it; it<U+2019>s really good telly. 
<U+201C>We<U+2019>re always careful to cut away from him before he starts talking to Peter, the <U+2018>Rapiest Giraffe of Them All<U+2019>.<U+201D> Jeremy Vine election coverage 
Jeremy Vine has been taking LSD ever since John Major<U+2019>s first election victory; the campaign proving so overwhelmingly dull that recreational drug use became BBC protocol for several weeks.

214.input:
time: null 
 author: Riva Gold Georgi Kantchev 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/stocks-face-threat-as-globalization-loses-steam-1476644188 
 text: LONDON<U+2014>Some big global investors worry that the broad slowdown in world trade and growing populist opposition to new trade agreements are undermining corporate profits and could be the next big drag on the stock market. U.S. equity prices have been supported for the past three decades by an acceleration of global trade and a freer flow of capital. Those factors lifted economic growth and allowed companies to take advantage of new markets and economies of scale. The S&P 500 is up nearly ninefold since October 1986, according to FactSet. But now there is worry that the party is ending. <U+201C>We believe globalization has probably reached its peak,<U+201D> said Marino Valensise, head of the multiasset team at Barings, a member of the MassMutual Financial Group with $275 billion in assets under management. <U+201C>The market won<U+2019>t like it.<U+201D> Barings<U+2019>s senior managers every winter gather at their central London office to iron out their 10-year investment forecast. At the next one, they expect to consider reducing<U+2014>or even outright eliminating<U+2014>their estimate of the value globalization adds to stocks, what they term a <U+201C>globalization premium.<U+201D> The Barings managers say the slowdown in global trade is one factor leading them to move away from stocks that have benefited most from globalization and into places like bonds, which are in some cases better valued than the U.S. stock market and may suffer less amid rising geopolitical tensions. Other investors favor switching from multinational companies to national champions like Chinese internet companies or Latin American airlines. Global trade this year will grow at the slowest pace since 2007, according to the World Trade Organization, just as protectionist policies are on the rise and efforts to liberalize trade have stalled. The International Monetary Fund recently warned that anti-trade trends such as increases in tariffs could cause long-term damage to the world economy. Some are worried this could spill over to corporate profits. Global stock-index provider MSCI estimates that if policies such as trade protectionism and government deficit spending increase significantly in the developed world in the next two years, U.S. equities would shed more than 17%, while European equity markets would fall by close to 20%.<U+00A0>In a stress test run by MSCI, the firm assumes that such policies would lead to stagflation, a toxic combination of higher inflation and lower growth. Over the past 12 months, the MSCI Europe index is down 6.4%, while S&P 500 is up 4.9% Michael O<U+2019>Sullivan, chief investment officer for Europe at Credit Suisse , said investors are facing a <U+201C>postglobalization<U+201D> landscape. <U+201C>For markets, the slowdown in globalization means even more uncertainty,<U+201D> he said. Companies around the globe, from shippers to manufacturers, have already pointed to slowing trade and rising protectionism as a drag on profits. U.S.-based Deere & Co., the world<U+2019>s largest seller of tractors and harvesting combines, said earlier this year that protectionism and trade restrictions could hurt its results. In Australia, Ansell Ltd. , one of the world<U+2019>s biggest makers of condoms, sees the rise of political risk clouding its long-term outlook. The U.K.<U+2019>s vote to exit the European Union added <U+201C>an element of uncertainty in all of Europe,<U+201D> Chief Executive Magnus Nicolin said on the company<U+2019>s latest earnings call. It wasn<U+2019>t supposed to be this way. Equity valuations spiked in the early 1990s after the fall of the Berlin Wall ushered in the end of the Cold War. World trade boomed, McDonald<U+2019>s Corp. started flipping more burgers in China and Ford Motor Co. could manufacture pickup trucks cheaply in Thailand. U.S. stock valuations jumped above their 120-year average on the assumption of ever increasing global trade and easier movement of goods, services and capital across borders, said Christopher Mahon, director of asset allocation research also on the multiasset team at Barings. The globalization premium meant that U.S. stocks collectively traded at a price/earnings ratio roughly one whole number higher they otherwise would have, Barings estimates. P/E ratios, calculated by dividing stock prices by earnings per share, are a common measure of how expensive shares are. Barings calculated the premium by analyzing historical valuations and stripping out the impact of other variables such as inflation dynamics and central-bank policies. Calculating the globalization premium is the result of extensive debate among senior investment strategists at the firm, who pore over economic data, forecasts and research reports before deciding on a number every year. But that equation is changing. Over the past decade, Barings has cut the premium by half, and the firm<U+2019>s outlook for stocks is going down with it. Other fund managers say they are becoming more selective, shunning the sectors and countries they view as most likely to suffer from the resulting slowdown. <U+201C>Globalization is increasingly coming under siege,<U+201D> said Stefan Scheurer, senior market strategist at Allianz Global Investors. Mr. O<U+2019>Sullivan of Credit Suisse said the U.S. profit cycle correlates well with world trade. <U+201C>And in the past two years we had falling profits and slowing trade,<U+201D> he said. Companies listed in the S&P 500 derive more than 30% of their revenue overseas, according to FactSet. Global container-shipping operators have already cited the slowdown in trade as a major drag on profits, with the shipping industry facing its worst year since the 2008 financial crisis. The number of protectionist measures implemented around the globe so far this year has climbed to 338, according to researchers at Global Trade Alert, the highest for the corresponding period since they began tracking the figure in 2009 and up from 61 in the same period that year. Global Trade Alert is a trade-monitoring group coordinated by the Centre for Economic Policy Research, an independent research think tank based in London. Efforts to liberalize world trade have also stalled, including the trans-Atlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, the potential free-trade deal between the U.S. and the European Union. In the U.S., the Peterson Institute for International Economics said the proposed trade policies of presidential candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton would deeply hurt the American economy by slowing productivity growth. <U+201C>We<U+2019>re very concerned about the positions of both parties in trade,<U+201D> Fred Smith, chief executive at FedEx Corp. , said on the company<U+2019>s June earnings call. Some investors argue that even as globalization may be on the decline in the West, pockets of the world continue to open themselves up for trade, creating new investment opportunities. Sandra Crowl at French asset manager Carmignac points to Argentina, for instance, as a country that may benefit more from opening itself up to the world even as other countries, such as the U.S., become more protectionist. At Barings, managers favor moving away from equities and into fixed-income securities like bonds, which are likely to be more insulated from the turmoil. <U+201C>In March, I dare say we will be once again putting a haircut to our globalization premium,<U+201D> Mr. Mahon said. <U+201C>Or possibly cut it to zero.<U+201D> Write to Riva Gold at riva.gold@wsj.com and Georgi Kantchev at georgi.kantchev@wsj.com

217.input:
time: null 
 author: Patrick Temple-West Seung Min Kim Burgess Everett Josh Gerstein Madeline Conway Jack Shafer 
 source: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/11/liberals-push-kara-stein-to-lead-sec-as-warren-lends-tacit-backing-230722 
 text: Sen. Elizabeth Warren tacitly endorsed Kara Stein to replace SEC Chair Mary Jo White last month. | Getty By Patrick Temple-West 11/04/16 09:00 AM EDT When Sen. Elizabeth Warren last month demanded that President Barack Obama immediately replace SEC Chair Mary Jo White, she said the president could easily fill the position without Senate confirmation. That was a tacit endorsement of Kara Stein, the agency<U+2019>s lone Democratic commissioner, who could move into the top job without Senate involvement. Story Continued Below For Warren, it was probably the strongest hint yet at who she would like to see in government if Hillary Clinton is elected president. While the Massachusetts progressive has been clear about who she doesn<U+2019>t want to see in a Clinton administration <U+2014> almost anyone connected with Wall Street <U+2014> she has been less open in public about who she wants. In contrast to White, Stein has become a champion of progressives. Warren may not have spelled out her preference for the next SEC chair, but liberal groups allied with her are advocating for Stein. Her name has been on at least two of the lists they have drawn up of Wall Street watchdogs they would want Clinton to nominate, according to two people familiar with the matter. One of the people said liberals have recommended Stein to Clinton transition team officials Ed Meier and Ann O<U+2019>Leary. Other names that have been circulated by progressives for top jobs: Labor Secretary Tom Perez; former CFTC Commissioner Gary Gensler; Deputy Treasury Secretary Sarah Bloom Raskin, and Heather Boushey, the chief economist on the Clinton transition team. By Seung Min Kim and Burgess Everett Stein, who has sometimes clashed with White in pushing for tougher penalties on misbehaving companies and for greater investor protection, is being promoted by liberals who have voiced disappointment in the current SEC chair. <U+201C>Kara Stein is viewed by many progressives as the lone beacon of hope at a SEC that has repeatedly fallen far short of their expectations,<U+201D> said Isaac Boltansky, director of policy research for Compass Point Research & Trading in Washington. For the last three years, Warren and investor advocates have accused White of being too deferential toward businesses. Last year, the liberal advocacy group Credo Action hired a truck to drive around Washington with a billboard saying that White <U+201C>works for banks, not for you.<U+201D> In her Oct. 14 letter to Obama, Warren blasted White for not compelling corporations to disclose their political spending, saying the SEC chair, a former federal prosecutor, was failing <U+201C>to direct the agency's resources toward pressing matters of compelling interest to investors and the public.<U+201D> In a sign that she might be campaigning for a new job, Stein in August expanded and updated her biography page on the agency<U+2019>s website. Neither of the agency<U+2019>s other two commissioners have changed their official profiles since they started at the SEC in 2013. By Josh Gerstein and Madeline Conway An aide for Stein declined to comment. Stein, 52, drafted parts of the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act while working for Sen. Jack Reed (D-R.I.) on the Senate Banking Committee. She was appointed to the SEC by Obama in 2013, the same year Warren joined the Senate. Given her record at the agency, an SEC led by Stein would be a nightmare for corporations. Stein pressed for a stronger <U+201C>Volcker rule,<U+201D> the section of Dodd-Frank that banned banks from proprietary trading. She also hammered her fellow commissioners for voting to give financial firms permission to continue doing certain business operations after the companies agreed to misconduct settlements with the agency. Clinton, in her 2015 Wall Street regulatory plan, promised to strengthen the Volcker rule and criticized the SEC for generously issuing corporate waivers. <U+201C>A Stein-led SEC would likely take a more skeptical view of the markets as a whole, and that would seek to shelter investors since she often comes across as viewing markets as inherently dangerous places,<U+201D> said Thaya Brook Knight, associate director of financial regulation studies at the Cato Institute, a libertarian think tank. <U+201C>We might see an across-the-board shift toward a fearful view of market forces that would contrast with White<U+2019>s approach which, overall, has been more moderate and more restrained,<U+201D> she said. By Bill Scher By Thomas Wright By Joshua Zeitz By Jack Shafer

221.input:
time: null 
 author: NICK CORASANITI GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO 
 source: https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/30/us/politics/bruce-springsteen-donald-trump.html?_r=0 
 text: Bruce Springsteen is often called the troubadour of white, working-class America, a landscape he explores in his autobiography released this week . But this election, the Republican presidential nominee, Donald J. Trump , has captured many of those blue-collar voters<U+2019> hearts, with his denunciation of trade deals and promises to bring back manufacturing. Take a tour of signature Springsteen spots to see which are turning toward Mr. Trump. Youngstown, Ohio Song: <U+201C>Youngstown<U+201D> Album: <U+201C>The Ghost of Tom Joad<U+201D> State of the race: Northeastern Ohio favors Mrs. Clinton <U+201C>Youngstown<U+201D> traces the long history of steel and iron production that has defined this working-class city. Mr. Trump has visited Youngstown and made revival of the steel industry a focus of his campaign, pledging to rebuild American cities<U+2019> infrastructure with steel produced in the United States. Still, he trails the Democratic nominee, Hillary Clinton , 46 percent to 33 percent, in northeastern Ohio, home to Youngstown and Cleveland, though he holds a slight edge statewide, according to a recent Suffolk University poll . _____ Atlantic City Song: <U+201C>Atlantic City<U+201D> Album: <U+201C>Nebraska<U+201D> State of the race: Southern New Jersey favors Mrs. Clinton This is one of many Springsteen songs tinted by the economic anxieties of the Carter-Reagan recession. In the 34 years since the song<U+2019>s release, the area has grown more distressed, largely because of the closings of casinos. But Mr. Trump has little traction here; Atlantic County, home to Atlantic City, is more ethnically diverse and economically depressed than most of the Jersey Shore, and appears to be leaning Democratic again this year. _____ Badlands National Park, S.D. Song: <U+201C>Badlands<U+201D> Album: <U+201C>Darkness on the Edge of Town<U+201D> In this song, the dry, craggy terrain of the badlands becomes a symbol of hard living and perseverance in the American West. Most of the badlands states, shaped by a frontier politics, vote reliably Republican, and Mr. Trump is ahead of Mrs. Clinton among likely voters here in the Dakotas and nearby Plains states, 43 percent to 36 percent, according to the most recent New York Times/CBS News poll . But many young adults here have been energized by the Libertarian candidate , Gary Johnson, who is drawing 13 percent, which may prevent Mr. Trump from running up a big victory margin. _____ Johnstown, Pa. Song: <U+201C>The River<U+201D> Album: <U+201C>The River<U+201D> State of the race: Mrs. Clinton has an edge in southwestern Pennsylvania The sense of malaise that Mr. Springsteen noted in blue-collar communities across America at the turn of the 1980s is still strongly felt in places like western Pennsylvania, where manufacturing jobs have largely vanished . White voters without a college degree are among Mr. Trump<U+2019>s strongest supporters there, as they are nationwide: 56 percent of these likely voters support him in a two-way race, versus 37 percent for Mrs. Clinton, according to this month<U+2019>s Quinnipiac University poll of Pennsylvania. But Mrs. Clinton is making that up with support from nonwhites <U+2014> three-quarters of whom say they will vote for her <U+2014> and more educated white voters. The poll gives her a five-point advantage over Mr. Trump statewide. _____ Amarillo, Tex. Song: <U+201C>Cadillac Ranch<U+201D> Album: <U+201C>The River<U+201D> State of the race: Northwestern Texas favors Mr. Trump <U+201C>Cadillac Ranch<U+201D> is a carefree, borderline-nonsensical salute to one of Mr. Springsteen<U+2019>s favorite themes: the joys of a good, shiny sedan. It is also a homage to the famed tourist attraction in Amarillo. The city<U+2019>s thriving economy revolves around meatpacking and defense contracting. A recent Texas Lyceum poll shows Mr. Trump leading Mrs. Clinton by just six points in Texas, and if that holds, he would win the state by a narrower margin than any Republican candidate since Bob Dole. But his fate seems secure in Amarillo, which is in the state<U+2019>s northwestern quadrant, where no statewide Republican candidate since 2010 has taken less than 70 percent. _____ Darlington County, S.C. Song: <U+201C>Darlington County<U+201D> Album: <U+201C>Born in the U.S.A.<U+201D> State of the race: South Carolina favors Mr. Trump Location: <U+201C>Darlington County<U+201D> tells the lighthearted story of two men who have left New York City behind and are cruising down Interstate 95, searching for work <U+2014> presumably escaping some unsavory business back home. The area is friendly to Mr. Trump, who trounced the field in South Carolina, including in Darlington County, where he defeated Senator Ted Cruz of Texas by roughly 10 points. No reliable general election polls have been published in South Carolina, but Mr. Trump should coast to victory here. No Democratic presidential nominee has won the state since 1976, two election cycles before Mr. Springsteen recorded this song. _____ Charlotte County, Fla. Song: <U+201C>Working on the Highway<U+201D> Album: <U+201C>Born in the U.S.A.<U+201D> State of the race: The Florida Gulf Coast favors Mr. Trump This song<U+2019>s narrator finds himself arrested and enlisted in a prison gang doing highway construction in Charlotte County, along Florida<U+2019>s Gulf Coast. The area is a conservative stronghold dominated by retirees and white-collar professionals. Ninety percent of county residents are white, and white Floridians overwhelmingly favor Trump, according to a recent Monmouth University poll . A separate poll by CNN/ORC gave him a lead of 49 percent to 33 percent in the central Gulf Coast region. Mr. Trump feels a special connection to Florida, which he calls his second home, and barely a week goes by that the candidate does not visit what his campaign considers one of the most important states in the general election. Find out what you need to know about the 2016 presidential race today, and get politics news updates via Facebook , Twitter and the First Draft newsletter . A version of this article appears in print on October 1, 2016, on Page A10 of the New York edition with the headline: A Turn to Trump in the America of Springsteen. Order Reprints | Today's Paper | Subscribe

 text: Home | World | Anti-Brexit Meddler Gina Miller Poses Outside the Houses of Parliament Anti-Brexit Meddler Gina Miller Poses Outside the Houses of Parliament By Alphonse Mucus 08/11/2016 13:27:37 
LONDON <U+2013> England <U+2013> Anti-Brexit campaigner Gina Miller has been revelling in her new found fame by posing outside the Houses of Parliament. 


<U+201C>I used to be a model you know,<U+201D> Miller says every two minutes. 
She seems to be enjoying the limelight and fame of being one of the foreign interests who was instrumental in attempting to block 52% of British voters who voted to leave the EU. 
Posing in defiance, Ms Miller, a native of Guyana, brings out her new hat, acquired at some posh shop no doubt, or a betting shop lavatory to be more precise. 
<U+201C>Do you like my new hat?<U+201D> she scowls, as the primping begins in earnest. 
The photographer adjusts his lens, then sniffs loudly. 
<U+201C>S<U+2019>cuse me Miss, but what<U+2019>s that awful smell? It smells like a turd that has festered in satan<U+2019>s butt hole for a thousand years.<U+201D> 
<U+201C>It<U+2019>s my hat, or shall I say crown. I shall wear it wherever I go from now on, and anyone who looks at me will see my beautiful crown that I wear so proudly, and think of me.<U+201D> 
At that moment, four dozen bluebottle flies plop themselves on Gina Miller<U+2019>s crown and tuck down to some good nosh. 
In the background, the spire of Big Ben looms over the scene, and as the coughing photographer clicks away, a wry smile comes over Gina Miller, she is the Queen today, the Queen of No-Brexit, and she will cherish this moment of fame for the fifteen minutes it will afford her. 
Enjoy your crown Gina Miller, you will wear it for the rest of your pitiful life.

223.input:
time: null 
 author: Dan Wright 
 source: shadowproof.com 
 text: Despite the establishment media<U+2019>s hopes and repeated claims that it could never happen, Donald Trump is the president-elect of the United States of America. Now liberal pundits are scrambling to explain how the hell it happened. Isn<U+2019>t this country changing demographically? Didn<U+2019>t Donald Trump disqualify himself with his racist and sexist statements? What about the nuclear codes? 
Well, Donald Trump had one thing in his favor: he ran against one of the most unpopular and despised presidential candidates in American history, Hillary Rodham Clinton. Combine the electorate<U+2019>s Clinton antipathy with a risky but targeted strategy to flip the Rust Belt and it<U+2019>s not so hard to understand why Donald Trump, a man with no experience in government, will be sitting in the oval office come late January.
The usual suspects have had no luck in crafting a convincing narrative that doesn<U+2019>t make them look like idiots. Joan Walsh of The Nation, a shameless hack for Hillary, wrote a sardonic piece wherein she played the victim and defended Clinton<U+2019>s candidacy, saying, <U+201C>she had more of a message than her lefty haters give her credit for.<U+201D>
Actually, no, not really. Clinton ran the definition of a negative campaign and what little of a progressive message she presented was copy and pasted from Senator Bernie Sanders<U+2019> campaign and extremely unconvincing given her neoliberal record. Clinton had trust issues from the beginning, which were only exacerbated by her extremely dishonest attacks on Sanders and equally dishonest revisionism of her own herstory. 
Jamelle Bouie, whose biggest claim to fame is saying Trump could not win, offers another equally moronic analysis of Trump voters, claiming anyone who voted for Trump is a racist and deserves no empathy. Yes, African-Americans, Asians, and non-white Hispanics voted for Trump, but according to Bouie they apparently hate themselves.
Bouie is reliably wrong, so expect him to fail up in pundit world. But his blame the voter strategy parallels that of bourgeoisie feminists, who claim women who voted for Trump (or even just did not for Clinton) did so because they have <U+201C>internalized misogyny.<U+201D> Jess McIntosh, the former communications director for the Clinton campaign, made that explicit claim in an interview with DNC-friendly MSNBC. 
So, to recap, anyone who did not vote for Hillary Clinton this cycle hates minorities and women (including minorities and women).
Well, allow me to retort. Hillary Clinton lost the election because she was a terrible candidate. Nobody likes or trusts her (yes, elections actually are popularity contests) and her neoliberal domestic policies and neoconservative foreign policies turned people off because they are genuinely bad. Clinton represented the establishment in a change election, something she was happy to do. She even openly courted Republicans hoping her <U+201C>temperament<U+201D> talking point would make partisan Republicans vote for one of the most hated Democrats in history. It didn<U+2019>t work.
Clinton also refused to talk about class and only seriously brought up racism to label Trump supporters as racist <U+201C>deplorables<U+201D> and <U+201C>irredeemable.<U+201D> Which, beyond excessively judgmental, was just stupid politics as many of those people live in the god damn Rust Belt. Way to ensure they voted Hillary! If Clinton is so smart, why is she so stupid? Riddle me that.
Now, thank the lord, we as a country are going to move on from the Clinton crime family. The Democratic Party needs a major overhaul, which it will have plenty of time to focus on as it is now out of power in the House, Senate, and White House. Great job, Team Hillary.
But first, how about the Hillary Clinton supporters stop blaming everyone else for their terrible candidate? Democrats had a populist who did well in the Rust Belt, Clinton supporters did everything they could to destroy him. This election is on them.
The post Dear Hillary Supporters, Own Your Terrible Candidate appeared first on Shadowproof .

225.input:
time: null 
 author: The Doc 
 source: silverdoctors.com 
 text: The Next Big Shoe to Drop Posted on   The Next Big Shoe to Drop 
This is yet another source of highly flammable fuel that will result in more gasoline when the Fed is called in<U+2026> 

From Dr. Jeffrey Lewis : 
More than 40 million young Americans carry federal and private student loan debt <U+2013> amounting to over $1 trillion. Defaults are on the rise and the issue has grown to become a nasty wealth transfer mechanism, as well as sad example of the failure of finance in general. 
This week, President Obama announced a new initiative framed as a way of addressing the issue. Sadly, it is far from the mark, and just one more indication that monetary masters are the real puppeteers. 
Many have pointed out that the student loan debt bubble could be the next subprime crisis. 
Perhaps so, but it is potentially much worse, acting as an anvil when considered in the context of other consumer debt like car loans and credit cards. 
The student debt debacle has the potential of corrupting not only education, but a generation as well. 
It risks becoming the blight on a generation of would-be productive and innovative work force. 
Furthermore, the workforce declines, and falls behind, as more students return home to live with parents. And the extra burden on multi-generational households adds yet another deflationary force to the natural trend. 
From the perspective of bankers, policy makers, and the propaganda machine, college loan programs have been a tremendous success, providing access for students who would otherwise not be able to afford the privilege. 
It is about threading a narrow political path. 
Defaults are on the rise and the notional value of student loans went north of $1 trillion. 
Servicers must be getting nervous; the lobbyists are circling the wagons. 
There is no clear indication of who will pay for it <U+2013> or how. 
Defaults on the rise; one in seven currently default. 
The news of doing something comes around to yet another intervention with all the familiar signs that it is meant to save the financiers and has very little to do with helping students. 
The problem is that this is too little too late. 
Student loan debt is a trillion dollar reality in the context of a major, ongoing depression. 
We are a Nanny state <U+2013> with almost 50 million on food stamps and more on some sort of assistance. Labor force participation is at 40 year lows. 
There is already a major dis-incentive to work. If you take a horrible minimum wage job, you lose valuable benefits, entitlements. 
Which, incidentally, also explains why while it took the U.S. economy 6 years to recover all the job losses since Lehman. This took place at the expense of 13 million Americans leaving the labor force for good even as the U.S. population rose by 15 million. 
It also means that using a historical average participation rate, U.S. unemployment is over 11%, while underemployment is currently well in the 20% range <U+2013> a far more realistic assessment of where the U.S. economy really is. 
People on assistance programs are literally paid to stay home <U+2013> think of the cultural implications. 
It<U+2019>s almost a conspiracy. You have a massive class of under the table people with no voice. Give them bread and circuses. 
The student loan debacle is another story. 
For the parents, the typical situation is framed by skyrocketing tuition; and little help from scholarships become fractions in the face of rising tuition. 
The income cut-off for need-based financial aid is low. 
Parents are expected to contribute 25% of pre-tax income to the cost of tuition. 
If you earn $80K a year and your child<U+2019>s college tuition is $20K, you get nothing in terms of need-based financial aid. And that 25% doesn<U+2019>t count room & board, books, etc. 
So, it<U+2019>s basically impossible for middle-class families to send their kids to college without taking out student loans. In fact, the entire higher-education system is built to force people into debt if they want to send their kids to college. 
And it has a sinister underlying theme<U+2026> 
It<U+2019>s always about the <U+201C>irresponsible student<U+201D> or the <U+201C>hairdresser subprime loan borrower<U+201D> who <U+201C>should have known better<U+201D>. 
They should have known that housing prices eventually fall, even though <U+201C>everyone<U+201D> in the mainstream, including the chairman of the Federal Reserve said they would not. They should have read carefully the fine print instead of trusting the fancy loan officer. 
And everyone knows that without a college education you will not succeed, so <U+201C>borrow whatever it takes<U+201D>. You<U+2019>ll pay it back. 
Two decades of further tweaks to the bankruptcy code ensued until 2005, when Congress passed the Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act of 2005. This Act made it so that no student loan <U+2014> federal or private <U+2014> could be discharged in bankruptcy unless the borrower can prove repaying the loan would cause <U+201C>undue hardship,<U+201D> a condition that is incredibly difficult to demonstrate unless the person has a severe disability. It essentially lumps student loan debt in with child support and criminal fines <U+2014> other types of debt that can<U+2019>t be discharged. 
But our system is perfectly fine going after the invisible <U+2013> those without a political voice <U+2013> whether the poor or elderly who get crushed by inflation, or the 18 year olds who get out with $100K in debt and an art appreciation degree. 
But the price of education should tell an even deeper story<U+2026>. 
Quality of Education Suffers 
The compounding irony is that not only does the price of education go up, but the quality goes down. Institutions become entrenched. There is little incentive evolve, tenure runs rampant. And the curriculum declines. 
Higher education becomes both a commodity and a spectacle. Not a vehicle for progress or a reflection of the needs of the culture or the economy. 
That may not be hyperinflation<U+2026>but it<U+2019>s very sad. College education quality has not risen proportionately with price. 
Student loan debt is out of control by any and all measures. It<U+2019>s a debacle that benefits no one besides the banker and the servicers. The schools lose by making themselves unviable in the long run. 
The students come away with non-dischargeable student loans and enter a world without, for the most part, having any marketable skills. 
Sadly, the student loans are just one more politically untouchable issue providing yet another source of highly flammable fuel that will result in more gasoline when the Fed is called in.

AS TEACHERS in Ireland enjoy some well earned time off this week, they have been plagued by the undeserved stereotype of being hard party animals that love nothing more than to be 4 days into a session with no end in sight. 
WWN carried out some extensive research to discover not all teachers fit the lazy stereotype and are actually making the most of their time off. 
Here<U+2019>s 5 things they<U+2019>re doing that won<U+2019>t result in them ending up face down in a pool of their own vomit while haphazardly correcting your child<U+2019>s <U+2018>I love my Mammy because<U+2019> essay. 
1) Pre-Session 
Don<U+2019>t even try to class this as a balls to the wall session. It isn<U+2019>t. Do not misunderstand the situation. A pre-session is no more a session than the Pope is a Muslim. So don<U+2019>t try and pull a fast one on teachers. Sure it can<U+2019>t be a session, there<U+2019>s no drugs in sight, trust us, we looked.

Just going for the one is simply that, an expression of a desire to have a casual catch up with a fellow teacher friend without being unfairly labelled a basket case that can<U+2019>t go two minutes without recreating their favourite scenes from Trainspotting. And it<U+2019>s still <U+2018>just the one<U+2019> if it<U+2019>s an early house, after ambling home from last night<U+2019>s pre-session.

See, it<U+2019>s not all fun and games and importing four tonnes of class A drugs. Teachers have some serious work to do, and a bottle of wine and a line will certainly make the whole thing go more smoothly. 
4) Bumping into a student in a nightclub 
An awkward encounter many people can sympathise with. What is your favourite pupil Thomas doing in Flannerys at 2.30am? And what<U+2019>s he eating a Toffee Crisp for? Why is his mother shouting at you? Wait, why does Flanneys now look eerily like a suburban front garden. An easy mistake to make, don<U+2019>t worry about it. 
5) Re-lax-ing-the-fuck-out 
Educating the Nation<U+2019>s little shits isn<U+2019>t easy, we can only imagine, which is why teachers often just catch up on their sleep during a midterm. Or if sleep isn<U+2019>t possible, a trance sleep-like state after necking some Ketamine in a field in Kildare.

228.input:
time: null 
 author: noauthor 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/any-relief-for-the-monetary-policy-guinea-pigs-1478822871 
 text: Rockefeller University, a pre-eminent biomedical research institute with more Nobel Prizes to its credit than most countries, knows how to run experiments. Since its founding in 1901, the university and its scientists have been pioneers in a broad range of fields. from infectious diseases to Alzheimer<U+2019>s disease, AIDS and opiate addiction. But today, the university, like many endowed institutions, has become a subject in a grand experiment run by global central bankers exploring uncharted territory in interest-rate policy and market intervention. In this monetary experiment<U+2014>to paraphrase <U+201C>Pogo<U+201D> cartoonist Walt Kelly <U+2014>we have met the lab mice and they are us. Barring a monetary U-turn prompted by the Trump administration, our future may not be rosy. Since the onset of ultra-low interest rates in 2008, returns to savers, both individual and institutional, have been in relentless decline. They are expected to fall further, even while costs for services like health care and education continue to rise well above the rate of the general consumer-price index. Pension plans are increasingly underfunded and the boards of most universities are anxiously discussing the implications of lower endowment returns for budgets going forward. According to Cambridge Associates, in the decade that ended June 30, 2016, the average annual return for even large sophisticated endowments (those with assets over $1 billion) fell below 6%. With average annual spending rates of 5% or higher, and the inflation-measuring Higher Education Price Index growing at an annual rate above 2%, most endowments have lost ground unless they had substantive new giving. This means less research, less scholarship aid and less opportunity for future generations. For scientific research in particular, declines in endowment funding coinciding with persistent declines in government funding would be particularly unfortunate. Good scientists know that correlation does not imply causation<U+2014>the coincidence of extreme monetary measures with declining real, or after-inflation returns does not prove that monetary policy has caused returns to decline. But the concurrence should prompt some questions. Most obviously, negative real rates<U+2014>below-zero rates, after adjustment for inflation<U+2014>punish bond investors. The more conservative the investment strategy, the worse the punishment, pushing both individuals and institutions further out on the risk curve than they otherwise would or should be. In theory, all prudent investors hold some bonds to provide much-needed diversification and guaranteed income<U+2014>a haven from equity-market volatility. Negative real rates destroy this safe harbor. First, the guaranteed income is now a guaranteed loss. Second, at very low interest rates, the price of bonds becomes much more sensitive to even small changes in interest rates. In bond speak, the duration of all bonds is increasing<U+2014>making any upward adjustment in interest rates extremely painful. Negative real rates may hurt investors in more insidious ways as well. An extremely low cost of capital may result in excess capital investment that in turn results in boom-bust cycles of increasing frequency and magnitude. Housing, energy and steel come to mind as recent examples of excessive investing gone bad. Shopping malls and retail may well be next up at bat. Evidence of this can be seen in periodic blowouts in credit markets. It can also been seen in the sustained increase in the rolling 10-year observed volatility of the S&P 500, which has remained nearly double its long-term average even while implied or expected volatility remains very low. More broadly, a lower cost of capital lowers the bar for returns on capital investment<U+2014>potentially reducing the productivity of capital overall. We might also ask what happens to consumption spending when unprecedented aging in the world<U+2019>s largest economies meets punitive treatment of pensioners. By 2030, Rockefeller University scientist Joel Cohen notes, based on United Nations predictions, the proportion of the population over age 65 will hit 20% in the U.S. and 30% in Japan and Germany, even while expected lifespans continue to increase. That we will have to raise the retirement age seems obvious, but what will this mean for consumption and job growth? There may be a tipping point where low expected returns on savings forces more savings instead of more consumption. Whatever the cause, declining returns on investment deplete the coffers of America<U+2019>s most important incubators of science and technology. The grand experiment may well be stimulating demand in some corners<U+2014>but it is undoubtedly killing savers, pensioners and endowed institutions. It may also be impoverishing the elderly and increasing the burden of their care on the young. These are serious consequences indeed. At a very minimum, we should be examining these costs with greater urgency, honesty and analytical heft. If we have to be mice, let<U+2019>s not be blind in the bargain. Ms. Falls is the chief investment officer at Rockefeller University, where she oversees the university<U+2019>s $2 billion endowment.

Thanks to the incredibly fast processing power of computers in this day and age, early votes were counted in record time giving the soon-to-be-President an entire extra day to get ready for his imminent Presidency. The irony of an election called so early, and what Trump would have said had it been called in Hillary<U+2019>s favor about it being <U+201C>rigged<U+201D> is not lost on many Americans. Local pig farmer and regional pie eating champion Kenneth Bacon said of the results, <U+201C>Now how about that. I was gonna go vote for Hillary tomorrow, but I suppose if it<U+2019>s a lost cause I<U+2019>ll just farm some extra pigs. I know when I<U+2019>m beat and I see no reason to pretend it ain<U+2019>t how it is!<U+201D> Many analysts are perplexed by the incredibly early voter turnout in favor of Trump, citing that poll numbers just don<U+2019>t seem to match up. <U+201C>I guess Trump supporters are just a close-lipped bunch that keep their opinions to themselves,<U+201D> said Nate Silver, an American economist and well-respected predictor of both baseball and American elections. <U+201C>We just couldn<U+2019>t have seen this coming. 
To be honest with you, I<U+2019>ve lost a lot of money and am going to have quite a bit of egg on my face when I get into the office tomorrow.<U+201D> 
Even if every person that hasn<U+2019>t voted yet in the country rushed out and voted right this minute, Hillary could still not possibly win, meaning those of us that haven<U+2019>t voted can just sit back and relax. Especially Trump supporters. 
When reached for comment about the victory, Trump had few words, saying only, <U+201C>Now that I<U+2019>ve won I<U+2019>m not going to just sit back and rest on my laurels. I<U+2019>m going to get out there and start doing my damnedest to make America great again, just like I promised.<U+201D>

230.input:
time: null 
 author: Patrick Temple-West Nick Juliano Burgess Everett Andrew Restuccia Jack Shafer 
 source: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/11/trump-team-unions-activists-231875 
 text: During his time at the SEC, Atkins demonstrated a preference for putting a light touch on regulations. | Getty By Patrick Temple-West 11/28/16 10:44 AM EST Updated 11/28/16 03:25 PM EST Presidential Transition By Bob King and Nick Juliano Paul Atkins has one thing in common with Donald Trump: He doesn<U+2019>t hedge on his opinions. Atkins, a former financial regulator who is playing a major role in the Trump presidential transition, has railed against labor unions, environmentalists and gay rights groups for challenging public companies through shareholder activism. He has called companies <U+201C>weenies<U+201D> who often "cave" to social activists. And he was once the only one of 68 business leaders who refused to endorse a report recommending ways to combat <U+201C>crony capitalism<U+201D> in Washington. Story Continued Below Now Atkins, a Republican and onetime SEC member, may be in line to land a top regulatory post in the Trump administration. Atkins is meeting with Trump and Vice President-elect Mike Pence in New York on Monday. Atkins, the transition<U+2019>s team leader for financial regulatory agencies, is on the same page as Trump on a number of issues, most notably on Dodd-Frank, the sweeping market-reform law that the president-elect says he wants to dismantle. Atkins has testified in the House three times in the last three years about the side-effects of the 2010 law, which was enacted after the financial crisis and is one of President Barack Obama<U+2019>s signature policies. But comments of his, recorded at a 2012 Heritage Foundation event, reveal candid criticism of global-warming believers, organized labor and other Democratic allies. That suggests Atkins<U+2019>s influence could help companies well beyond Dodd-Frank deregulation. <U+201C>While Paul is in some ways more of an establishment Republican, I would put him in the free-market category,<U+201D> said Thaya Brook Knight, an official at the Cato Institute, a libertarian-leaning think tank. She added that she was <U+201C>thrilled<U+201D> with Atkins<U+2019> position on the Trump team. As for whether Atkins would return to government for Trump, Knight said <U+201C>it is customary<U+201D> for transition team people to end up in a president<U+2019>s administration. Others are not as thrilled at that prospect. <U+201C>Tick down the list of issues we care about and you will typically find him on the other side,<U+201D> said Lisa Gilbert, an official with Public Citizen, a liberal advocacy group. <U+201C>We are nervous about what his placement in the transition means,<U+201D> Gilbert said. Atkins<U+2019> status in Trump<U+2019>s Washington world is quickly becoming apparent. A member of the SEC from 2002 to 2008, Atkins is on the transition landing teams for multiple agencies <U+2014> the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and Office of the Comptroller of the Currency. One of Atkins<U+2019> former staffers at the SEC is also on a landing team. Atkins is a top candidate to be the Federal Reserve<U+2019>s vice chairman for supervision, according to two sources familiar with the matter. That post <U+2014> a powerful position charged with overseeing regulation of the nation<U+2019>s financial institutions <U+2014> has not been filled by the Obama administration since it was created out of Dodd-Frank. Atkins is currently chief executive of Patomak Global Partners, a consulting firm he founded, and he was a senior partner at Sphere Consulting, a public relations firm in Washington. During his time at the SEC, he demonstrated a preference for putting a light touch on regulations. He dissented from a plan to overhaul rules for the stock market in 2005. He also dissented from rules for hedge funds in 2004 that were later struck down in court. And he opposed big fines that the SEC imposed on companies as part of enforcement settlements. Another similarity to Trump is that Atkins isn<U+2019>t afraid to go against the consensus. In October 2015, he was the only dissenter among dozens of business leaders who were asked to draw up a report titled <U+201C>Crony Capitalism: Unhealthy relations between business and government.<U+201D> The report called for enacting stricter prohibitions on the revolving door from Congress to K Street lobbying firms, and it advocated for campaign-finance reform, among other measures. It is unclear why Atkins opposed the report. A spokeswoman for Atkins referred questions to the Trump transition team, which did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Atkins has also criticized labor unions, environmental organizations, gay-rights groups and state pension funds that he has said try to <U+201C>co-opt or disenfranchise<U+201D> companies. He has spoken in favor of the American Legislative Exchange Council, the controversial, Koch brothers-backed group that has pushed for voter ID laws and <U+201C>stand your ground<U+201D> statutes in many states. He has also defended anonymous <U+201C>dark money<U+201D> in politics. <U+201C>ALEC is a great organization,<U+201D> Atkins said at the July 3, 2012, Heritage Foundation event, according to an audio recording available online. In 2012, after the shooting of unarmed teenager Trayvon Martin in Florida, Coca-Cola, Kraft Foods Inc. and other businesses withdrew funding for ALEC. According to Atkins, the companies were reacting to attacks from Moveon.org and Color of Change, both liberal-leaning advocacy groups. <U+201C>This is part of a thing that we<U+2019>ve seen this year where social activists, environmental groups and other sorts of gay rights groups and others <U+2014> unions, state pension funds and even politicians <U+2014> have been very open about what their goal is,<U+201D> Atkins said at the Heritage event. <U+201C>And that is to put pressure on corporations through the shareholder proposal process.<U+201D> He also referred to the scrutiny focused on Target Corp., which in 2010 apologized for contributing to Minnesota Forward, a group that gave money to gubernatorial candidate Tom Emmer, who opposed same-sex marriage. <U+201C>Corporations usually are weenies, and they don<U+2019>t really want to be in a political fight,<U+201D> Atkins said. <U+201C>They often cave.<U+201D> Atkins made these comments during a discussion about shareholder proposals. Though they are nonbinding, votes on such proposals can steer a company<U+2019>s management toward a social cause advocated by the investor. In August 2015, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said it would stop selling the AR-15 assault rifle, despite winning a court battle with a shareholder<U+2019>s proposal seeking to rein in firearm sales at the retail giant. <U+201C>They do it all over the Fortune 500, which then gives them a megaphone of free publicity through the process and through harassment of the corporations, because then the management wants to negotiate with them to get rid of their proposal,<U+201D> Atkins said at the event, referring to activist groups. Using the shareholder voting process to push companies on social issues has been a common practice of progressive pension funds for unions. But the National Center for Public Policy Research, a conservative, tax-exempt group based in Washington, has also successfully adopted the technique. Over the years, the SEC<U+2019>s rules have been changed to benefit social activists, and that needs to swing back, he said. <U+201C>The next big fight is going to be over corporate governance rules and shareholder communications and how corporations interact with shareholders,<U+201D> he told the audience. <U+201C>Because right now the rules have really drifted way off to one side like I said between co-opting and disenfranchising. So I think it is going to have to be radically changed back.<U+201D> Labor unions will resist the rule changes, Atkins said. As their memberships decline, the unions are well aware of the tactical value the shareholder process gives them. <U+201C>This is their last power,<U+201D> he said. Presidential Transition By Burgess Everett Presidential Transition By Andrew Restuccia By Bill Scher By Joshua Zeitz By Thomas Wright By Jack Shafer

232.input:
time: null 
 author: Nolan D. McCaskill Jack Shafer 
 source: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/11/never-trump-critics-offer-trump-congrats-2016-election-231106 
 text: <U+201C>Congratulations on your victory @realDonaldTrump,<U+201D> tweeted Jeb Bush. | AP Photo By Nolan D. McCaskill and Katie Glueck 11/09/16 01:24 PM EST So much for the Republican resistance. Reality has set in for the Never Trump Republicans, who just days ago were strategizing about how to reshape their party in a post-Trump world. Now, they are coming to terms with the harsh truth: They lost, Trumpism won and there is little appetite right now for any of the GOP internecine warfare that raged for much of this year, even in the name of principle. Story Continued Below <U+201C>Let<U+2019>s just say the pause button just got hit on the Republican civil war in the aftermath of a victory where the Republican Party is in a stronger position, top to bottom, than it<U+2019>s been in, say, 100 years,<U+201D> said David French, a conservative leader of the Never Trump movement who was so disheartened by the presidential options earlier this year that he weighed mounting his own independent bid. <U+201C>It doesn<U+2019>t mean there won<U+2019>t be strife and division. But as far as any large-scale GOP conflict, that<U+2019>s not going to happen. This is a large-scale GOP win. There may be some score-settling directed toward the Never Trumpers, but the electoral impact of Never Trump was marginal at best.<U+201D> It<U+2019>s a sharp departure from what many Never Trumpers were expecting and hoping for days ago: Serious soul-searching about how to make the party more inclusive, and how to ensure that what they saw as Trump<U+2019>s brand of grievance-driven populism and nativism didn<U+2019>t define the GOP going forward. Expecting a Trump loss, many saw an opportunity to reshape their party going forward, and were eager to see the hardline views<U+2014>and people and organizations<U+2014>who helped propel Trump forward, stamped out. <U+201C>The fear a lot of people have is that the energy is with the Breitbart crowd, and people who would consider themselves to be more traditional Republicans, who do they rally behind? Who<U+2019>s the leader, the face of that?<U+201D> said a former GOP party official in an interview before the election. <U+201C>There<U+2019>s a lot of concern going around.<U+201D> And with good reason. As the dust settles, it<U+2019>s not clear that they have anyone else to rally behind: Trump, as the president-elect, is the new head of the GOP, and some of his most pointed critics made sure to offer public expressions of support. <U+201C>Best wishes for our duly elected president: May his victory speech be his guide and preserving the Republic his aim,<U+201D> tweeted Mitt Romney, the 2012 GOP nominee who delivered a speech in Utah encouraging Republican primary voters to support whichever candidate had the best chance to beat Trump in a given state. Romney, along with former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, Ohio Gov. John Kasich, South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham and Nebraska Sen. Ben Sasse, did not vote for Trump. <U+201C>Congratulations on your victory @realDonaldTrump,<U+201D> tweeted Jeb Bush, who Trump savaged during the primary and dubbed <U+201C>low energy.<U+201D> <U+201C>As our President, Columba and I will pray for you in the days and months to come.<U+201D> <U+201C>The American people have spoken and it<U+2019>s time to come together. Congratulations President-elect @realDonaldTrump ,<U+201D> Kasich, who voted for 2008 GOP nominee John McCain, wrote on Twitter. Graham and Sasse, darlings of the Never Trump movement, also offered congratulatory words and sounded conciliatory notes, pointing to areas where they hoped to work together. It<U+2019>s not that the conservatives who staunchly opposed Trump have suddenly come around to embracing his views on the issues and tone they have long found troubling. Many continue to have grave concerns, and some are considering leaving the party for good, fearing that a Trump-led GOP will cater, above all, to angry older white voters who propelled Trump<U+2019>s candidacy, though clearly his appeal ultimately went beyond just that constituency, as Democratic turnout for Hillary Clinton also appeared to be down. <U+201C>From my point of view, that<U+2019>s a huge problem for the Republican Party: Is it going to be a party for all Americans, not merely white Americans?<U+201D> asked Avik Roy, a prominent conservative who has advocated for a more inclusive Republican Party. <U+201C>While there are going to be plenty of partisan Republicans happy about Trump winning, it<U+2019>s not going to mean anything over the long term unless the Republican Party can be a party that addresses the concerns of all Americans, and builds a coalition that is demographically diverse.<U+201D> But in the short term, they<U+2019>re hoping for the best and staying focused on the good news: Republican control of both chambers of Congress, with enough Republicans in leadership positions who take more of a traditional GOP perspective on issues like free trade and an internationalist foreign policy, and have used more inclusive language toward immigrants. <U+201C>I hope some of his more heated rhetoric was campaign trail rhetoric, and when he gets into office he sits down coolly and calmly and talks with Republican leaders in Congress like Speaker Ryan,<U+201D> said Brendan Steinhauser, a conservative operative who was a vocal Trump opponent. Still, he and other conservatives maintained that conservatives need to continue to press their case, even if the Never Trump vehicle for doing so faces defeat. <U+201C>I guess NeverTrump has been overtaken by events!<U+201D> said Bill Kristol, the editor of the conservative publication The Weekly Standard. <U+201C>But American conservatism (which incorporates classical liberalism) remains far preferable, in my view, to nanny-state progressivism or grievance-stoking populism. So we conservatives have to do three things at once: adapt to new circumstances, do a better job of persuading, and keep the flag flying.<U+201D> On Twitter, he was even more blunt about the state of the movement. <U+201C>To my fellow #NeverTrumpers,<U+201D> tweeted, <U+201C>Let us be magnanimous losers.<U+201D> By Bill Scher By Thomas Wright By Joshua Zeitz By Jack Shafer

time: null 
 author: noauthor 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-president-clinton-could-give-germany-a-backbone-1477336233 
 text: When asked who they would like to be the next President of the United States, 90% of Germans say Hillary Clinton, a major public-opinion organization reported in mid-October. Four percent favored Donald Trump. That may be just another poll, but if Mrs. Clinton is elected it should serve as encouragement for her tough-on-Russia views, and for putting them forward directly to Chancellor Angela Merkel as the leader of the United States<U+2019> most important ally. Just how far the European Union, and Germany as its essential member, are from any kind of decisive response to Russia<U+2019>s savagery in Syria or anywhere else was demonstrated last week when the EU said it is <U+201C>considering all available options should the current atrocities continue.<U+201D> The wording of the final document was defanged to remove references from earlier drafts to <U+201C>sanctions,<U+201D> or to Russians who might be targeted by them. Threats of using <U+201C>all available options<U+201D> were about as likely to scare Vladimir Putin as the Obama administration<U+2019>s repetition of the word <U+201C>unacceptable<U+201D> spooked the mullahs during negotiations with Iran on a nuclear weapons agreement. An accompanying and revelatory glimpse on the enforcement of existing EU sanctions: Vladislav Surkov, a Russian regime figure who has been barred from entry into the EU since 2014 following Russia<U+2019>s seizure of Crimea, attended a meeting Wednesday in Berlin between Mr. Putin and Mrs. Merkel to discuss Ukraine. A German press report said he had received a special dispensation. Here<U+2019>s a scared Germany, declining in stability, in the midst of an ineffectual Europe. The pillars of probity that were Deutsche Bank and Volkswagen are gone; Bundeswehr units supporting the anti-Islamic State coalition avoid lethal action in Iraq; and a pro-Russian right-wing party is likely to enter the Bundestag in 2017. Mrs. Clinton surely sees the chancellor<U+2019>s relative fragility. But there is one area in relation to Russia where, as a president-elect, she could urge Mrs. Merkel to take a nonmilitary but realpolitik stance that would represent Germany reuniting with its better instincts. Mrs. Clinton should call on the chancellor to renounce the construction of Nord Stream 2, the second Russia-to-Germany direct undersea natural-gas pipeline. Scheduled to come online in 2019, it<U+2019>s backed by Gazprom and five European minority investors, two of them German. European critics have called it dangerous and politically inspired because Nord Stream 2 would dramatically increase Europe<U+2019>s and Germany<U+2019>s dependency on Russian-sourced natural gas to 80% and 60%, respectively. The pipeline replicates the Baltic Sea track of Nord Stream 1, which currently operates at only 70% of its intended capacity. Nord Stream 1 was promoted by Gerhard Schr<U+00F6>der, the former Social Democratic chancellor, whose political desires included Germany<U+2019>s <U+201C>emancipation<U+201D> from America. Since his defeat by Mrs. Merkel in 2005, he has served as a Gazprom shill, being named this month as chairman of Nord Stream 2. Before Mrs. Clinton was photographed holding the symbolic button for the Obama administration<U+2019>s failed reset with Russia, she had warned in 2009, as the designated U.S. Secretary of State, that Russian control of European energy supply was <U+201C>a challenge we ignore at our peril.<U+201D> Now, it<U+2019>s time to block Nord Stream 2. This would hardly be good ol<U+2019> unilateral America in action, although that wouldn<U+2019>t be a bad thing under the circumstances. Also vigorously opposed are German mainstream heavyweights such as Manfred Weber, who heads the Christian Democrat political grouping in the European Parliament, and to his left, Reinhard B<U+00FC>tikofer, who is chief of the Greens<U+2019> delegation. Norbert R<U+00F6>ttgen, the Christian Democratic president of the Bundestag<U+2019>s foreign-relations commission, in a reference to linking Nord Stream 2 and Russia<U+2019>s Syrian abominations, told me: <U+201C>What we need is a transatlantic relaunch helping to redefine the German-American approach to an aggressive Russia.<U+201D> But Mrs. Merkel is described as regarding the pipeline as a private, commercial project, although she campaigned in 2005 to stop Nord Stream 1. Within months of her election, she flip-flopped to endorse the project and assuage her Social Democrat coalition partners. Eleven years later, led by Vice Chancellor Sigmar Gabriel, the Social Democrats remain zealous, Russia-friendly advocates of Nord Stream 2. The chancellor has not pushed back. Could a newly elected President Clinton, seemingly willing to reassert an American leadership role on Russia, decide that fighting off its energy hold on Europe can wait without risking peril? Remember that in 2010 she rolled back her call for crippling sanctions against Iran in favor of <U+201C>smart<U+201D> ones that <U+201C>would not contribute to the suffering of everyday Iranians.<U+201D> Here<U+2019>s a test of credibility. In order to pass, Mrs. Clinton has to tell Mrs. Merkel and the 90% of Germans supporting her candidacy against Mr. Trump that they cannot allow Mr. Putin to employ new energy exports to finance Russia<U+2019>s dearest destructive goals<U+2014>which unmistakably aim at Germany<U+2019>s effective neutralization.

235.input:
time: null 
 author: Natalie Andrews 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/hillary-clinton-supporters-plan-to-sport-pansuits-at-the-polls-1478208739 
 text: Libby Chamberlain says she will honor her presidential pick, Hillary Clinton, on Election Day with more than a vote. She also plans to wear a pantsuit. Ms. Chamberlain, 33, has also recruited thousands of others who are hoping to see the election of the first female U.S. president. A private Facebook group she created dubbing<U+00A0>Nov. 8<U+00A0>as <U+201C>National Pantsuit Day<U+201D> has drawn more than 600,000 members<U+00A0>in two weeks. On the page, the invitation-only members trade stories about their admiration for the Democratic nominee and discuss plans to sport their own version of Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s signature campaign-trail attire. <U+201C>There is a literal pantsuit thing happening, which does involve shopping for some and rummaging around in closets for others,<U+201D> Ms. Chamberlain said. <U+201C>But so much more important is the idea that we can take this symbol of feminism and the struggle for equality and own it. Literally wear it to the polls.<U+201D> Republican rival Donald Trump <U+2019>s backers are also seeking to show support for their candidate. On some conservative blogs and Reddit, they are encouraging each other to wear red on<U+00A0>Nov. 8. Mr. Trump<U+2019>s warning that the election could be rigged has some supporters nervous that their vote won<U+2019>t be counted. Their solution: Create a sea of red that can<U+2019>t be ignored. The same <U+201C>wear red<U+201D> text has been copied and pasted repeatedly, like a modern-day chain letter, on the message board Reddit and multiple conservative blogs. Some of Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s fans face a tricky challenge: finding a pantsuit. The candidate<U+2019>s clothes are custom made, and pantsuits aren<U+2019>t a staple in many women<U+2019>s closets. At 67, Camy Clough remembers when she wasn<U+2019>t allowed to wear pants to work. Then, she had a closet full of pantsuits as they came into vogue in the 1970s. She recently donated many of them to charity but luckily kept a few in the closet. <U+201C>I have a black tweedy pantsuit, and then I<U+2019>m hoping the next day I can come to work wearing ivory slacks and a sweater with a scarf that has purple and gold in it,<U+201D> said Ms. Clough, a museum educator in Washington, D.C. <U+201C>That<U+2019>s all of the colors of the women<U+2019>s suffrage movement.<U+201D> Historically, pants were seen as a man<U+2019>s prerogative. As women started wearing loose versions of what are now known as pants in the latter half of the 1800s, it was seen as usurping gender roles, said Kevin Jones, museum curator for the Fashion Institute of Design & Merchandising in Los Angeles. The modern women<U+2019>s pantsuit, often monotone or patterned slacks and a jacket, hit the stage with the women<U+2019>s movement of the 1970s. <U+201C>That<U+2019>s what we know it as today, the <U+2018>power suit,<U+2019> <U+201D> said Kevin Jones, museum curator for the Fashion Institute of Design & Merchandising in Los Angeles. <U+201C>That was a really heady time of a woman wearing whatever she wanted to wear.<U+201D> Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s candidacy has the potential to turn it into the ultimate power outfit. On the campaign trail, she has embraced the sometimes-maligned ensemble as a badge of honor<U+2014>much like the way her female fans latched onto Mr. Trump<U+2019>s <U+201C>nasty woman<U+201D> labeling in their final debate. Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s Twitter bio describes her as a <U+201C>pantsuit-aficionado,<U+201D> and she<U+2019>s nicknamed some of her most ardent followers as <U+201C>my sisterhood of the traveling pantsuits.<U+201D> The campaign<U+2019>s website offered an <U+201C>everyday pantsuit<U+201D> unisex T-shirt for $30 until it sold out. It is now on a wait list. Amanda Reddy, 38, stopped at a department store near her home in Columbia, Md., to pick up a white pantsuit. When the sales clerk complimented Ms. Reddy on her choice, Ms. Reddy told her it was in honor of the suffragists who had campaigned for the Nineteenth Amendment that gave women the right to vote. <U+201C>They used fashion to create a visual identity for their movement and to make it easy for others to express support, even if they weren<U+2019>t the ones being arrested or harassed in the street,<U+201D> Ms. Reddy said. <U+201C>So the white pantsuit is for them.<U+201D> After hearing the story, the saleswoman gave Ms. Reddy a discount. Ms. Chamberlain started her Facebook group so she and her friends would have a place to stand <U+201C>together in a great big pant-suited mass telling each other stories and lifting each other up after an election season that has left many of us wounded, jostled, disheartened, and afraid.<U+201D> As one friend invited another, the group ballooned. In a week, it had 100,000 members.<U+00A0>In 10 days, there were 200,000. As of<U+00A0>Friday, they stood at more than 609,000. Her friend, Caddie Jackson, 34, of Massachusetts, plans to match her candidate, right down to the color she wore in the third debate. <U+201C>I went out right away and I bought a white pantsuit that I<U+2019>m so excited to wear on<U+00A0>Nov. 8,<U+201D> Ms. Jackson said. It cost her $8 at Goodwill. Elana Snow, an administrator in Somerville, Mass., surveyed her closet, which is full of professional separates that could be pulled together, but no pantsuits. <U+201C>I think I<U+2019>m just going to go to Goodwill and get a matchy bright one,<U+201D> she said. Ms. Chamberlain, a school counselor in the Blue Hill area of Maine, had hoped to shop for her outfit this week but lost time managing her growing Facebook project. She<U+00A0>ordered three pantsuits online, two from Macy<U+2019>s and one from Amazon, to have one in time for Election Day. Write to Natalie Andrews at Natalie.Andrews@wsj.com

 text: Duterte Calls US Admin <U+2018>Monkeys<U+2019> for Halting Arms Sales November 02, 2016 Duterte Calls US Admin 'Monkeys' for Halting Arms Sales 
(MANILA) - Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte chided the United States on Wednesday for halting the planned sale of 26,000 rifles to his country, calling those behind the decision "fools" and "monkeys" and indicating he might turn to Russia and China instead. Duterte's tirades against the former colonial power are routine during his speeches and he said on Wednesday he once believed in Washington, but had since lost respect for what is the Philippines' biggest ally. The U.S. State Department halted the sale of the assault rifles to the Philippine police after U.S. Senator Ben Cardin said he would oppose it, Senate aides told Reuters on Monday. Aides said Cardin, the top Democrat on the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee, was reluctant for the United States to provide the weapons given concern about human rights violations in the Philippines during Duterte's bloody, four-month-old war on drugs. 
"Look at these monkeys, the 26,000 firearms we wanted to buy, they don't want to sell," Dutertesaid during a televised speech. 
"Son of a b***h, we have many home-made guns here. These American fools." 
More than 2,300 people have been killed in police operations or by suspected vigilantes as part of Duterte's anti-narcotics campaign, which was the lynchpin of his election campaign. 
Duterte has vented his anger at the United States for raising concerns about the extra-judicial killings. 
"That's why I was rude at them, because they were rude at me," he said. 
According to procedures in Washington, the State Department informs Congress when international weapons sales are in the works. Aides said the State Department had been informed Cardin would oppose the deal during the prenotification process, thus halting the sale. 
U.S. State Department officials did not comment. 
The Philippine police chief, Ronald dela Rosa, on Tuesday expressed disappointment that police would not get the M4 rifles, which he said were reliable. 
Duterte reiterated that Russia and China had shown willingness to sell arms to the Philippines, but he would wait to see if his military wanted to continue using U.S. weapons. 
"Russia, they are inviting us. China also. China is open, anything you want, they sent me brochure saying we select there, we'll give you. 
"But I am holding off because I was asking the military if they have any problem. Because if you have, if you want to stick to America, fine. 
"But, look closely and balance the situation, they are rude to us." Article by Doc Burkhart , Vice-President, General Manager and co-host of TRUNEWS with Rick Wiles Got a news tip?
