273.input:
time: null 
 author: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS GARDINER HARRIS 
 source: https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/08/us/politics/obama-donald-trump.html?_r=0 
 text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. <U+2014> President Obama was feeling a little sentimental. His shirt sleeves rolled up, his vowels slipping off the ends of his words, his last day on the campaign trail finally here, Mr. Obama soaked up an unseasonably warm autumn sun on a baseball field at the University of Michigan on Monday, and drank in the energy of his political finale. <U+201C>We<U+2019>ve got one more day, Michigan <U+2014> one more day,<U+201D> he said, gazing out over a crowd of more than 9,000 at midday. But Mr. Obama was not quite ready for it to be over. <U+201C>This is gonna be my last<U+201D> <U+2014> he caught himself <U+2014> <U+201C>probably my last day of campaigning for a while.<U+201D> For Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton , Monday<U+2019>s cross-country travels were all about tomorrow. For Mr. Obama, his travels here to Michigan, and then to New Hampshire and Philadelphia, were part victory lap and part nostalgia tour, as he was accompanied on Air Force One by some of his longest-serving aides, and was ushered in and out of rallies by the same U2 and Bruce Springsteen anthems that were the soundtracks of his campaigns. But his core mission was to implore voters across the country to rally behind Mrs. Clinton on Tuesday, or see the values and ideals that fueled his rise and powered his agenda defeated. So Mr. Obama stumped on Monday with the fervor of a man battling to preserve his legacy and with the joy of one who has watched his approval ratings tick higher as the presidential race<U+2019>s tenor has sunk ever lower, savoring the almost palpable sense at Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s rallies that Americans will miss him when he is gone. <U+201C>Whatever credibility I<U+2019>ve earned after eight years as president,<U+201D> Mr. Obama said, <U+201C>I am asking you to trust me on this one.<U+201D> <U+201C>I already voted,<U+201D> he added. <U+201C>I voted for Hillary Clinton, because I am absolutely confident that when she is president, this country will be in good hands <U+2014> and I<U+2019>m asking you to do the same.<U+201D> <U+201C>I love you!<U+201D> supporters kept shouting at the president as he turned serious to lay out the stakes of an extraordinary race. <U+201C>I love you back <U+2014> I do,<U+201D> Mr. Obama said in Michigan. <U+201C>But tomorrow, you will choose whether we continue this journey of progress, or whether it all goes out the window.<U+201D> Nostalgia aside, there was no mistaking the seriousness of his message. Mr. Trump could never be trusted with control over the nation<U+2019>s nuclear arsenal, the president said, if his own staff regarded him as too temperamental to use restraint on social media. <U+201C>Over the weekend, his campaign took away his Twitter account,<U+201D> Mr. Obama said, referring to a report in T he New York Times about the closing days of Mr. Trump<U+2019>s campaign. <U+201C>Now, if your closest advisers don<U+2019>t trust you to tweet, then how can we trust him with the nuclear codes?<U+201D> <U+201C>Donald Trump is temperamentally unfit to be commander in chief,<U+201D> Mr. Obama said. <U+201C>He<U+2019>s unqualified to be America<U+2019>s chief executive.<U+201D> Mr. Obama began his day at the White House, striding out of the residence to board Marine One just after 9:30 a.m. to begin his final campaign sprint. He rarely paused in the hours that followed, jetting from state to state on Air Force One, speeding from airport to rally site and back again in his armored limousine, racing against the clock on a historic presidential contest and his own campaign denouement. In New Hampshire, his motorcade rushed at sunset down roads flanked by flaming-red and burnt-orange foliage to deliver him to a rally that drew more than 7,600. At the airport in Portsmouth, he confessed to a young boy who asked about the presidential jumbo jet that he was reluctant to relinquish Air Force One. <U+201C>I am going to miss this plane,<U+201D> he told the boy with a smile. <U+201C>I only have it for a few more months.<U+201D> His itinerary on Monday took the president to three states that he won in 2008 and 2012, and that are now crucial bulwarks for Mrs. Clinton. All three are also places where it is more difficult for Democrats to turn out their core supporters because they do not offer early voting. <U+201C>It<U+2019>s not that often you get the chance to move history in a better direction,<U+201D> Mr. Obama said. <U+201C>This is one of those moments. Don<U+2019>t let it slip away.<U+201D> In Michigan, he allowed himself a few moments to gloat, reminding voters of all that his administration had done to pull American automobile makers from the brink of bankruptcy. <U+201C>I think I<U+2019>ve earned some credibility here,<U+201D> Mr. Obama said tartly, repeating the phrase three times as he checked off the metrics of a resurgent automobile industry and recovering manufacturing sector. He returned to his trademark campaign-trail catchphrases. As he elicited jeers by reciting a litany of criticisms of Mr. Trump <U+2014> his not paying taxes, his comments about immigrants, women and Muslims <U+2014> Mr. Obama barked, <U+201C>Don<U+2019>t boo. Vote!<U+201D> He sparked chants of <U+201C>Yes we can!<U+201D> and <U+201C>O-BAM-A.<U+201D> In Durham, N.H., he returned to the now-familiar story about how his 2008 campaign found its signature <U+201C>Fired up! Ready to go!<U+201D> theme, borrowed from a woman in a small town in South Carolina, whom he met after getting soaked in a driving rain to attend a gathering of only about 20 people. <U+201C>Every meeting she goes to, she does this thing<U+201D> of chanting the refrain, Mr. Obama said. <U+201C>Which is kind of strange. But the thing is that after a while, I get kind of fired up,<U+201D> Mr. Obama said. <U+201C>I<U+2019>m starting to feel like I<U+2019>m ready to go.<U+201D> When he retired to his cabin on Air Force One, Mr. Obama sat with senior adviser Valerie B. Jarrett, a confidante whose friendship with Mr. Obama dates to his Chicago days, and Susan E. Rice, his national security adviser. Brian Deese, his senior adviser for climate change, came too, along with Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary who has been with him throughout his presidency, and David Simas, his political director. But it was in the thronging crowd that Mr. Obama seemed to relive his campaign experience most poignantly. In Ann Arbor, he lingered for several minutes after he finished speaking, clasping hands with supporters and grinning at them broadly, as the strains of Mr. Springsteen<U+2019>s <U+201C>Land of Hope and Dreams<U+201D> pulsed the stadium, a throwback to four years ago. Then he turned on his heel to go, and a sudden cheer went up as people throughout the emptying stadium raised their arms and gave the president one final wave goodbye. Julie Hirschfeld Davis reported from Ann Arbor, Mich., and Gardiner Harris from Durham, N.H. A version of this article appears in print on November 8, 2016, on Page A1 of the New York edition with the headline: An Energized Obama Stumps for Clinton, and His Own Legacy. Order Reprints | Today's Paper | Subscribe

 author: Kaitlyn Stegall

 text: November 8, 2016 Undermining America: Did Obama Just Encourage Illegals to Vote? 
In perhaps the most tortured presidential answer since Bill Clinton parsed the word <U+201C>is,<U+201D> Barack Obama offered a response in a Friday interview that many say gives illegal aliens a green light to vote. Worse still, there may be reason to suspect he was fed the question in advance and gave a premeditated, Machiavellian answer. 
While talking to actress and rapper Gina Rodriguez on the Latin-oriented YouTube channel MiTu, Obama was asked, <U+201C>Many of the millennials, dreamers, undocumented, um, citizens <U+2014> and I call them citizens because they contribute to this country <U+2014> are fearful of voting. So if I vote, will immigration know where I live? Will they come for my family and deport us?<U+201D> Here was Obama<U+2019>s answer (video below): 
Not true. And the reason is, first of all, when you vote, you are a citizen yourself <U+2014> and there is not a situation where the voting rolls somehow are transferred over and people start investigating, et cetera. The sanctity of the vote is strictly confidential in terms of who you voted for.

275.input:
time: null 
 author: Jason Ditz | Antiwar.com 
 source: mintpressnews.com 
 text: Videos US Backed Saudi Airstrikes Kill 100 Yemenis In Two Days Saudi Arabia has been coming under growing international criticism for its air war against Yemen, with massive numbers of civilians killed and little sign that the promised improvements to targeting will ever amount to anything. | October 31, 2016 Be Sociable, Share! People gather at the al-Zaydiya security headquarters that was destroyed by Saudi-led airstrikes Saturday, in the Red Sea port city of Hodeida, Yemen, Sunday, Oct. 30, 2016. Security and medical officials say dozens of prisoners and security personnel are feared dead after airstrikes battered two prisons inside the security headquarters. (AP Photo/Abdoo Alkarim Alayashy) 
While the biggest single Saudi airstrike over the weekend in Yemen targeted a prison in Hodeidah, dozens of other strikes were reported over the weekend by villagers around Taiz and in the Maarib Province, with attacks killing at least 27 civilians , and wounding a number of others. 
Most of the casualties were in Taiz, where attacks destroyed several homes and caused a large number of injuries. With hospitals in the area having very limited access to medicine because of the naval blockade, many of those injuries proved fatal. 
The attacks in Maarib and Saada, however, may prove more devastating to the country in the long run, targeting some of the very limited farmland Yemen has, destroying a number of villagers<U+2019> homes and burning a lot of that farmland. Yemen has to import some 90 percent of its food under normal circumstances, with such imports severely limited by the blockade, and the loss of farmland just adds to food insecurity in the nation. 
Saudi Arabia has been coming under growing international criticism for its air war against Yemen, with massive numbers of civilians killed and little sign that the promised improvements to targeting will ever amount to anything. 
Previous article from Anti-war.com From October 30th: 
Mostly destroyed and no longer usable, the prison in the Yemeni city of Hodeidah held 84 inmates until Saturday, when Saudi Arabian warplanes repeatedly bombed it, killing at least 60 of the people within and wounding dozens of others. 
The exact number of prisoners killed compared to guards is unknown, though prisoners are said to be the vast majority. The prison was leveled in the attack, according to witnesses, and rescue workers are still looking through the rubble, with others believed trapped within. 
Three airstrikes were targeted against the prison, with the first hitting it directly, bringing down the roof, and the follow-up attacks targeting the gates and the administration buildings. The Saudi coalition insisted the attacks were in keeping with targeting procedures, noting the prison was known to have Houthi security forces within. 
It is unclear who the prisoners generally were at the prison, but deliberately attacking a prison will doubtless add to concerns about Saudi Arabia<U+2019>s standards for airstrikes against Yemen, which have killed massive numbers of civilians over the past 19 months. 
This article originally appeared in Anti-War.com Be Sociable, Share!

 author: Louis Nelson Nolan D. McCaskill Jack Shafer 
 source: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/trump-alicia-machado-joe-biden-229055 
 text: By Louis Nelson 10/03/16 02:41 PM EDT Asking the crowd gathered before him to consider the <U+201C>character<U+201D> of Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, Vice President Joe Biden mocked the Manhattan billionaire for his week-long feud with a former Miss Universe winner. <U+201C>You<U+2019>ve got to really think about the character of someone. What type of leader awakens at three o<U+2019>clock in the morning,<U+201D> Biden said at a Hillary Clinton rally in Orlando, pausing as the crowd interrupted him with laughter. <U+201C>No, no, no, no, no, I<U+2019>m being deadly earnest. You don<U+2019>t have to be a psychologist or psychiatrist, but what kind of a leader awakens at three o<U+2019>clock in the morning and tweets Hillary helped, quote, disgusting Alicia M, become a U.S. citizen so she could use her in a debate. Or 3:30 in the morning? This guy wants to be president of the United States of America.<U+201D> Story Continued Below The wee-hours Twitter rant to which Biden referred occurred early last Friday morning, punctuating a week that Trump<U+2019>s team spent defending itself in the face of the GOP nominee<U+2019>s long history of derogatory remarks towards women. At last week<U+2019>s presidential debate, Clinton recalled Alicia Machado, who was crowned Miss Universe in 1996 and who Trump called <U+201C>Miss Piggy,<U+201D> because of her supposed weight gain, and <U+201C>Miss Housekeeping,<U+201D> referencing her Hispanic heritage. In his Friday flurry of Twitter posts, Trump went on to charge that Clinton had been <U+201C>duped and used<U+201D> by Machado. He urged his followers to <U+201C>check out [Machado<U+2019>s] sex tape and past,<U+201D> references to a 1998 murder investigation in which she was never charged and rumors that she has appeared in pornographic films, of which there is no evidence. By Nolan D. McCaskill After Clinton brought her up at the debate, Machado quickly vaulted into the political spotlight, doing interviews with NBC<U+2019>s <U+201C>Today<U+201D> show and Cosmopolitan Magazine. She told the latter that Trump<U+2019>s name-calling had triggered a return of her bulimia that took her years to recover from and that she had become a U.S. citizen this summer specifically so that she could vote against the real estate mogul. In response, Trump told Fox News that Machado was <U+201C>the worst we ever had<U+201D> at the Miss Universe pageant because <U+201C>she gained a massive amount of weight, and it was a real problem.<U+201D> He added that of all the slights Clinton had launched his way at Monday night<U+2019>s debate, recalling Machado was the only one that got under his skin. Aside from the issue of Trump<U+2019>s treatment of Machado, Biden also attacked the Manhattan billionaire<U+2019>s lack of awareness on issues of foreign policy. He slammed Trump<U+2019>s <U+201C>unabashed admiration<U+201D> for Russian President Vladimir Putin and seeming ignorance in a past interview that Russia had invaded Ukraine. <U+201C>To his credit he recently acknowledged he realized Crimea is part of Ukraine, which is like he<U+2019>s going to acknowledge there<U+2019>s gravity later, too,<U+201D> Biden joked. The vice president seemed unable to help himself from taking another shot at Trump when a baby began crying at the start of his remarks. <U+201C>Unlike Trump I really don<U+2019>t mind, the baby crying, I mean,<U+201D> Biden said, recalling a Trump campaign event over the summer when Trump ejected a baby who was making noise during his speech. By Thomas Wright By Bill Scher By Joshua Zeitz By Jack Shafer

277.input:
time: null 
 author: Valerie Bauerlein Laura Meckler 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/hillary-clinton-makes-a-big-push-for-north-carolina-1475709556 
 text: RALEIGH, N.C.<U+2014>In the cool production room of Raleigh<U+2019>s Trophy Brewing this week, some 130 women lifted glasses of wine and craft beer while belting out Helen Reddy<U+2019>s 1970s anthem <U+201C>I Am Woman.<U+201D> The loose-knit group began meeting a month ago, hoping to persuade women not typically active in politics to register voters, knock on doors and help elect Hillary Clinton. <U+201C>I<U+2019>ve always voted, but I never really got involved. I couldn<U+2019>t be silent any more. Voting is not enough,<U+201D> said Tonya Debnam, a Realtor. She was one of more than 360 people who turned up for a debate-watching party<U+00A0>hosted by the group last week. North Carolina was a reach for then-Sen. Barack Obama in 2008, when he barely won the state, and an afterthought in 2012, when he barely lost it. This year, it has become central to the Clinton strategy. The Clinton campaign chose the state for Mr. Obama<U+2019>s first campaign rally this year. Mrs. Clinton has headlined four events there since<U+00A0>Sept. 1, and it is the only battleground she has appeared in more times over that span than Republican Donald Trump. The campaign has had staff on the ground since April and has 33 offices in the state. Since<U+00A0>Aug. 1, the Clinton campaign and supportive groups have spent or reserved more than $22 million on TV ads in North Carolina, according to an independent ad tracker. That is nearly as much spending as in Pennsylvania. The last six public polls have all had Mrs. Clinton ahead, though often inside the margin of error. A survey released<U+00A0>Tuesday by Elon University showed her leading Mr. Trump, 45% to 39%, among likely voters. Mrs. Clinton had trailed him<U+00A0>by one point in a September Elon poll. North Carolina isn<U+2019>t the easiest state for Mrs. Clinton to win, or even the most important, Clinton advisers say. But they see it as a <U+201C>roadblock<U+201D><U+2014>if she can take it, Mr. Trump<U+2019>s path to victory becomes much more difficult. Many Democrats now say the simplest Electoral College path for Mrs. Clinton would be to win the swing state of Virginia, where she is polling well, and hold the traditionally Democratic states of Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin, plus all the other safe Democratic states. Under that scenario, a win in North Carolina would bring Mrs. Clinton victory, even if she lost Ohio, Florida and every other competitive state. Before 2008, Democrats hadn<U+2019>t won a presidential contest in North Carolina since 1976, and their improving fortunes are mostly due to changing demographics. It is among the fastest-growing and -urbanizing states, and a place where newcomers will hold significant sway in the presidential election. North Carolina grew by<U+00A0>5.3% from 2000 to 2015, faster than the national rate of 4.1%,<U+00A0>according to the<U+00A0>Census Bureau.<U+00A0>About 27%<U+00A0>of<U+00A0>that population increase took place in Democratic strongholds<U+2014>Mecklenburg County, home to Charlotte, and Wake County, home to Raleigh. A Clinton victory, if it comes, would be built on votes from African-Americans and left-leaning transplants. About half of North Carolina<U+2019>s registered voters are now from somewhere else, according to a September analysis of state elections data by Rebecca Tippett, who directs Carolina Demography at the<U+00A0>University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. New York is the second most common birthplace, followed by places like Virginia, Pennsylvania and Ohio. <U+201C>This is a real purple state now,<U+201D> said Jim Hunt, a Democrat who served as the state<U+2019>s governor for 16 years over two stints. <U+201C>It<U+2019>s getting bluer and bluer.<U+201D> Lawrence Shaheen, a Republican consultant in suburban Charlotte, predicted North Carolina would be decided in the suburbs, where Mrs. Clinton is benefiting from unease with Mr. Trump and the state law known as House Bill 2. The law, championed by Republican Gov. Pat McCrory, requires transgender people to use the public bathroom corresponding with the gender on their birth certificate. It has led to boycotts of the state, and Mr. Shaheen said the law had made it difficult for his legislative clients to raise funds in the suburbs. A Clinton campaign aide said controversy over the law has mobilized Democrats and helps Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s chances. Democrats appear to be off to a strong start in early voting, which is expected to make up as much as 60% of all ballots cast. As of<U+00A0>Wednesday,<U+00A0>17,317 ballots had been accepted, a slight drop from this time in 2012, according to an analysis by Michael Bitzer, a political scientist at Catawba College in Salisbury, N.C. Still, Democrats are ahead of where they were four years ago in returned and accepted, or properly completed, ballots, while Republicans lag behind their pace of four years ago, Mr. Bitzer said. The state and national Republican<U+00A0>parties have 175 paid staffers on the ground and are coordinating with the Trump campaign, which has a small but growing staff here, according to the state party executive director. Last week the state GOP began holding <U+201C>Trump<U+00A0>Tuesday<U+201D> volunteer training parties at a dozen sites. On Sunday, Mrs. Clinton campaigned in Charlotte , visiting an African-American church. Two days later, first lady Michelle Obama campaigned in Charlotte and Raleigh, where she addressed some 6,000 people at North Carolina State University. She said Mrs. Clinton could win North Carolina, but only if young people turned out and voted for her. <U+201C>It<U+2019>s not enough to come to a rally, get a selfie,<U+201D> she said. <U+201C>I know y<U+2019>all love your selfies.<U+201D> She added: <U+201C>Elections aren<U+2019>t just about who votes, but who doesn<U+2019>t vote.<U+201D> Write to Valerie Bauerlein at valerie.bauerlein@wsj.com and Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com

278.input:
time: null 
 author: noauthor 
 source: trunews.com 
 text: Dueling Drills Further Increase NATO Russia Tensions November 03, 2016 Dueling Drills Further Increase NATO Russia Tensions 
Irked by NATO's disaster-relief drills in Montenegro, Russia held special forces exercises with its Balkan neighbour Serbia on Wednesday. In Montenegro, which split from Serbia a decade ago, NATO is on Friday due to wrap up a five-day disaster-relief drill of 680 unarmed personnel from seven NATO members and 10 partner countries including Serbia. "It is in the interest of Montenegro, in the interest of NATO, and also in the interest of the region, to be part of NATO and promote Euro-Atlantic values in the Balkans, and these values benefit each and every one of us," Montenegro's deputy Prime Minister Dusko Markovic , said about the exercise. Across the border, in Serbia, Russia flew in its paratroopers along with allied Belarus for an exercise called "Slavic Brotherhood", which according the Serbian defence ministry focuses on "fighting terrorism". 
The drills are set to last until November 9 and will include 212 Russian, 450 Serbian and 56 Belarusian troops. Three Russian transport planes have already landed in Belgrade on Wednesday bringing in soldiers and equipment. 
Drills in the two former Yugoslav republics reflect mounting tensions between Russia and the West over a variety of geopolitical issues including conflicts in Syria and Ukraine. 
READ MORE: RUSSIA IS MOVING NUKES WEST IN RESPONSE TO CONTINUING NATO AGGRESSION 
In Serbia, NATO is hugely unpopular after its 1999 bombing ousted Belgrade's armed forces out of its former southern province of Kosovo. 
But as part of its integrations with the West, Serbia last year signed the Individual Partnership Action Plan (IPAP), the highest level of cooperation between NATO and a country not aspiring to join. 
An EU candidate, Serbia insists that it is militarily neutral, but maintains close ties with Russia, its Orthodox Christian and Slavic superpower ally, the biggest gas and oil source and an obstacle to Kosovo's membership in the United Nations. 
Last year Montenegro accepted an invitation to join NATO, a move that soured relations withRussia. Ahead of October's parliamentary vote Montenegro's outgoing Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic accused Moscow of meddling in country's elections and of financing the opposition. A fifth of the votes in the poll went to an anti-NATO, pro-Serbia bloc. Article by Doc Burkhart , Vice-President, General Manager and co-host of TRUNEWS with Rick Wiles Got a news tip? 279.input:
time: null 
 author: Middle East Eye 
 source: mintpressnews.com 
 text: Videos France<U+2019>s Far-Right National Front Seeks Funding From United Arab Emirates With French banks reluctant to lend to the National Front, the party says it could resort to foreign funding from as far away as the UAE. | October 29, 2016 Be Sociable, Share! An electoral board showing France<U+2019>s far-right National Front president Marine Le Pen and reading: 100% National Front. 0% migrants is pictured during a demonstration in Forges-les-Bains, south of Paris, France, Saturday, Oct. 8, 2016. 
France<U+2019>s National Front is known to have diverse funding streams, but an investigation published this week unveiled a new potential funder: the United Arab Emirates. 
It is certainly an odd source of funding for a party whose leader, Marine Le Pen, has been taken to court for anti-Muslim hate speech. 
Le Pen<U+2019>s Russian networks are already well known: in 2014, the National Front received a loan of <U+20AC>11mn ($12mn) from the First Czech Russian Bank. 
This fact was admitted by the party<U+2019>s treasurer, Wallerand de Saint-Just, who said: <U+201C>The party makes requests to foreign banks, why not Russian banks?<U+201D> 
The latest controversy was sparked by a book by famed French investigative journalists Christian Chesnot and Georges Malbrunot. In 2004, the journalistic duo were even held hostage at one point by Islamic militants in Iraq. 
Titled Nos tr<U+00E8>s chers <U+00E9>mirs (Our dear emirs), their latest book exposes the murky relationship between a number of French politicians and the countries of the Arabian Gulf. 
In the wake of the controversy caused by the book<U+2019>s publication, the news website Mediapart has raised the question of possible funding of Marine Le Pen<U+2019>s presidential campaign by the UAE. 
A source familiar with the far-right French party told Middle East Eye: <U+201C>It is true that in 2014 Marine Le Pen met an Emirati emissary in her residence in Montrebout, in the Hauts-de-Seine region, who offered to help her. 
<U+201C>That being said, the FN [National Front] has always been clear on this point: it has two enemies, Qatar and Saudi Arabia, which it regards as sponsors of wahhabism, but in her eyes the Emiratis are an ally in the fight against radicalisation.<U+201D> 
Wahhabism is an ultra-orthodox strand of Sunni Islam practised in Saudi Arabia and the Gulf, and it has become an increasingly popular theme to explain the chaos gripping the Middle East. 
<U+201C>France must break its relations with Qatar and Saudi Arabia, which helped, assisted, and funded Islamic fundamentalists worldwide,<U+201D> Le Pen said in September 2014 on France 24. 
<U+201C>We must rely on those Muslim countries which fight fundamentalism,<U+201D> she added, naming the UAE and Egypt as examples of such countries and calling for <U+201C>a wide coalition<U+201D> against Islamic extremism. 
In 2014, pro-Le Pen French MEP Jean-Luc Schaffhauser told Mediapart that he had negotiated a loan at a rate of 2.8 percent with the National Bank of Abu Dhabi, but that it in the event it did not materialize. 
The following year in May, Le Pen travelled to Cairo to meet with the Grand Imam of al-Azhar Mosque <U+2013> a trip allegedly funded by the UAE, according to Christian Chesnot and Georges Malbrunot. 
The allegation was denied earlier this week by National Front MEP and Secretary General Nicolas Bay, who told France 2 television: <U+201C>That is incorrect.<U+201D> 
<U+201C>For now, about 50 percent of the campaign should be funded by Cotelec, the FN<U+2019>s funding organisation that is chaired by Jean-Marie Le Pen,<U+201D> the source close to the party told MEE. 
These loans granted to the party by its members will be refunded once the state has itself reimbursed the campaign. This rule applies to all parties that win more than 5 percent of the vote in the first round of the elections. 
<U+201C>The needs for the first round are estimated at around <U+20AC>12mn, and <U+20AC>21mn for the second round. For the first round, they still lack <U+20AC>6-7 million, but they are aware of the fact that appealing to the Gulf countries harm them in terms of image,<U+201D> the source added. 
<U+201C>So at first, the goal is to look for loans in European countries. If this is not enough, they will turn to the Russians, and thirdly, to the UAE. We can say that this is an option, but a third choice option.<U+201D> 
The National Front has indicated that around 40 banks have refused to lend it money. Yet polls assure that Le Pen will win more than the 5 percent of votes needed to be reimbursed by the state. 
<U+201C>If we have to borrow abroad, we will borrow abroad,<U+201D> Wallerand de Saint-Just, the party<U+2019>s treasurer, told France 3. <U+201C>There are no exceptions to this, either in Russia, Argentina, or in the United States<U+2026> and why not in the Middle East?<U+201D>

It<U+2019>s time to Make America Great Again.

 text: By Madeline Conway 11/04/16 05:57 PM EDT Two senior House Democrats are asking the Justice Department's inspector general to investigate whether the FBI is leaking information that could benefit Donald Trump. Rep. Elijah E. Cummings and Rep. John Conyers, Jr., ranking members on the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform and House Judiciary Committee, respectively, cited Trump campaign surrogate Rudy Giuliani<U+2019>s suggestion on Fox News on Friday that he <U+201C>heard about<U+201D> a new FBI review of materials in the Hillary Clinton email investigation from <U+201C>former FBI agents<U+201D> and expected such an announcement to come earlier. Story Continued Below FBI Director James Comey offered few details about the agency's latest review of emails that might be relevant to Clinton investigation after he sent a brief letter to lawmakers notifying them of the new probe. News outlets have relied on unnamed department sources in their follow-up reporting following the bombshell revelation last Friday. <U+201C>It is absolutely unacceptable for the FBI to leak unsubstantiated<U+2014>and in some cases false<U+2014>information about one presidential candidate to benefit the other candidate,<U+201D> Cummings and Conyers wrote to Inspector General Michael Horowitz on Friday. <U+201C>Leaking this information to former FBI officials as a conduit to the Trump campaign is equally intolerable.<U+201D> When asked about the letter during an TV appearance Friday evening, Giuliani claimed he knew nothing about Comey<U+2019>s missive to Congress before it was released. Instead the former Mayor claimed he was referencing an upcoming Trump campaign advertising blitz along with other newspaper reports. "That's not correct,<U+201D> Giuliani told CNN<U+2019>s Wolf Blitzer. <U+201C>I've had no conversations with anyone inside the FBI. I was referring to the consternation in the FBI which The New York Times has reported on and The Wall Street journal has reported on.<U+201D> The letter also cited a report by Fox News<U+2019> Bret Baier about an FBI review of the Clinton Foundation that the anchor later retracted. <U+201C>These unauthorized and inaccurate leaks from within the FBI, particularly so close to a presidential election, are unprecedented,<U+201D> Cummings and Conyers concluded. <U+201C>For these reasons, we are calling on your office to conduct a thorough investigation to identify the sources of these and other leaks from the FBI and to recommend appropriate action.<U+201D> By Michael Grunwald By Bill Scher By Thomas Wright By Joshua Zeitz

282.input:
time: null 
 author: Ed Ballard 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/gold-prices-rise-on-dimmer-economic-outlook-1477407571 
 text: Gold closed at a three-week high on Tuesday, as investors continued to stock up following a recent pullback. Gold for December delivery settled up 0.8% at $1,273.60 a troy ounce on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, closing at the highest level since October 3. The drop in gold prices over the past few weeks has brought some buyers back into the market, traders said. Gold was also supported by a weaker economic outlook on Tuesday, after the Conference Board said its index of consumer confidence fell to 98.6 in October from 103.5 in September, falling short of economist expectations. <U+201C>You<U+2019>re seeing a flight to safety,<U+201D> said Bob Haberkorn, senior market strategist at RJO Futures. As gold prices have drawn closer to $1,250 an ounce, <U+201C>there<U+2019>s some life that steps in<U+201D> to the market, he said. Earlier this month, a run of strong U.S. economic data strengthened the case for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates this year . The prospect of higher rates has sapped the appeal of commodities that don<U+2019>t pay interest and pushed gold below $1,300 an ounce. Nitesh Shah, commodities strategist at ETF Securities, said demand had remained resilient since the selloff. He said some investors were speculating that the market had fallen too far in anticipation of higher rates and an actual increase might be followed by a rebound. He added that the impending U.S. presidential election was also likely providing some support for the commodity, which is seen as a haven, as investors seek to insure portfolios against a victory for Republican nominee Donald Trump, a result that could rattle financial markets. <U+201C>As that date [Nov. 8] approaches, people are making sure they<U+2019>ve got these hedges in their portfolio, just in case,<U+201D> Mr. Shah said. Analysts at UBS said they would be monitoring flows in and out of exchange-traded funds that purchase gold, after Friday saw a large net outflow of 518,000 ounces. That reduction -- the biggest one-day decline since July 2013<U+2014>marked a change from the recent pattern of resilient inflows into ETFs. With the London gold price little changed since its close Friday, UBS noted that the market <U+201C>seems to have taken [Friday<U+2019>s] selling quite well for now.<U+201D> But there is a risk that ETF buyers who entered the market at higher levels could get <U+201C>spooked<U+201D> and start selling, UBS said. <U+201C>ETF selling presents risks to the market -- the key question right now is whether the chunky selling on Friday was a one-off or if outflows would continue in the days ahead,<U+201D> UBS said. Write to Stephanie Yang at stephanie.yang@wsj.com and Ed Ballard at ed.ballard@wsj.com

time: null 
 author: Alex Ansary 
 source: amtvmedia.com 
 text: New bionic eye implant connects directly to brain 11/03/2016 
RUSSIA TODAY Scientists may have made a significant breakthrough in restoring human sight, as a woman who had been blind for seven years has regained the ability to see shapes and colours with a bionic eye implant. 
The 30-year-old woman had a wireless visual stimulator chip inserted into her brain by University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) surgeons in the first human test of the product. As a result, she could see colored flashes, lines, and spots when signals were sent to her brain from a computer. 
The woman, who wished to remain anonymous, suffered no significant adverse side effects in the process, according to a statement. 
The device, which was developed as part of the Orion 1 programme by Second Sight, uses technology to restore sight by bypassing the optic nerve to stimulate the brain<U+2019>s visual cortex, according to chairman Robert Greenberg. 
It is designed for those who cannot benefit from the Argus II retinal system that was unveiled at Manchester Royal Eye Hospital last year, but has limited application, as it depends on the patient having some retinal cells. 
This new system goes one step further by sending signals directly to the brain. It has the potential to restore sight to those who have gone completely blind for virtually any reason, including glaucoma, cancer, diabetic retinopathy, or trauma, according to the manufacturer. 
The next step is to connect the implant to a camera on a pair of glasses, and the company plans to seek FDA approval in 2017 to get the go ahead to conduct these trials. 
UCLA neurosurgeon Nader Pouratian, who implanted the stimulator, said the results of the surgery are promising. 
<U+201C>Based on these results, stimulation of the visual cortex has the potential to restore useful vision to the blind, which is important for independence and improving quality of life,<U+201D> he said.

 text: By Nolan D. McCaskill 10/10/16 06:06 PM EDT Updated 10/10/16 06:05 PM EDT Donald Trump emerged from Sunday night<U+2019>s presidential debate, ready to sling more mud. Trump, speaking before a rally in Pennsylvania on Monday afternoon, said he's been ganged up on ever since Friday's release of a 2005 tape that captured the billionaire speaking in incredibly crude terms about women. Story Continued Below <U+201C>I was getting beaten up for 72 hours on all the networks for inappropriate words 12 years ago <U+2014> locker room talk, whatever you wanna call it,<U+201D> Trump said, referring to the wall-to-wall coverage of comments that described his ability to get away with sexual assault. <U+201C>But, I said to myself, wait a minute <U+2014> and I just saw very inappropriate words <U+2014> but Bill Clinton sexually assaulted innocent women, and Hillary Clinton attacked those women viciously. One of them said more viciously than he attacked them.<U+201D> Trump warned against the release of more damaging tapes of his past comments, threatening to continue attacking the Clintons over former President Bill Clinton<U+2019>s alleged infidelities and Hillary Clinton<U+2019>s response to those women<U+2019>s accusations if more such tapes emerge. Though Clinton<U+2019>s campaign has denied any involvement in leaking the <U+201C>Access Hollywood<U+201D> clip that has dogged Trump<U+2019>s campaign all weekend and prompted an exodus of support from prominent Republicans, Trump said more such releases will come at a risk for the Clintons <U+2014> he cast Bill Clinton as a predator Monday and Hillary Clinton as a <U+201C>total hypocrite<U+201D> who enabled him to hurt more women. <U+201C>If they wanna release more tapes saying inappropriate things, we<U+2019>ll continue to talk about Bill and Hillary Clinton doing inappropriate things,<U+201D> Trump said. <U+201C>There are so many of them, folks.<U+201D> Trump aggressively went after Hillary Clinton at his rally, reviving a number of attack lines he used in Sunday<U+2019>s debate all the while ignoring the news that rippled through Washington: House Speaker Paul Ryan dumped Trump earlier Monday (though he hasn<U+2019>t officially rescinded his endorsement), telling Republicans in his chamber on a conference call that he will no longer defend Trump and that they should do whatever<U+2019>s necessary to maintain their majority. By Nolan D. McCaskill Clinton emerged from Trump's weekend of wreckage with a double-digit lead over the billionaire nationally, according to an NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll released Monday. His 11-point deficit threatens to be a drag on congressional Republicans<U+2019> reelection efforts. Trump has repeatedly attacked Bill Clinton since the revelation of extremely lewd comments the real estate mogul made about women were exposed on Friday. In a brief written statement, Trump dismissed his remarks about trying to sleep with a married woman and groping women<U+2019>s genitals and forcibly kissing them with impunity because he<U+2019>s famous as <U+201C>locker room banter.<U+201D> He accused Bill Clinton of having said <U+201C>far worse<U+201D> to him in private conversations while golfing. But he didn<U+2019>t leave it at that, and he didn<U+2019>t stop there. He attacked the Clintons again in a video statement released shortly after midnight Saturday and once again Sunday evening at the St. Louis debate, which the GOP nominee preceded with a surprise panel on Facebook Live featuring women who have accused the Clintons of wrongdoing. Those women <U+2014> Juanita Broaddrick, Paula Jones, Kathleen Willey and Kathy Shelton <U+2014> also attended the debate. Trump<U+2019>s campaign had even devised a covert plan to have the four women join the Trump family<U+2019>s box and cause a scene on national television by entering the debate hall with the 42nd president. But the plan that was thwarted by a co-chair of the Commission on Presidential Debates, which threatened to have security remove the women from the family-only elevated box. <U+201C>You probably saw yesterday: We brought four wonderful women to St. Louis. And honestly, it was both very beautiful and very sad,<U+201D> Trump said Monday. <U+201C>Really, they had been trying to get their feelings out for so long and the media wouldn<U+2019>t take it.<U+201D> That is, until they appeared with Trump. <U+201C>So they were able to get what they wanted to get out,<U+201D> Trump said, going on to quote Broaddrick<U+2019>s accusations about Bill Clinton<U+2019>s alleged rape and Hillary Clinton<U+2019>s alleged threat. <U+201C>She<U+2019>s been struggling to get the media to pay attention to her for many, many years. So last night I decided we would expose the hypocrisy of the Clintons and the media to the entire world.<U+201D> By Toby Eckert Trump re-upped his claim that Hillary Clinton has <U+201C>hatred in her heart.<U+201D> He restated that Bill Clinton is <U+201C>the worst abuser of women ever to sit in the Oval Office<U+201D> and blamed Hillary Clinton for <U+201C>systematically<U+201D> attacking and discrediting <U+201C>the victims of Bill Clinton<U+2019>s sexual harassment and assault.<U+201D> <U+201C>These things aren<U+2019>t written by the media, but they<U+2019>re true,<U+201D> said Trump, who rattled off about a half-dozen of Bill Clinton<U+2019>s accusers but cautioned that <U+201C>many, many more<U+201D> exist (the Clintons have denied such allegations). <U+201C>For decades, Hillary Clinton has been deeply familiar with her husband<U+2019>s predatory behavior, and instead of trying to stop it, she made it possible for him to take advantage of even more women. She put even more women in harm<U+2019>s way and then she goes out and says, <U+2018>I love women, I<U+2019>m gonna help women, I<U+2019>m gonna help them.<U+2019> She<U+2019>s a total hypocrite.<U+201D> Trump slammed the alleged <U+201C>hypocrisy of the media and our politicians.<U+201D> <U+201C>They condemned my words, but they ignore and defend the reprehens<U+2014> and this is the way it is <U+2014> the reprehensible actions of Hillary and Bill Clinton that have destroyed and hurt so many lives.<U+201D> He also blasted Hillary Clinton for defending a man who allegedly raped then-12-year-old Kathy Shelton. <U+201C>As the lawyer for the rapist, Hillary Clinton said the little girl was emotionally unstable and had a <U+2014> quote <U+2014> tendency to seek out older men and engage in fantasizing. Hillary ruined that young girl<U+2019>s life,<U+201D> Trump said. <U+201C>Destroyed her life, and years later she was recorded laughing about it on videotape. She was laughing at the girl.<U+201D> While the notion that Clinton was laughing at Shelton has been debunked, Trump added: <U+201C>There<U+2019>s nothing Hillary Clinton won<U+2019>t do or say to obtain power, and it<U+2019>s about time people started to understand that. But the hypocrites in the media don<U+2019>t wanna talk about what Hillary Clinton has done to these victims. They don<U+2019>t wanna talk about what their other political heroes have done to other innocent girls and women.<U+201D> By Thomas Wright By Bill Scher By Joshua Zeitz By Jack Shafer

 author: Sean Adl-Tabatabai 
 source: yournewswire.com 
 text: Sean Adl-Tabatabai in News , US // 0 Comments 
Hillary Clinton has kicked longtime aide Huma Abedin from her campaign plane in Florida, fuelling rumors that Abedin is about to give the FBI information that could lead to an indictment for Hillary. #Hillarysemail Huma Abedin is not on the plane with #HillaryClinton today. She must be freaking out especially since she signed this doc. pic.twitter.com/KOwI5rN1pW 
<U+2014> Trump Street Team FL (@ChatRevolve) October 29, 2016 RELATED CONTENT Treason: Clinton Sold State Secrets To Middle East Via Huma Abedin 
The news comes on the same day that the FBI obtained a warrant to search emails on Anthony Weiner<U+2019>s laptop. 
Law enforcement sources say that the emails were sent and received through Huma Abedin<U+2019>s laptop <U+2013> the same device used to send thousands of emails to Clinton. 
Speaking at a campaign rally in Golden, Colo. yesterday, Donald Trump questioned whether Hillary would fire Huma, given the news that she was so heavily implicated in the email scandal. 
<U+201C> Huma<U+2019>s been a problem <U+2026> I wonder if Huma is going to stay there and I hope they haven<U+2019>t given Huma immunity because she knows the real story <U+2014> she knows what<U+2019>s going on, <U+201D> Trump said. 
<U+201C> How can you have all of this incredible confidential, secret information and have your top person married to this guy? <U+201D> Trump asked. <U+201C> Everyone said one thing has nothing to do with another <U+2014> well, it turns out it does .<U+201D> 
Nbcnews.com reports: 
Agents will now compare the latest batch of messages with those that have already been investigated to determine whether any classified information was sent from Clinton<U+2019>s server. 
Clinton called the move an <U+201C>unprecedented<U+201D> departure from FBI policy, and on Sunday, Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid scolded Comey for potentially breaking the law. 
<U+201C>Your actions in recent months have demonstrated a disturbing double standard for the treatment of sensitive information, with what appears to be clear intent to aid one political party over another,<U+201D> the letter says. <U+201C>I am writing to inform you that my office has determined that these actions may violate the Hatch Act.<U+201D> 
The act bars government officials from using their authority to influence elections. 
<U+2014> Jeff Pegues (@jeffpeguescbs) October 30, 2016 Image surfaces of Huma Abedin crying on plane as Clinton Campaign finds out the FBI has re-opened the email investigation. #HillarysEmails pic.twitter.com/2yIUgiYOsV

287.input:
time: null 
 author: noauthor 
 source: https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/09/opinion/sunday/is-idealism-missing-from-the-presidential-campaign.html?_r=0 
 text: Readers discuss David Brooks<U+2019>s lament that <U+201C>there is no uplift<U+201D> in the presidential race. To the Editor: Re <U+201C> The Death of Idealism <U+201D> (column, Sept. 30): David Brooks writes that <U+201C>this boomer-versus-boomer campaign has decimated idealism.<U+201D> Hillary Clinton, as she herself has admitted, is not a natural politician. Yes, in her speeches <U+201C>the poetic, aspirational quality is entirely absent<U+201D> and she <U+201C>fails to make an emotional connection.<U+201D> But no, that does not mean that she has lost her idealism. Mrs. Clinton became a fiery social activist in college, where she led protests to increase African-American admissions to Wellesley. As first lady she worked for universal health care; when her idealism hit Washington reality she persisted, helping to gain health care coverage for children. As a senator from New York she worked across the aisle, compromising and gaining the respect of her Republican colleagues. After being defeated in the 2008 Democratic primaries, she worked as secretary of state to extend American ideals around the world. For myself, an older baby boomer, I would like to think that, while I have scaled back my immediate goals as I have become more pragmatic and realistic, I have retained the idealism and humanity that determine my long-term goals. And I would like to think that of Hillary Clinton. ALLAN D. GREENBERG Scarsdale, N.Y. To the Editor: David Brooks has succumbed to the cynicism and distrust that he decries in his dismissal of the two leading presidential candidates. He apparently listens to Hillary Clinton<U+2019>s campaign with selective inattentiveness to her appeals to idealistic principles and the common good <U+2014> <U+201C>the higher angels of our nature.<U+201D> And how is it that her extensive, informed familiarity with governmental policy amounts to <U+201C>an arid hodgepodge<U+201D> of uninspiring details, offered merely out of political self-interest? Perhaps Mr. Brooks should turn to the question of why informational substance receives such short shrift in American politics. The visionary <U+201C>uplift<U+201D> of shining cities on hills comes cheap. More deserving of public respect is a foundation of historically steeped, nuts-and-bolts competence in governance on which to construct such a city. A firm insistence by the media that politicians display in-depth knowledge, fact-based realism and astute judgment <U+2014> while eschewing empty sloganism and easy campaign promises <U+2014> would be a real show of idealism. To comment negatively on both contestants, albeit more scathingly on Donald Trump, is to suggest equivalent undesirability <U+2014> a journalistic disservice given the extreme hazard embodied in the Republican nominee. A. ROSS HILL Brooklyn To the Editor: David Brooks<U+2019>s lament about Hillary Clinton<U+2019>s loss of her 1960s idealism all too easily fits into his conservative worldview. I offered the invocation at the Wellesley graduation at which she gave her famous speech in 1969. I knew her well in those days. Even then her <U+2019>60s idealism was well tempered by a Niebuhrian realism. She has not changed fundamentally since then. On the one hand, in those days she was a devout, churchgoing Methodist who believed that we should <U+201C>do all the good you can, in all the ways you can, in all the places you can, for all the people you can.<U+201D> On the other hand, she is firmly convinced, as she was at Wellesley, that politics is the art of the possible. At Wellesley, she was by no means some head-in-the clouds student radical. She was both idealistic and realistic, and so she remains today, which was and is an ethical complexity that Mr. Brooks apparently does not take with full seriousness. (Rev.) H. PAUL SANTMIRE Watertown, Mass. To the Editor: While I agree with David Brooks<U+2019>s assessment of Donald Trump<U+2019>s dismal character, I find it unfortunate that he falls into the typical, widely identified trap of setting up a moral equivalence between Mr. Trump and Hillary Clinton: <U+201C>There is an entire absence, in both campaigns, of any effort to appeal to the higher angels of our nature.<U+201D> Really? Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s calling for paid sick leave, better health care for children, debt-free college opportunities, and working together as a diverse society is equivalent to Mr. Trump<U+2019>s race-baiting, calls for stop-and-frisk and law and order, and vilification of immigrants? Mr. Brooks clearly fails to hear what Mrs. Clinton is actually saying. He should have found a way to frame his arguments without resorting to the tired and dangerously inaccurate equalization of the two candidates<U+2019> shortcomings. JEFFREY SCHIFF Brooklyn To the Editor: I invite David Brooks to picture Hillary Clinton in the Oval Office vetoing bill after bill passed by a Republican-controlled Congress (which is what the polls are projecting) <U+2014> legislation abolishing the Environmental Protection Agency and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, gutting Medicare and Social Security, abolishing voter rights, abolishing financial controls on Wall Street, sweeping away women<U+2019>s and gender rights, diluting freedom of choice for women <U+2026> the list is endless. If Republicans control the presidency and Congress, 70 years of progress will hang from the thin thread of the filibuster rule, which is not constitutionally protected. Does anyone care if her veto is inspirational? Does anyone care if she smiles? It<U+2019>s her actions, not her speaking style or demeanor, that count. This is not about quibbles over Mr. Brooks<U+2019>s failure to recognize false equivalencies. Americans need to wake up and consider what they might be on the verge of doing. ROBERT MILLSAP Woodland, Calif. To the Editor: l am sick and tired of naysayers like David Brooks who are not sufficiently inspired, uplifted or moved by Hillary Clinton. She is being held to a totally different standard than that applied to any other candidate <U+2014> in this or any other presidential contest. If she articulates specific policies or proposals, she is a <U+201C>policy wonk.<U+201D> If she has the inner strength to admit mistakes (unlike her opponent), she is untrustworthy. The woman has a wealth of experience, sound judgment, international respect and an incredible work ethic. She has articulated a vision of a more fair, just and inclusive society, and has given the specifics of how to achieve it. David Brooks and his holier-than-thou ilk are not only unfair in their assessment of her, but they also act as if they are unaware of the consequences of this dismissive, condescending portrayal, which is to actively encourage those who will either sit this election out or vote for a third-party candidate. HARRIETT GALVIN New York Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter (@NYTopinion) , and sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter . A version of this letter appears in print on October 9, 2016, on Page SR10 of the New York edition with the headline: An Absence of Idealism?. Today's Paper | Subscribe

time: null

 source: shadowproof.com 
 text: If you want to support the show and receive access to tons of bonus content, subscribe on our Patreon page for as little as $5 a month. Also, don<U+2019>t forget to subscribe, rate, and review the show on iTunes . We can<U+2019>t do this show without your support!!! 
On this episode, we keep the focus on the massive, nationwide #PrisonStrike that began on September 9th and which we covered in our last episode. 
First, we play a clip from On The Media with Azzurra Crispino, our guest from last week. Azzurra is media co-chair for the Incarcerated Workers Organizing Committee (IWOC), a branch of the Industrial Workers of the World (IWW) and an Associate Professor of Philosophy at Austin Community College and Co-Founder of Prison Abolition Prisoner Solidarity , an organization dedicated to supporting prisoners and prison abolition efforts. In the clip, she asks whether mainstream media is complicit in violence within prisons because they only cover prison resistance when it turns violent, ignoring non-violent resistance like the current strike. Kumars and Roqayah discuss this point and brainstorm ways to get around this sad reality.
Next, Kumars interviews <U+201C>D<U+201D>, the incarcerated strike leader from South Carolina who we spoke to in our last episode. Kumars gets an update from D about conditions on the ground where he is, and the repression he and others have faced as they keep their strike alive. Importantly, D discusses the lasting changes in terms of prisoner consciousness and solidarity he already sees, and discusses next steps for this movement which will not end until prisons as we currently know them cease to exist.

If you want to learn more or get involved:

time: null 
 author: Grant Stern 
 source: occupydemocrats.com 
 text: Comments 
Democratic Rep. Elijah Cummings (D-MD) was the ranking minority member on the House Benghazi committee, so he knows firsthand how Republican witch-hunts work from up close personal experience. 
On CNN<U+2019>s New Day this morning, he revealed the real motivation behind the FBI Director<U+2019>s stunningly improper memo to Congress last week. 
<U+201C>I don<U+2019>t think the American people have a clue how hard the Republicans <U+2013> particularly on my committee <U+2013> have been on the FBI. This is a man <U+2013> Director Comey <U+2013> who they loved. They said he was the greatest thing in the world, very honorable.<U+201D> 
<U+201C>When he came out with the decision in July to not prosecute Mrs. Clinton, they suddenly turned against him. He knows that if he makes any misstep, the Republicans are going to be all over him and they<U+2019>re going to try and bring harm to him. The thing that he did say in our hearing, and it stuck with me, is that <U+2018>there should not be a double standard to the disadvantage of Mrs. Clinton.'<U+201D> 
That<U+2019>s right, it is heavily implied that the FBI Director was so intimidated by Congressional Republicans and their innuendo machines that he caved in and fed them the kind of vaguely worded red meat memo the Trump campaign desperately needed to keep their failing campaign on life support. 
Even Comey himself admitted that his memo was going to be widely misinterpreted , which is probably why CNN<U+2019>s host began her interview with Congressman Cummings by saying, <U+201C>Trump is lying about the email probe.<U+201D> 
It hasn<U+2019>t taken long for the roof to cave in on Comey<U+2019>s career anyway, as his obvious meddling in the election has drawn bipartisan complaints about illegal electioneering by the FBI Director, his former boss to condemn his actions and for the Senate minority leader Harry Reid to demand answers from the FBI about the Republican candidate<U+2019>s love affair with Russian dictator Vladimir Putin. Reid<U+2019>s point was not lost on the Congressman from Maryland who told CNN: 
<U+201C>There has been a lot of information out there about Mr. Trump, Mr. Manafort and the Russian government and alleged attempts to take over our election. Members of Congress have asked for months, for the FBI to provide us with information if Mr. Trump, Mr. Manafort and any elements of the Russian government have any coordination or connection with each other.<U+201D> 
<U+201C>They have not given us one syllable. So the question here is: Do we have a double standard here?<U+201D> 
Of course there<U+2019>s a double standard! 
The FBI has a responsibility to keep certain things secret, and when it comes to partisan elections that responsibility is key to the ability of our electoral democracy<U+2019>s basic functioning. Newsweek<U+2019>s Kurt Eichenwald pointed out cogently that Republican George W. Bush was investigated by the FBI in 1996, prior to running for President. Yet, the Clinton White House didn<U+2019>t grab his FBI file and air all of the dirty laundry claiming a very partisan need for transparency during an election. Otherwise, the FBI could decide to influence every election in America, and over time the FBI would pick the elected officials to their liking. 
Nothing can un-ring the bell that FBI Director Comey struck by letting loose his vague memo, but everyone can understand there is a sexist, partisan and blatant double standard at play by Republicans celebrating a vague memo, which only happened because an official sworn to be non-partisan decided he valued his political career more than the integrity of our electoral system

292.input:
time: null 
 author: Ryan Dube Damian Paletta 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/ecuador-restricts-wikileaks-founder-julian-assanges-communications-1476834096 
 text: Ecuador said Tuesday that it restricted Julian Assange <U+2019>s internet access at its embassy in London in light of concerns that the WikiLeaks founder, who has lived there since he was granted political asylum in 2012, was meddling in the U.S. presidential election. The acknowledgment resolves the mystery of why Mr. Assange<U+2019>s internet link was severed on Saturday. WikiLeaks has published thousands of emails detailing the internal deliberations of Hillary Clinton <U+2019>s presidential campaign. WikiLeaks has continued operations despite the interruption. While Ecuadorean President Rafael Correa told news channel Russia Today in late September that he preferred Mrs. Clinton over Republican candidate Donald Trump as the next president of the U.S., Ecuador<U+2019>s Foreign Relations Ministry said it doesn<U+2019>t favor any candidate in the election. The decision to cut Mr. Assange<U+2019>s access sought to prevent interference in the <U+201C>internal affairs of other states,<U+201D> the ministry said. WikiLeaks said Tuesday on Twitter that U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry had asked Ecuadorean officials to stop Mr. Assange from publishing more of the Clinton emails. The State Department has denied pressuring Ecuador, and the Ecuadorean government said its foreign policy decisions aren<U+2019>t influenced by pressure from other states. Mr. Assange<U+2019>s predicament is unique because his origins and activities cut across at least six countries. He was born in Australia, lives now at Ecuador<U+2019>s U.K. embassy, is publishing documents allegedly stolen by Russia that affect the U.S. election, and is being pursued by law enforcement in Sweden over sexual-assault allegations that Mr. Assange denies. Ecuador has signaled that it would continue to grant Mr. Assange asylum, but the Foreign Relations Ministry statement suggests he would be treated differently. <U+201C>Ecuador has exercised its sovereign right to temporarily restrict access to some of its private communications network within its Embassy in the United Kingdom,<U+201D> the ministry said. <U+201C>This temporary restriction does not prevent the WikiLeaks organization from carrying out its journalistic activities.<U+201D> WikiLeaks gained international attention in 2006 when it published cables that detailed the inner workings of U.S. foreign policy. It regained global attention in recent months with the publication of emails stolen from top Democratic Party officials. In July, days before the Democratic National Convention, it published more than 19,000 emails believed stolen from the Democratic Party, some sufficiently embarrassing to prompt the resignation of top party officials. Earlier this month, WikiLeaks published a new batch of emails, several thousand a day, revealing messages apparently sent and received by top Clinton aide John Podesta. The organization is expected to continue releasing thousands of additional Podesta emails in the days leading up to the election. The Clinton campaign has accused Russia of stealing the emails and then having WikiLeaks post them, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation is probing the case. The Clinton campaign has declined to confirm whether the emails are authentic. U.S. intelligence agencies have said the publication of these emails by WikiLeaks represented a key part of a well-orchestrated campaign by top Russian officials to interfere in the U.S. election.

293.input:
time: null 
 author: James Taranto 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-tweets-the-darnedest-things-1480446638 
 text: (Note: We<U+2019>re off the rest of the week, to return Monday.) Those who expected Donald Trump to quit with the zany tweets in the interest of becoming more <U+201C>presidential<U+201D> have been disappointed (or relieved, depending on taste). He<U+2019>s perhaps slowed his pace a bit, but the hits keep on coming. Here<U+2019>s his latest , this morning: <U+201C>Nobody should be allowed to burn the American flag<U+2014>if they do, there must be consequences<U+2014>perhaps loss of citizenship or year in jail!<U+201D> Follow James on Twitter We<U+2019>re going to take that literally and rebut it, but only because we enjoy writing about constitutional law. The U.S. Supreme Court held in Texas v. Johnson (1989), and reaffirmed in U.S. v. Eichman (1990) that burning the American flag is a form of symbolic speech, protected by the First Amendment. True, both rulings were 5-4, and the entire court has turned over since then except Justice Anthony Kennedy (who was in the majority). But we doubt very much the justices would overturn these precedents. Not only is the current court generally friendlier to free-speech claims than the 1989-90 court was, but a generation has gone by without any evident diminution of respect for the flag. As Justice William Brennan observed in Johnson: Trump critics have taken particular offense at his suggestion that flag-burners be stripped of U.S. citizenship. But the suggestion is frivolous. No one can be stripped of U.S. citizenship, possibly excepting someone whose naturalization rested on fraud. ( Ari Fleischer , White House press secretary to George W. Bush, offers a mischievous compromise proposal: <U+201C>I disagree because it<U+2019>s a free speech right for Americans, but any non-citizen who burns the flag should not be allowed to become a citizen.<U+201D>) Two days ago, amid the futile recall effort of Green Jill Stein, Trump tweeted : <U+201C>In addition to winning the Electoral College in a landslide, I won the popular vote if you deduct the millions of people who voted illegally.<U+201D> We would fault him for the phrase <U+201C>won the popular vote,<U+201D> because the aggregate national popular vote is a meaningless statistic. To say he (or Hillary Clinton) <U+201C>won<U+201D> it is as meaningful as saying the Denver Broncos <U+201C>won the total yardage<U+201D> on Sunday night, when they were losing to the Kansas City Chiefs 30-27 in overtime. But what stirred most of the interest was the factual underpinning of his tweet<U+2014>or, more likely, the lack thereof. It was widely assumed that Trump<U+2019>s <U+201C>three million<U+201D> came from Alex Jones of the right-wing conspiracy site Infowars.com, who claimed two weeks ago that <U+201C>three million votes in the U.S. presidential election were cast by illegal aliens.<U+201D> One reason to regard that assertion as dubious is that it specifically mentions illegal aliens. All aliens, regardless of legal status, are prohibited from voting in federal elections. We wondered if there was any reliable estimate of the number of aliens (or ineligible citizens) who voted. The answer appears to be no. PolitiFact did a <U+201C>fact check<U+201D> on Jones<U+2019>s assertion and rated it <U+201C>false,<U+201D> even though checker Allison Graves acknowledged <U+201C>we don<U+2019>t know for absolute certain.<U+201D> Graves makes a reasonable case that the three million figure is so high as to be implausible on its face. But she cites what looks like agenda-driven <U+201C>research<U+201D> producing numbers that seem implausibly low: A 2014 paper by a trio of political scientists from Virginia<U+2019>s Old Dominion and George Mason universities noted that <U+201C>very little reliable data exists concerning the frequency with which non-citizen immigrants participate in United States election.<U+201D> Their estimate of alien votes in 2008: <U+201C>from just over 38,000 at the very minimum to nearly 2.8 million at the maximum.<U+201D> To say the least, that is not very precise. Anyhow, who cares? Trump won the election, after all, so why quibble over the <U+201C>popular vote<U+201D>? His tweet prompted the closest thing we<U+2019>ve ever seen to a witty headline on the young-adult website Vox : <U+201C>Donald Trump Is Now Questioning the Legitimacy of the Election He Won.<U+201D> Top Voxen Ezra Klein observes in the piece: <U+201C>Back in March, I wrote a piece about how Trump was too gullible<U+2014>too fond of bad information and sycophants<U+2014>to be president. I think that piece holds up.<U+201D> Well, maybe<U+2014>except the part about being president! Of course Trump isn<U+2019>t actually questioning the legitimacy of the election, just quibbling over a meaningless stat. But why does he persist with the crazy tweets? Maybe he can<U+2019>t help himself, but even that doesn<U+2019>t preclude the possibility that there<U+2019>s method to the madness. For one thing, the outrage it draws provides opportunities to highlight Trump<U+2019>s critics<U+2019> hypocrisy. Example: After the flag-burning tweet provoked vigorous defenses of the First Amendment, many people pointed out that then-Sen. Clinton was a lead sponsor of the Flag Protection Act of 2005 . And of course her lukewarm endorsement of the Stein recount effort occasioned many reminders of how aghast Mrs. Clinton was when Trump refused to commit to accept the outcome of the election she was supposed to win. For another, it confuses antagonistic journalists. It draws attention away from consequential stories that might be awkward or damaging to Trump, such as the potential conflicts of interest posed by his businesses. Last night we noted this Twitter exchange between Harry Siegel and Josh Greenman, respectively a columnist and the opinion editor of New York<U+2019>s Daily News: We interjected with a link to a Columbia Journalism Review piece titled <U+201C>The Goal Is Not to Fear Trump, but for Trump to Fear You.<U+201D> The <U+201C>you<U+201D> is journalists, and something tells us that goal is far from realization. By the way, did CJR ever run a piece like that about Barack Obama? From <U+201C> we begin bombing in five minutes <U+201D> to <U+201C> the Cambridge police acted stupidly ,<U+201D> presidents have been bedeviled by <U+201C>gaffes.<U+201D> It<U+2019>s possible Trump has come up with a way of neutralizing the risk<U+2014>by making odd statements so often that they<U+2019>ll eventually stop making news. In the best-case scenario he<U+2019>ll help restore the balance of power in government by making fools of those who hang on the president<U+2019>s every word. And if nothing else, it<U+2019>s entertaining. Charles Murray of the American Enterprise Institute<U+2014>perhaps the most intensely anti-Trump person we encountered all year, which is saying a lot <U+2014>tweeted this morning: <U+201C>An ignoble confession: The next day<U+2019>s news if Hillary had won would have been so depressing. Now, I can<U+2019>t wait. Like watching a cliffhanger.<U+201D> Make That Four Make That 11 The Soft Bigotry of Low Expectations <U+201C>White House: Obama Proud No <U+2018>Major Personal Scandal<U+2019> Occurred in His Administration<U+201D><U+2014>headline, Washington Free Beacon, Nov.<U+00A0>28 Question and Answer<U+2014>I Question and Answer<U+2014>II Everything Seemingly Is Spinning Out of Control <U+201C>Pelosi Gets One Right<U+201D><U+2014>headline, Best of the Web, Nov.<U+00A0>28 Everything Seemingly Is Spinning Under Control <U+201C>Earth Isn<U+2019>t Doomed Yet. The Climate Could Survive Trump Policies.<U+201D><U+2014>headline, New York Times, Nov.<U+00A0>29 I Have a Dream, Sources Say Here<U+2019>s the lead of a <U+201C>climate change<U+201D> story from the New York Times, dateline Shaktoolik, Alaska: So the Times is now reporting<U+2014>in the science section!<U+2014>on people<U+2019>s dreams, as a lead-in to the tautology that floods tend to occur after storms. What was that about <U+201C> fake news <U+201D> again? Follow @jamestaranto on Twitter. Join Fans of Best of the Web Today on Facebook. Subscribe to the Best of the Web email with one click. (Carol Muller helps compile Best of the Web. Thanks to Mike Lavender, Tony Lima, Ethel Fenig, Michael Segal, Michele Schiesser, Debbie Wells, Irene DeBlasio, Ben Johnson, Mordecai Bobrowsky, Mark Finkelstein and Aliza Polkes.  text: By John Vibes 
In the midst of deepening tension between US allies NATO and Russia, NATO is planning the largest military buildup along the Russian border since the cold war. 
NATO called on allied governments this week to contribute whatever troops and equipment they can to the effort. According to Reuters , thousands of troops are expected to arrive in the coming days and weeks. 
It was reported that Italy, France, Denmark and other European states are expected to join the NATO military divisions that will be led by the United States along Russia<U+2019>s border. 
On Wednesday, Britain announced it is sending hundreds of soldiers and hardware to Russia<U+2019>s borders as part of a huge military deployment. 
A total of 800 troops, drones and tanks are moving to Estonia as part of the biggest military build-up of NATO troops on Russia<U+2019>s borders since the Cold War. 
In addition to the forces allocated for his specific operation, NATO has an army of over 40,000 ready to be called up to fight at any time. 
The US military claims that this threatening move is meant to act as a <U+201C>deterrent<U+201D> to the Russian military, but this is obvious a move that will escalate tensions and push towards a possible third world war. 
<U+201C>This is a credible deterrence, not to provoke a conflict but to prevent conflict,<U+201D> NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg said on Tuesday <U+2014> ironically ignoring the fact that it is a de facto provocation. 
Just imagine what would happen if Russian troops amassed along the Mexican border and told the US that this move was to <U+2018>prevent conflict.<U+2019> 
The so-called Iskander-M cruise missiles can hit targets across Poland and the Baltics, although NATO officials declined to say if Russia had moved nuclear warheads to Kaliningrad. 
The United States<U+2019> envoy to NATO, Douglas Lute, told reporters that NATO and the US military may consider Russia a threat if they had nuclear weapons within range of NATO<U+2019>s deployment. This statement is insane considering the fact that the US military is the one that is many miles from home on the border of someone else<U+2019>s lands. 
<U+201C>This deployment, if it becomes permanent if the presence of nuclear weapons were confirmed, would be a change in (Russia<U+2019>s) security posture,<U+201D> Lute said. 
If anyone is a threat, it is NATO and the US government. 
These military tensions are the result of an ongoing proxy war in Syria, in which Western powers are attempting to institute a regime change in the country by funding violent rebel groups. Meanwhile, Russia has interests in keeping their allies in the Syrian government in control, putting the two superpowers at odds. 
Until now, Russia and the US have been fighting through third parties, just as they had during the previous Cold War, and the same type of situation is developing today. 
John Vibes is an author and researcher who organizes a number of large events including the Free Your Mind Conference.
