398.input:
time: null 
 author: Kate King 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/chris-christies-future-shifts-spotlight-to-his-lieutenant-governor-1478735111 
 text: Speculation that New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie could secure a position in President-elect Donald Trump <U+2019>s administration drew attention Wednesday to Lt. Gov. Kim Guadagno, who would fill the state<U+2019>s highest office should Mr. Christie resign for a job in Washington. A spokeswoman for Mr. Trump and aides to Mr. Christie didn<U+2019>t respond to requests for comment. Mr. Christie, a Republican, was selected by Mr. Trump in May to lead the transition to the White House. If Mr. Christie steps down, New Jersey<U+2019>s Constitution stipulates that the lieutenant governor would become governor and serve out the remainder of the current term, state officials said. <U+201C>I am prepared to serve as governor should Governor Christie become part of the new administration,<U+201D> Mrs. Guadagno said in a statement. <U+201C>That<U+2019>s what lieutenant governors do.<U+201D> Mr. Christie is prevented by term limits from running for a third term and is scheduled to leave office in January 2018. The general election for his successor is next November. Former Goldman Sachs executive Phil Murphy is the front-runner for Democratic nomination in the race. Mrs. Guadagno, 57, a Monmouth Beach resident and former federal prosecutor, was elected on Mr. Christie<U+2019>s ticket in 2009. The governor had her oversee the New Jersey Department of State and run economic development initiatives. Mrs. Guadagno has largely operated in the background during her time in Trenton, said Brigid Harrison, who teaches political science and law at Montclair State University. <U+201C>Chris Christie is such a large presence that there wasn<U+2019>t a whole lot of room for the lieutenant governor, given his strong personality,<U+201D> Ms. Harrison said. <U+201C>In my view, her talents were probably underutilized for most of her tenure.<U+201D> Mrs. Guadagno is well-known and respected in the state<U+2019>s business community, said Tom Bracken, president and chief executive of the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce. The lieutenant governor chaired the state<U+2019>s Red Tape Review Commission, which Mr. Bracken credited with eliminating <U+201C>a lot of the regulations that have impeded business growth.<U+201D> <U+201C>She<U+2019>s been great,<U+201D> he said. <U+201C>She<U+2019>s been very attentive to the business community.<U+201D> The lieutenant governor, who told The Wall Street Journal last year that she was <U+201C>thinking about<U+201D> running to succeed Mr. Christie, has low name recognition statewide. But serving as governor would give her greater exposure and greatly improve her chances of winning the Republican nomination and the general election, Ms. Harrison said. <U+201C>If the governor steps down<U+2026>she will be able to forge her own legacy,<U+201D> she said. Mrs. Guadagno is the first person to serve as lieutenant governor in New Jersey. The position was created through a 2005 ballot referendum held after two governors<U+2014>in a span of less than five years<U+2014>left their posts before the end of their terms. Richard Codey was unexpectedly thrust into the state<U+2019>s top office in 2004, when Democratic Gov. Jim McGreevey admitted to an affair and resigned his post. At the time, New Jersey<U+2019>s succession plan called for the state Senate President to assume the governorship. Mr. Codey, then the Senate president, served as both New Jersey<U+2019>s governor and as the state Senate president for 14 months. <U+201C>I was scared, I didn<U+2019>t know what to expect,<U+201D> said Mr. Codey, a Democrat who is now a state senator. <U+201C>I had been [in the Legislature] a long time, but being in the No. 1 seat is totally different.<U+201D> Mr. Codey said Mrs. Guadagno<U+2019>s biggest challenge, should she become governor, will be to forge relationships with state lawmakers to advance her agenda. Mrs. Guadagno, who became the first female sheriff in Monmouth County in 2007, has never served in the state Legislature. <U+201C>It<U+2019>s going to be a learning experience and, at the same time, she<U+2019>s going to have to decide whether or not she<U+2019>s going to run,<U+201D> Mr. Codey said, noting that the filing deadline for the 2017 gubernatorial race is in April. Write to Kate King at Kate.King@wsj.com

401.input:
time: null 
 author: Pete Dolack 
 source: counterpunch.org 
 text: Email 
Class warfare is poised to reach a new milestone as this year<U+2019>s combined total of dividends and stock buybacks by 500 of the world<U+2019>s largest corporations will exceed US$1 trillion. 
So large is that figure that, for the second year in a row, the companies comprising the S&P 500 Index (a list of many of the world<U+2019>s biggest corporations) will pay out more money in dividends and stock buybacks than the total of their profits. Yes, times are indeed good for speculators. Not so good for employees <U+2014> you know, the people who do the actual work <U+2014> whose pay is stagnant or declining so that those at the top can scoop up still more. 
Although dividends, a quarterly payment to holders of stock, are steadily increasing, the increase in stock buybacks has been steeper. The total of these has tripled since 2009 as financiers and industrialists feverishly extract as much wealth as they can. This is part of why the <U+201C>recovery<U+201D> since the 2008 economic collapse has been a recovery only for those at the top. 
In short, a buyback is when a corporation buys its own stock from its shareholders at a premium to the current price. Speculators love buybacks because it means extra profits for them. Corporate executives love them because, with fewer shares outstanding following a buyback program, their company<U+2019>s <U+201C>earnings per share<U+201D> figure will rise for the same net income, making them look good in the eyes of Wall Street. Remaining shareholders love buybacks because the profits will now be shared among fewer shareholders. 
Wall Street and corporate executives both win! Hurrah! Who could by hurt by this? Oh, yes, the employees. They<U+2019>ll have to suffer through pay freezes, work speedups and layoffs because the money shoveled into executive pay and financial industry profits has to come from somewhere. This sort of activity helps buoy stock prices. So does the trillions of dollars the world<U+2019>s central banks have printed to sustain their <U+201C>quantitative easing<U+201D> programs. 
We<U+2019>re not talking loose change here. The U.S. Federal Reserve pumped $4.1 trillion into its three rounds of quantitative easing; the Bank of England spent <U+00A3>375 billion; the European Central Bank has spent about <U+20AC>1.34 trillion; and the Bank of Japan has spent <U+00A5>220 trillion so far. That<U+2019>s a total of US$8 trillion or <U+20AC>7.4 trillion. And the last two programs are ongoing. 
Encouraging investment or inflating bubbles? 
The supposed purpose of quantitative-easing programs is to stimulate the economy by encouraging investment. Under this theory, a reduction in long-term interest rates would encourage working people to buy or refinance homes; encourage businesses to invest because they could borrow cheaply; and push down the value of the currency, thereby boosting exports by making locally made products more competitive. 
In actuality, quantitative-easing programs cause the interest rates on bonds to fall because a central bank buying bonds in bulk significantly increases demand for them, enabling bond sellers to offer lower interest rates. Seeking assets with a better potential payoff, speculators buy stock instead, driving up stock prices and inflating a stock-market bubble. Money not used in speculation ends up parked in bank coffers, boosting bank profits, or is borrowed by businesses to buy back more of their stock, another method of driving up stock prices without making any investments. 
The practical effects of all this is to re-distribute income upward . That is the raison d<U+2019><U+00EA>tre of the financial industry. 
What else could be done with the vast sums of money thrown at the financial industry? In the U.S. alone, home to a steadily crumbling infrastructure, the money needed to eliminate all student debt, fix all schools, rebuild aging water and sewer systems, clean up contaminated industrial sites and repair dams is estimated to be $3.4 trillion <U+2014> in other words, $700 billion less than the Federal Reserve spent on its quantitative-easing program. 
The British think tank Policy Exchange estimates Britain<U+2019>s needs for investment in transportation, communication and water infrastructure to be a minimum of <U+00A3>170 billion, or less than half of what the Bank of England spent on its QE scheme. 
Borrowing to give more to speculators 
To return to the $1 trillion in dividends and buybacks, a research report by Barclays estimates that those payouts by S&P 500 corporations will total about $115 billion more than their combined net income. As a Zero Hedge analysis puts it: 
<U+201C>[C]ompanies will promptly send every single dollar in cash they create back to their shareholders, and then use up an additional $115 billion from cash on the balance sheet, sell equity or issue new debt, to fund the difference.<U+201D> 
Near-zero interest rates, another central bank policy that favors the financial industry, have enabled this accumulation of debt. Debt not for investment, but simply to shovel more money into the pockets of financiers and executives. But debt can<U+2019>t increase forever, and someday, perhaps in the not too distant future, central banks will raise interest rates, making debt much less attractive. The Barclays report calculates that 2015 also saw buybacks and dividends total more than net income; the last time there was consecutive years in which this happened were 2007 and 2008. 
It would of course be too simplistic to interpret this metric as a signal that an economic collapse on the scale of 2008 is imminent, but is perhaps a sign that the latest stock market bubble may be close to bursting. 
Another signal that trouble may be looming is that money is now being shoveled into bonds, a sign that confidence in the stock market is waning. A New York Times report suggests that European and Asian investors (the Times of course is much too genteel to use the word <U+201C>speculator<U+201D>) are pouring so much capital into U.S. bond markets that a bubble is being inflated there as well. These speculators are seeking higher returns from bonds floated by U.S. corporations than they can get at home. The Times reports : 
<U+201C>The surge in flows echoes a wave of investment in the years right before the financial crisis, when mostly European investors snapped up billions of dollars of mortgage-backed securities before the American housing market imploded. 
The current numbers are also arresting. According to [former Treasury Department official Brad W.] Setser<U+2019>s figures, about $750 billion of private money has poured into the United States in the last two years alone.<U+201D> 
Starved for investment 
Setting aside the touch of xenophobia in it, the Times report does at least broach the subject of under-investment. And wealthy investors possessing far more money than can possibly be invested is hardly an unknown phenomenon. As an example, let us examine Wal-Mart, which racked up more than $16 billion in net income for 2015 and seems poised to better that this year. 
The Walton family, heirs to founder Sam Walton, owns about half of Wal-Mart<U+2019>s stock and receive a corresponding share of the billions of dollars in dividends the company pays yearly. It also spends billions more buying back stock annually, an indirect help to the Waltons. This is a company notorious for dodging taxes while paying its employees so little they require government assistance, and is the recipient of vast amounts of government handouts . 
The Waltons make tens of thousands times what their ill-paid employees earn. They certainly don<U+2019>t work tens of thousands harder <U+2014> or even work at all, as the billions roll in just for being born into the right family. Wan-Mart is far from alone, but does provide an exemplary example of class warfare. An estimated $1 trillion a year goes to corporate profits that once went to wages, according to a PBS Newshour report. 
The harder you work, the more the boss, and financiers, make. What sort of system is this?

403.input:
time: null 
 author: GEORGE GURLEY 
 source: https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/17/fashion/nearys-new-york-republican-bar-trump-supporters.html?_r=0 
 text: The wall on the left side of Neary<U+2019> s, a green-canopied Irish restaurant and bar on East 57th Street that will celebrate its 50th anniversary next year, is covered with framed photos of politicians considered liberal: Hillary and Bill Clinton, Ted Kennedy, Chris Dodd, Hugh Carey and Michael Bloomberg. Rudy Giuliani, perhaps surprisingly, is up there, too. On the right wall are George Bush the elder and the younger, Dick Cheney and Ronald Reagan. Though Donald J. Trump he has been a patron, he is not yet on either wall. But since Mr. Trump, the president-elect, announced his candidacy 500-odd days ago, the bar has served as a refuge, a safe space for that rare creature: a Trump supporter in New York City. <U+201C>One hundred percent, it<U+2019>s why I spend so much time in here,<U+201D> Christophe Lirola, an investment banker, said while seated at the bar drinking a beer. <U+201C>I love having conversations with people about politics, and many places you can<U+2019>t really do that because then it<U+2019>s like the wolves surrounding the sheep.<U+201D> On Mr. Lirola<U+2019>s right, Mark Guest, a security consultant who looks after celebrities and fashion designers, said he didn<U+2019>t vote for Mr. Trump but plans to give him a chance. <U+201C>What<U+2019>s the Show Me state, Missouri ?<U+201D> Mr. Guest said. <U+201C>I think we are a country of <U+2018>show me.<U+2019> You made a claim? It might have been audacious, like P. T. Barnum <U+2014> you<U+2019>re a salesman, a huckster, a hustler, a barker? O.K. You made a claim? Prove us wrong. That<U+2019>s what our democracy<U+2019>s about.<U+201D> Kevin Philzone, known as Duffy, began bartending at Neary<U+2019>s right after Elaine<U+2019>s, a joint of equal repute, closed in 2011 . He said that he was behind Trump from the very beginning <U+2014> and shocked when he won. <U+201C>I told everybody I thought it was going to be really hairy, really close,<U+201D> he said. Mr. Philzone met Mr. Trump a couple of times at Elaine<U+2019>s and said he even witnessed him behaving in a <U+201C>crass<U+201D> manner. <U+201C>But if you work in construction, you<U+2019>ve got to have that in your repertoire,<U+201D> he said. <U+201C>It<U+2019>s part of your game.<U+201D> A suave older gent, Lee Peck, was sitting by himself at the end of the bar and looking amused. Mr. Peck, a retired banker, has been going to Neary<U+2019>s since the early 1970s. <U+201C>We used to come up here Friday nights after work and sit at the bar,<U+201D> he said. <U+201C>A lot of Friday nights. It<U+2019>s a great watering hole, a lot of good people.<U+201D> Mr. Peck, though a longtime conservative, voted for Hillary Clinton . <U+201C>Trump just turned me off, but he<U+2019>s president, so I have to root for him. So hopefully he<U+2019>s going to be O.K.,<U+201D> he said, and then gestured toward the owner of the bar, Jimmy Neary. <U+201C>Jimmy loves him. He<U+2019>s always been a big Trump guy.<U+201D> <U+201C>Yes, I like Donald Trump,<U+201D> said Mr. Neary, 86, who bears some resemblance to Clarence, the angel in <U+201C> It<U+2019>s a Wonderful Life .<U+201D> He was sitting in one of the red leather corner banquettes and remembering how Mr. Trump<U+2019>s relatives and friends have been visiting his establishment since the era when Mr. Trump was dating Marla Maples and palling around with Frank and Kathie Lee Gifford. <U+201C>To me, he<U+2019>s an absolute gentleman,<U+201D> Mr. Neary said. <U+201C>That<U+2019>s all I can say for him.<U+201D> Though happy to talk politics, he didn<U+2019>t mind returning the subject to his restaurant, which opened on St. Patrick<U+2019>s Day in 1967. <U+201C>The first year was mediocre, not bad,<U+201D> he said. <U+201C>And then I came in here one evening at 6 o<U+2019>clock, it was a nice crowd here, and I heard customers at the bar saying, <U+2018>He doesn<U+2019>t know who<U+2019>s here.<U+2019> Quietly, I disappeared and went into the kitchen and looked out of the glass window, and who was sitting in the corner? John Glenn. And I said to myself, <U+2018>If I wasn<U+2019>t in business another week, I still had the first man to orbit the earth in my restaurant.<U+2019><U+201D> (Well, the first American, anyway.) Gov. Hugh Carey was one of the first politicians to become a regular, back when he had just started his seven-term Congressional run. The Kennedys came, and the Clintons, and Mayor Bloomberg, who took Mr. Neary to Ireland on his private jet to visit the village where the proprietor was born. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar has been there, too. Gay Talese went for dinner recently. Mary Higgins Clark is a regular, and Mr. Neary has shown up as a character in 21 of her novels and even solves a murder in one. With his wife of 40 years, Eileen (<U+201C>now in heaven<U+201D>), he raised four children. His daughter Una Neary is at the restaurant on the weekends, usually in a hostess role but always available to fill in as a waitress, if needed. She is also a partner at Goldman Sachs, the head of bank holding company compliance. On Veterans Day at the bar, Ms. Neary recognized the country<U+2019>s servicemen and women, then added: <U+201C>Today is also another extra special day because on 11/11/1954, is when my father came to America.<U+201D> The place erupted with cheering and clapping. Then Ms. Neary asked everyone to sing <U+201C>God Bless America,<U+201D> which they did with gusto. Correction: November 16, 2016 An earlier version of this article misstated Jimmy Neary<U+2019>s age. He is 86, not 85. Continue following our fashion and lifestyle coverage on Facebook (Styles and Modern Love ), Twitter ( Styles , Fashion and Weddings ) and Instagram . A version of this article appears in print on November 17, 2016, on Page D4 of the New York edition with the headline: Where Everybody Knows Your Name and Accepts Your Politics. 404.input:
time: null 
 author: Alex Ansary 
 source: amtvmedia.com 
 text: US-led airstrike kills at least 30 Afghan civilians 11/03/2016 
PRESS TV 
At least 30 Afghan civilians, including women and children, have lost their lives in Afghanistan in an airstrike carried out by the so-called US-led military alliance in the country<U+2019>s volatile north. 
Local Afghan officials said more than two dozen civilians were also injured in the aerial assault which took place in the northern province of Kunduz on Thursday. 
<U+201C>Afghan forces and coalition troops conducted a joint operation against the Taliban insurgents. In the bombardment, 30 Afghan civilians were martyred and 25 others were wounded,<U+201D> media outlets quoted provincial spokesman, Mahmood Danish, as saying. 
Airstrike sparks anti-US protest rally 
Following the deadly airstrike, dozens of the relatives of those killed in the US-led raid staged a demonstration outside the governor<U+2019>s office in Kunduz to condemn the attack as they were carrying the bodies of the victims. 
<U+201C>I am heartbroken. I have lost seven members of my family. I want to know, why these innocent children were killed? Were they Taliban?<U+201D> said Taza Gul, a 55-year-old laborer, adding, <U+201C>No, they were innocent children.<U+201D> 
Afghan government forces are engaged in fierce fighting against the militants in and around Kunduz. Relatives and members of civilians sit next the dead body of a man who was killed during clashes between Afghan security forces and the Taliban in Kunduz, Afghanistan November 3, 2016. (Photo by Reuters) 
Taliban militants briefly overran the city of Kunduz, the provincial capital with the same name, in early October. They had briefly seized control of the city a year earlier but they were pushed out of Kunduz weeks later. They now seek to gain full control over the city. 
Taliban militants were removed from power following the 2001 US-led invasion of Afghanistan, but they have stepped up their activities in recent months, attempting to overrun several provinces. 
Afghan forces have been engaged in fierce clashes with Taliban to contain the ongoing insurgency across various parts of the violence-wrecked country. 
The rising violence in Afghanistan comes despite the presence of thousands of foreign troops in the country.

405.input:
time: null 
 author: Edmondo Burr 
 source: yournewswire.com 
 text: Sputnik reports: 
Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull said the government is set to present a parliamentary bill to amend the Migration Act , and prevent adults who are sent to Australia<U+2019>s offshore immigration centers from receiving an Australian visa in the future. 
<U+201C>This will send the strongest possible signal to the people smugglers, it will send the strongest possible signal to those who are seeking to persuade persons currently on Nauru and Manus (the islands where Australia<U+2019>s immigration centers are located) that the Australian government will change its mind and allow them to settle here,<U+201D> Turnbull said. 
Australian barrister Greg Barns, spokesman for the Australian Lawyers Alliance, told Radio Sputnik that the proposal breaches the UN Refugee Convention. This declares that refugees are entitled to claim asylum regardless of their method of reaching a country, if they say they have been persecuted in their country of origin. The government<U+2019>s plan would prevent migrants from visiting Australia many years later, while on business or as tourists, even if they have successfully settled in a third country and gained citizenship there. 
<U+201C>It<U+2019>s the most draconian legislation the world has ever seen, it<U+2019>s unprecedented in global terms, and it means that Australia puts itself, yet again, in the basket of pariah states when it comes to those sorts of issues ,<U+201D> Barns said. 
Turnbull<U+2019>s Liberal Party will require the support of opposition parties to pass the legislation. While Bill Shorten, leader of Australia<U+2019>s opposition Labor Party, said the proposal <U+201C>seems ridiculous,<U+201D> his party stopped short of rejecting it and instead promised to examine the plan closely. 
<U+201C>Unfortunately the opposition Labor Party in Australia has been very weak on these issues in recent years, and both the major political parties, the conservatives (Australia<U+2019>s Liberal Party) and the Labor Party, have been able to force these sorts of changes on Australian policy,<U+201D> Barns told Sputnik. 
<U+201C>There have been suggestions today that the Labor Party might finally get some backbone and oppose this legislation, because if the Labor Party, which is the major opposition party, supports this legislation, then it will become a reality.<U+201D> 
The government<U+2019>s claim that their proposal is compliant with international law is <U+201C>laughable,<U+201D> and <U+201C>shows yet again that Australia snubs its nose at international law when it suits it,<U+201D> Barns said. 
Barns said that Australia<U+2019>s immigration policy has become harsher as a result of public fears of migration, and the actions of successive government which have played on these fears. 
<U+201C>Some Australians have a xenophobic, racist view about the rest of the world, they have this ridiculous fear about hordes coming to this island continent and invading it, that<U+2019>s been historic.<U+201D> 
<U+201C>If you don<U+2019>t have strong political leadership which says that we can do better, this will become politically popular,<U+201D> said Barns, who contrasted the current policy with that of Malcom Fraser<U+2019>s 1970<U+2019>s Liberal government, which accepted large numbers of refugees who came on boats from Vietnam. 
Since the government of John Howard from 1996 to 2007, <U+201C>successive governments in Australia have pandered to the xenophobic, racist side of the country, and that<U+2019>s precisely what Malcolm Turnbull is doing with this legislation.<U+201D> 
<U+201C>Australia is a nation built on migration, and in fact some of the leading figures in Australian society came here by boat. Those very same people now would be banned under this law.<U+201D> 
Turnbull<U+2019>s proposal has won the praise of Australia<U+2019>s right-wing populist One Nation party, led by Pauline Hanson, who won re-election to Australia<U+2019>s House of Representatives this year. Good to see that it looks like the Government is now taking its cues from One Nation. Just like last time. #auspol #PHON #Nauru #Manus https://t.co/c0GQew7vR8 
<U+2014> Pauline Hanson (@PaulineHansonOz) 30 October 2016 
Barns said that Turnbull<U+2019>s proposal is an effort to attract votes from Hanson<U+2019>s One Nation to the conservative Liberal Party. 
<U+201C>Malcolm Turnbull<U+2019>s party wants to try and take over some of its vote, and it seems to be that this is the way to do it. To pass outrageous, draconian laws that trash Australia<U+2019>s reputation even further in world eyes when it comes to refugees, simply for short-term political gain.<U+201D>

time: null 
 author: Sean Adl-Tabatabai 
 source: yournewswire.com 
 text: Posted on October 27, 2016 by Sean Adl-Tabatabai in Middle East , News // 0 Comments 
The Palestinian Foreign Ministry have urged The International Criminal Court (ICC) to prosecute the Israeli army after they confessed to <U+201C>field executions<U+201D> against Palestinians. 
The Ministry made the comments after a leaked Israeli army report admitted it was possible to avoid firing against Palestinian people. 
Xinhuanet.com reports: 
<U+201C>The leaking of an Israeli army internal memo is meant to distort the work of the ICC and its preliminary investigations with regards to Israeli crimes including field executions in order to claim that the occupation authorities are undergoing due procedures with regards to such crimes,<U+201D> the ministry said in a statement. 
The ministry said that although the report mentions four cases, it <U+201C>ignores the fact that all cases of field executions that claimed the lives of dozens of Palestinians did not impose any serious harm or life threat to soldiers.<U+201D> 
Israeli public radio reported early on Tuesday that an internal report was dispatched to army soldiers saying that it was possible to avoid shooting Palestinians in the West Bank in four separate incident if the army forces acted in a proper way during those incidents. 
The report added that two Palestinians were killed in those incidents and two others were critically injured, pointing out that soldiers opened fire towards them while they should have not, and that if they had acted differently in some cases, they would have avoided shooting them. 
A wave of tensions has been flaring between Israel and the Palestinians in the Palestinian territories since October 2015. 
Official figures say at least 226 Palestinians and 40 Israeli were killed. 
Tension between the two ides mounted and went on on daily basis following the daily assaults on Jerusalem by Israeli settlers and security forces, besides the repeated attempts of radical Jewish groups to get into Al-Aqsa Mosque in East Jerusalem.

time: null 
 author: J.E. Dyer 
 source: libertyunyielding.com 
 text: Print 
[Ed. <U+2013> The taxation aspect is bad enough. But think about it. Think how the city has to track what people are doing in order to impose such a tax. Since it involves the collection of money for the government, there<U+2019>s no way IT service companies will be able to keep their books on this private. The vendor<U+2019>s books on what consumers are doing will have to be as open as the books on buying gas by the gallon at a gas pump. The difference with infosphere activities is that there is no such thing as cash-based anonymity for the customer. One way or another, a trail is left.] 
You just want to watch movies and TV shows where and when you want to, so you probably think a column about utility taxes has nothing to do with how you get your entertainment. Wrong. The city of Alameda, California, has put a measure, Measure K1, before its voters that would allow Alameda to tax pay-per-view and video streaming services like Netflix and Hulu as if they were public utilities. Watsonville has a similar measure. Other California municipalities have passed similar language. They haven<U+2019>t begun to levy utility taxes on these platforms, but figure as soon as one city decides to levy this tax, there will be a stampede across California. <U+2026> 
Michael Petricone of the Consumer Technology Association calls Measure K1 <U+201C>an absurd expansion of the definition of utility.<U+201D> Think of <U+201C>the precedent this sets,<U+201D> he noted, if cities can tax services that don<U+2019>t utilize public easements or infrastructure as utilities.

408.input:
time: null 
 author: Kenneth P. Vogel Kyle Cheney Nahal Toosi Jack Shafer 
 source: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/11/david-brock-donald-trump-donor-network-231588 
 text: Hillary Clinton<U+2019>s attack dog David Brock is launching his own Koch-brothers-like donor network to finance attacks on President-elect Donald Trump and to rebuild the political left after Trump<U+2019>s stunning victory over Clinton last week. Brock on Thursday night emailed more than 200 of the biggest donors on the left <U+2014> including finance titans George Soros, Tom Steyer and Donald Sussman <U+2014> inviting them to a retreat in Palm Beach over inauguration weekend to assess what Democrats did wrong in 2016, figure out how to correct it and raise cash for those initiatives. Story Continued Below <U+201C>This will be THE gathering for Democratic donors from across the country to hear from a broad and diverse group of leaders about the next steps for progressives under a Trump Administration,<U+201D> Brock wrote to the donors in an email obtained by POLITICO. The retreat, planned as the first in a series of regular gatherings, will feature appearances by an array of Democratic elected officials, operatives and liberal thinkers and group officials, Brock explained in an interview. Though he said he had yet to extend invitations beyond those sent to donors Thursday night, he predicted there would be significant interest, noting that the keynote address at his last major donor conference, back in 2013, was delivered by former President Bill Clinton. <U+201C>What better way to spend inaugural weekend than talking about how to kick Donald Trump<U+2019>s ass?<U+201D> Brock said. Congress By Kyle Cheney Brock <U+2014> a self-described right-wing hitman-turned-Clinton enforcer <U+2014> has used his relationships with some of the left<U+2019>s deepest pockets to build an armada of aggressive political outfits that have become pillars of the institutional left and that raised a combined $65 million during the 2016 cycle. Brock<U+2019>s groups include the conservative media monitoring nonprofit Media Matters, the opposition research super PAC American Bridge and the legal watchdog Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington. Other groups in his network include the liberal media-funding vehicle American Independent Institute, the media-training nonprofit Franklin Forum and the for-profit social media operation ShareBlue, which The New York Times described as <U+201C> Hillary Clinton<U+2019>s Outrage Machine .<U+201D> A seventh group, a super PAC called Correct the Record that was created to coordinate directly with Clinton<U+2019>s campaign , is winding down, though Brock said that a number of its functions and personnel likely will be absorbed by his other groups. While the entire political left is grappling with how to move on after Clinton<U+2019>s devastating loss, it could be a particular challenge for Brock and his groups, since he was so closely associated with Clinton. Brock acknowledged in the interview: "There is no question that we poured our heart and soul into this election for Hillary, but these institutions were built before her campaign and were intended to outlast it.<U+201D> And in his email to donors, he pointed out that he created Media Matters more than a decade ago to help the left push back during George W. Bush<U+2019>s presidency. <U+201C>In 2005, we were part of a successful progressive effort to regroup, retool and recover,<U+201D> he wrote. <U+201C>While today<U+2019>s situation is more dire, media matters more than ever.<U+201D> One of the areas where the left has been at a disadvantage is using the legal and regulatory system to call out Republican politicians and groups, Brock said. He cited the success of the conservative group Judicial Watch in using the Freedom of Information Act and legal system to pry free emails from Clinton<U+2019>s State Department. Presidential Transition By Nahal Toosi <U+201C>Judicial Watch has a $30 million budget, and they had a significant impact on the election,<U+201D> he said, comparing it to CREW<U+2019>s $2-million budget. <U+201C>And if we<U+2019>re heading into an administration that looks like it could well be as corrupt as the gilded age, we need to significantly reinforce the capacities for an aggressive ethics watchdog.<U+201D> The Palm Beach retreat in some ways seems to be a challenge to the 12-year-old Democracy Alliance, a club of liberal financiers that was started by Soros and a handful of other major donors to fund the institutional left . In fact, the club, which held its annual winter meeting this week in Washington, helped launch Media Matters, and many of Brock<U+2019>s donors are included among its ranks. Brock said he<U+2019>s inviting the president of the DA, as the club is known, to his Palm Beach retreat. But, while the Democracy Alliance at its winter meeting discussed ways to push back on the Trump administration, many of the group<U+2019>s members have tried to train its focus on pressuring Democrats from the left on issues like fighting climate change, money in politics and drug laws. Brock<U+2019>s network, on the other hand, is more overtly and aggressively political, and has been largely agnostic on the philosophical divisions with which Democrats are grappling. <U+201C>We don<U+2019>t think of this as representing a faction of the Democratic Party, but a cross-section of it, so we<U+2019>re not going to precook things ideologically,<U+201D> he said. <U+201C>It is very politically minded, and there is an urgency to it.<U+201D> By Bill Scher By Thomas Wright By Joshua Zeitz By Jack Shafer

<U+201C>I<U+2019>ve been trying to figure out what common trait binds Clinton supporters together. As far as I can tell, the most unifying characteristic is a willingness to bully in all its forms. Have a Trump sign in your lawn? They will steal it. If you have a Trump bumper sticker, they will deface your car.

412.input:
time: null 
 author: noauthor 
 source: https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/24/opinion/the-religious-right-and-the-election.html?_r=0 
 text: To the Editor: Re <U+201C> In Defense of the Religious Right ,<U+201D> by Ross Douthat (column, Oct. 16): As the granddaughter of an evangelical pastor, I am numbed by the hypocrisy of this group and the candidacy of Donald Trump. Always quick to condemn the sexual behavior of others in the past, evangelical leaders have chosen to look the other way regarding the outrageous sexual behavior of their candidate. In the apparent hope that a Trump Supreme Court will finally make all abortions illegal in this country, they have willingly signed on with a candidate who sexually degrades and humiliates women. No matter which way you slice it, women cannot win with this bunch. DARLEE CROCKETT La Jolla, Calif. To the Editor: Ross Douthat writes about politics as if the religious right is and has been the only home for Christians. New York<U+2019>s great liberal senator, Robert Wagner, was born an ordinary German, married Irish and was buried Catholic. Some of us still see his work <U+2014> Social Security, labor and racial justice <U+2014> as the secular expression of the great papal encyclical, <U+201C>Rerum Novarum.<U+201D> Perhaps the Democrats of today no longer have a place for us, but as I hear from my relatives and college friends, it is fair to say that we are still closer to Wagner<U+2019>s vision for America than we are to Mr. Douthat<U+2019>s, and that Donald Trump is anathema. JAMES F. McMANUS III Phoenix To the Editor: Ross Douthat thinks that religious conservatives are needed. But the rigid religious longing for and insistence on a return of bygone days and ways, coupled with a maddeningly plastic embrace of an irreligious candidate who fails any reasonable test of responsible ethical and moral standards, shows how much harm they can do, not how needed they are. Indeed, as fanatics of every stripe seem intent on proving, when a deity is perceived to be on their side, horrific actions are made defensible. If one historical figure religious conservatives recognize were around today, he might say it<U+2019>s time to drive the religious from the temple of democracy. JOHN CLARK Warren, N.J. To the Editor: I can<U+2019>t think of two more contemporary defenders of Christianity<U+2019>s bedrock beliefs than Ben Carson and Jerry Falwell Jr., mentioned by Ross Douthat in his column. In contrast, the column underscores the dilution of every Judeo-Christian belief by a political community called America. We are no longer a country of religious believers as extolled by de Tocqueville in his masterpiece, <U+201C>Democracy in America.<U+201D> We<U+2019>ve succumbed to an apostate electorate, what Plato<U+2019>s <U+201C>Republic<U+201D> called democracy<U+2019>s next step, a tyranny of the masses. TERENCE O<U+2019>FLANAGAN Rockville Centre, N.Y. To the Editor: As we left a funeral the other day, I asked my uncle, a Catholic priest, what the bishops were doing about this election. I asked because I used to argue with my father about his votes for president. <U+201C>The bishops tell me my soul is in danger if I vote for a Democrat who supports abortion,<U+201D> my father would say. <U+201C>So it<U+2019>s O.K. to vote for someone who believes in the death penalty but not abortion?<U+201D> was my retort. The last Democrat he got to vote against was Bill Clinton. And my dad was a Democrat. My uncle the priest told me that the bishops still believe that abortion is the gravest sin (he disagrees), but that this year they were telling their flocks to listen to their consciences. Either these old men have finally seen a Republican too vile and repugnant to endorse, or the Nuns on the Bus have really won the hearts and minds of American Catholics. ROBERT LAUGHLIN Denver A version of this letter appears in print on October 24, 2016, on Page A20 of the New York edition with the headline: The Religious Right and the Election. Today's Paper | Subscribe

414.input:
time: null 
 author: noauthor 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/mexicos-options-in-a-trump-trade-war-1479680567 
 text: If the sharp selloff of the Mexican peso after the Nov. 8 election of Donald Trump were set to music it might sound like a funeral dirge, the dearly departed being the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta). The peso has fallen to an all-time low of more than 20 to the dollar, and on Thursday the Bank of Mexico raised its benchmark interest rate to stem the bleeding. Mexico investors are worried that Mr. Trump might actually believe<U+2014>as he argued in his campaign<U+2014>that U.S. productivity growth and job creation depend on renegotiating Nafta to discourage U.S. investments south of the border. But Mexico won<U+2019>t easily yield to a new deal that limits its access to U.S. markets in order to make it less attractive as a destination for capital. If Mr. Trump counters with tariff hikes in violation of Nafta, Mexico is likely to respond with its own duty increases. It did this with $2.4 billion in retaliatory tariffs on important U.S. export products in 2009 when the U.S. failed to live up to its Nafta obligation in trucking. There is even the possibility that Mr. Trump will carry out his threat to tear up the agreement. There are no winners in any of these narratives. In the 23 years since Nafta was launched, Mexico has cultivated a middle-class, a more-vibrant democracy and a diversified economy far less dependent than it once was on oil. The country now sends 80% of its exports to the U.S. A trade war would be an economic disaster and open the door to political instability. Thus it won<U+2019>t be so easy for Mr. Trump to bully the neighbors. National pride will play a role in stiffening the Mexican spine, and President Enrique Pe<U+00F1>a Nieto <U+2019>s government is signaling that it intends to face any crisis by deepening structural reforms, getting its fiscal house in order and looking more aggressively for new trading partners. The unspoken message to Mr. Trump is that if he plays the protectionist game, Mexico is ready to raise the stakes. Nafta<U+2019>s demise would be bad for the U.S. too, although the U.S. stock market rally suggests that the fear of a trade war is overblown. Protectionist steel and textile tycoon Wilbur Ross is rumored to be in line for a job in the new administration. But Vice President-elect Mike Pence is a free trader from Indiana, which in 2015 exported $4.8 billion in goods to Mexico, its second-largest export market. From time to time Mr. Trump has had flashes of sanity on trade. In a joint press conference with Mr. Pe<U+00F1>a Nieto in Mexico in August, then-candidate Trump spoke of the need to <U+201C>keep manufacturing wealth in our hemisphere.<U+201D> Some expect the Trump administration to find a way to largely leave Nafta alone while it works on legitimate trade issues like China<U+2019>s practice of intellectual-property theft. Mexico seems to want to help in this face-saving endeavor and has wisely decided not to escalate the rhetoric. It doesn<U+2019>t need to: Americans have plenty to lose if Nafta is destroyed. Many U.S. corporations are now heavily invested in supply chains that crisscross the continent to create globally competitive products. These support millions of U.S. manufacturing jobs. Saying goodbye to duty-free access to Mexico under Nafta also would hit U.S. agricultural exports hard. Mexican Economy Minister Ildefonso Guajardo told Reuters on Nov. 10 that his government is <U+201C>ready to talk so we can explain the strategic importance of Nafta for the region. Here we<U+2019>re not talking about . . . renegotiating it, we<U+2019>re simply talking about dialogue.<U+201D> He also said Mexico will look for new markets, adding to more than 40 existing free-trade agreements. It had hoped for expanded opportunities via the proposed Trans-Pacific Partnership, a 12-nation accord that includes the U.S. and much of Asia. But President Obama wasn<U+2019>t able to get TPP through Congress and Mr. Trump has promised to kill it. Mr. Guajardo said that Mexico will pursue the possibility of completing a smaller TPP with the countries that are expected to have ratified it by the end of 2016. He named Japan, New Zealand, Australia, Singapore, Vietnam and Malaysia. Australia would probably be eager to replace the U.S. as Mexico<U+2019>s chief food supplier. None of this would make up for the loss of U.S. market access under Nafta, which means that increasing Mexican competitiveness is urgent. Mr. Pe<U+00F1>a Nieto got historic constitutional reforms in energy and telecommunications through his Congress in 2013. Opening these markets to competition will attract capital and improve the infrastructure for producers but implementation takes time. Unfortunately the government<U+2019>s debt burden has increased sharply in recent years and taxes have gone up, adding to disappointing economic performance. These are mistakes that Mexican policy makers cannot afford if Mr. Trump plays chicken with Nafta. Write to O<U+2019>Grady@wsj.com.

Sen. Mark Kirk (R-Ill.) ignited a political firestorm Thursday night after he randomly brought up his Democratic rival<U+2019>s heritage after she touted her military experience during a debate. 
Rep. Tammy Duckworth (D-Ill.), who is of mixed Thai and American descent, cited her military service as well as her family<U+2019>s when making the case against rushing into war. 
<U+201C>I<U+2019>m a daughter of the American Revolution. I<U+2019>ve bled for this nation. But I still want to be there in the Senate when the drums of war sound,<U+201C> she said. <U+201D>Because people are quick to sound the drums of war and I want to be there to say, <U+2018>This is what it costs, this is what you<U+2019>re asking us to do<U+2019>. Let<U+2019>s make sure the American people understand what we are engaging in.<U+201D>

US Representative Tammy Duckworth of Illinois arrives to address delegates on the fourth and final day of the Democratic National Convention at Wells Fargo Center on July 28, 2016 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Duckworth responded on Twitter with an indisputable message. My mom is an immigrant and my dad and his family have served this nation in uniform since the Revolution #ILSEN pic.twitter.com/ehEBHswFMs <U+2014> Tammy Duckworth (@TammyforIL) October 28, 2016 
Kirk<U+2019>s campaign later issued a statement addressing the controversy:

Duckworth lied about her legal troubles, was unable to defend her failures at the VA and then falsely attacked Senator Kirk over his record on supporting gay rights.<U+201D> 
But at that point, the damage was already done.

416.input:
time: null 
 author: Jimmy Vielkind 
 source: http://www.politico.com/states/new-york/albany/story/2016/11/how-a-democratic-rout-is-actually-good-for-andrew-cuomo-107267 
 text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo. | AP Photo/Seth Wenig By Jimmy Vielkind 11/10/16 06:39 AM EST ALBANY <U+2014> His longtime friend Hillary Clinton was handed a stunning upset in her bid for the presidency. Republicans continue to control a majority in both houses of Congress. His efforts to help Democrats win the state Senate are sputtering toward failure. Yet Tuesday's results may have been just what Gov. Andrew Cuomo's career needed. Story Continued Below Clinton<U+2019>s unexpected defeat will hit the reset button within the national Democratic Party in a way that puts Cuomo, a self-styled centrist and populist Democrat, in the mix for 2020. And continued Republican control of the state Senate <U+2014> likely to be buttressed, again, by the chamber<U+2019>s Independent Democratic Conference <U+2014> keeps a system in place that has worked perfectly well for Cuomo during the last six years. <U+201C>He never had it so good,<U+201D> said Hank Sheinkopf, a political consultant who advised the governor<U+2019>s 2014 re-election bid. The governor himself was quiet between a 10:30 p.m. appearance outside Clinton<U+2019>s election night party on Tuesday night at the Javits Center and a 4:30 p.m. phone interview on Wednesday with the NY1 cable network. In a 10-minute exchange, Cuomo said his "friend" Clinton<U+2019>s loss made for an <U+201C>emotional day,<U+201D> but that he had already conducted a pleasant conversation with President-elect Donald Trump about his own plans to upgrade the state<U+2019>s transportation infrastructure. Lewis Dodley, the anchor, asked Cuomo about his role in the national Democratic firmament as it undergoes self-diagnostics and repairs. Cuomo<U+2019>s answer outlined the <U+201C>New York philosophy,<U+201D> which is that <U+201C>we believe in individual rights, but we believe in the collective.<U+201D> He then talked about his accomplishments over six years in office, including the legalization of same-sex marriage and increasing the minimum wage to $15 in many parts of the state. Asked if he would play a role in national party affairs, Cuomo replied: <U+201C>I see a role for myself as governor of the state of New York.<U+201D> Erie County Democratic chairman Jeremy Zellner had a more succinct answer when reached by phone on Wednesday: <U+201C>Absolutely.<U+201D> After years of gridlock and divided government in Washington, Zellner explained, Cuomo could offer a counternarrative. His basic political story involves reaching across the political aisle and getting big things done. <U+201C>People want government to work, and that<U+2019>s definitely a huge positive for our governor,<U+201D> Zellner said. <U+201C>I hope we can continue moving this state forward.<U+201D> While the final votes are still being tallied, the local result of the 2016 elections appear to be a state Senate that is still controlled by Republicans , probably in concert with the moderate IDC. Cuomo has worked well with the Republicans, and will have a much easier time threading a coming debate over state income tax policy if they are around to neutralize liberal, union-backed Democrats who dominate the state Assembly. Ostensibly, Cuomo<U+2019>s decision this cycle to raise money for Senate Democratic challengers and endorse select candidates was ideological. The governor said he had worked well with Republicans, but needed a Democratic Legislature to implement public campaign financing, extend tuition assistance programs to undocumented immigrants, raise the age of criminal responsibility and limit lawmakers<U+2019> outside income. Progressives have long dreamed of these policies, but considered Cuomo a fair weather ally at best. Leaders of the state<U+2019>s institutional left wing issued statements mourning the setbacks to these priorities. <U+201C>It<U+2019>s impossible to put a positive spin on last night<U+2019>s results,<U+201D> Citizen Action executive director Karen Scharff wrote in an email. <U+201C>I couldn<U+2019>t sleep last night, and woke up this morning heartbroken.<U+201D> But on Wednesday Cuomo said nothing. He is unlikely to have shed any tears when Zephyr Teachout, who challenged him from the left in 2014, lost her bid for a seat in Congress. Republicans, many of whom suspected this year was more about the governor<U+2019>s left flank than about a genuine ideological split, said they were ready to move along without any hard feelings. <U+201C>My thoughts are simply this: my relationship with Andrew Cuomo is not going to change one iota. I deal with him when I deal with him and his position knowing full well that the only consideration that he has on any issue is which way that issue is going to be assisting him politically at that moment,<U+201D> Senate deputy majority leader John DeFrancisco, a Republican from Syracuse, said. <U+201C>If you know that, you should be able to deal with that situation accordingly.<U+201D> Will Cuomo keep pushing his agenda? With an eye toward possible re-election in 2018 or a presidential campaign in 2020, Sheinkopf said it almost doesn<U+2019>t matter. Cuomo already has racked up bipartisan achievements, he explained, so issues that rally the Democratic base (but aren<U+2019>t enacted into law) are arguably more useful than additional achievements. <U+201C>Reaching across the aisle as a principle is a great thing, but blaming the opposition party for not working with you is also a great thing,<U+201D> he said. <U+201C>He can have it both ways.<U+201D> There<U+2019>s also sufficient space between Cuomo and Clinton that he won<U+2019>t be damaged by her loss. The governor endorsed the former senator from New York and secretary of state immediately upon her entry into the race <U+2014> a move fueled by a desire to jump ahead of the governor<U+2019>s foe, New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio <U+2014> and was a dutiful surrogate in the run-up to Clinton<U+2019>s April 19 primary win over Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders. Cuomo, though, also flirted conspicuously with Vice President Joe Biden when he was considering a late-entry into the race. His efforts for Clinton, perhaps by bilateral agreement, were confined to the borders of the Empire State <U+2014> where her victory was assured. In August and early September, before revelations of Trump<U+2019>s misogyny that many thought would finish him, Cuomo held back from attacking him. Finally, in a trio of rallies on the final weekend of the campaign, Cuomo described Trump as <U+201C>un-New York<U+201D> for his stances on immigrants and women. All of this will no doubt be scrutinized by the party base in coming months and years. As will arguments over his role, or lack thereof, in the Bridgegate scandal and the federal and state corruption charges against members of his inner circle. But while a Clinton victory would have given Cuomo a place along the bar rail of Democratic politicians, her loss gives him a chance to do more than gaze at the top shelf. <U+201C>It gives different people new opportunities,<U+201D> said state Sen. Simcha Felder, a Democrat who caucuses with Republicans. <U+201C>No one would admit that, but I think they<U+2019>re very happy.<U+201D> A free synopsis of our Pro morning email about New York education policy and politics A free synopsis of our Pro morning email about New York energy policy and politics A free synopsis of our Pro morning email about New York health care policy and politics A free synopsis of our Pro morning email about New York real estate policy and politics Our morning email with must-read analysis and breaking news on state news and politics A morning email with must-read analysis and breaking news on city news and politics. A weekly round-up of legislation in City Council for politics and policy professionals. A reported briefing on money in politics, executive moves, and trends in communications, lobbying and consulting. Our twice-a-week digest of news on courts and the law in New York Azi Paybarah and Jimmy Vielkind's must-read briefing informing the daily conversation among knowledgeable New Yorkers.

417.input:
time: null 
 author: Jess Bravin 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/alaska-lawyer-accuses-justice-thomas-of-groping-her-at-1999-dinner-event-1477609085 
 text: WASHINGTON<U+2014>An Alaska lawyer has accused Justice Clarence Thomas of groping her at an event for young scholars in 1999, as similar allegations against men in powerful political and business positions have sparked a national debate on the treatment of women. Moira Smith, 41 years old, said the justice touched her buttocks several times when they were seated together at his request at a dinner for Truman Foundation scholars in Falls Church, Va. Ms. Smith<U+2019>s allegations were first reported Thursday by the National Law Journal. A Supreme Court spokeswoman said Justice Thomas, 68, had no comment beyond a statement made to the publication. <U+201C>This claim is preposterous and it never happened,<U+201D> the justice said in that statement. The incident would have taken place eight years after he joined the Supreme Court and recalls a controversy that dogged the justice<U+2019>s Supreme Court 1991 confirmation, when a female aide, Anita Hill, testified that he had made inappropriate sexual remarks and propositions to her. Justice Thomas vigorously denied the allegations and was confirmed by a 52-48 vote. Ms. Smith posted an account of the incident on Facebook on Oct. 7, after hearing a 2005 <U+201C>Access Hollywood<U+201D> recording in which Donald Trump, now the Republican presidential nominee, lewdly spoke of grabbing and kissing women. Several women have subsequently made claims of inappropriate sexual behavior by Mr. Trump, which he has denied. The National Law Journal said it learned of the incident through the social media posting. The publication interviewed friends and former roommates of Ms. Smith, who told the publication that she complained of the incident after it occurred 17 years ago. In a statement Thursday, Ms. Smith said she was motivated to disclose the incident after seeing other women speak up about alleged assaults or inappropriate behavior by influential men. <U+201C>As the mother of a young daughter and son, I am coming forward to show that it is important to stand up for yourself and tell the truth,<U+201D> she said. <U+201C>When Justice Thomas touched me inappropriately and without my consent, I was 23 years old<U+2014>and felt there was nothing I could do. Seventeen years later, it is clear that sexual harassment, misconduct and assault continue to be pervasive, having an impact on all women.<U+201D> Ms. Smith is general counsel of a public utility in Anchorage, the Enstar Natural Gas unit of AltaGas Ltd. , Calgary, Alberta, and is married to Jake Metcalfe, a former chairman of the Alaska Democratic Party. A 1997 Georgetown University graduate, she was awarded a Truman Scholarship through a foundation Congress established to benefit young people who demonstrate <U+201C>outstanding potential for and who plan to pursue a career in public service.<U+201D> She later received a law degree from the University of California, Berkeley. Carrie Severino, chief counsel at the conservative Judicial Crisis Network and a former Thomas law clerk, sought to defend Justice Thomas in a piece published online in the National Review on Thursday . <U+201C>The alleged conduct bears no resemblance to the man I worked closely with, whom I still count a friend after nearly 10 years,<U+201D> Ms. Severino wrote, adding she gave the allegations <U+201C>no credit whatsoever.<U+201D> Justice Thomas, the second African-American and among the most conservative jurists to serve on the Supreme Court since the 1930s, rose through Republican ranks as an aide to a GOP senator, an official in the Ronald Reagan administration and an appointee first to a federal appeals court and then the Supreme Court by President George H.W. Bush. Ms. Hill, a University of Oklahoma law professor who had been an aide to Justice Thomas when he was an Education Department official and then chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, testified 25 years ago at his Senate confirmation hearings. Four additional women made similar allegations but weren<U+2019>t called to testify, according to the book <U+201C>Strange Justice,<U+201D> an account of the confirmation battle by then Wall Street Journal reporters Jill Abramson and Jane Mayer. Write to Jess Bravin at jess.bravin@wsj.com

time: null 
 author: Ed Ballard 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/copper-slides-after-recent-rise-1479208680 
 text: Copper prices fell Tuesday as analysts cautioned the market was due for a correction after a dramatic rally stoked by Donald Trump <U+2019>s election. Copper for December delivery closed down 0.6% at $2.5050 a pound on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices for the metal are up more than 19% from their October lows, driven by expectations of increased U.S. infrastructure spending under a new administration and a steadier economic outlook for China. China and the U.S. are the world<U+2019>s largest copper consumers, respectively. <U+201D>Prices ran ahead of themselves,<U+201D> said William Adams, head of Research at Fast Markets Ltd. <U+201C>We<U+2019>ll probably consolidate this week after the froth of last week.<U+201D> Looking ahead, he said news of appointments to President-elect Donald Trump<U+2019>s team could move the market as investors seek a clearer understanding of the likely direction of U.S. government policy. Meanwhile, Chinese foreign direct investment data due later Tuesday may shift views of the strength of demand from the world<U+2019>s key consumer of industrial metals. Carsten Menke, commodities research analyst at Julius Baer, said Mr. Trump<U+2019>s victory probably won<U+2019>t have a big influence on the global balance of supply and demand for base metals, even if he delivers on his promise to boost infrastructure investment. <U+201D>Even an assumed 10% increase in [U.S.] infrastructure-related copper consumption would hardly matter on a global scale,<U+201D> he wrote. Analysts at Commerzbank highlighted <U+201C>further correction potential<U+201D> for copper after data from the U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission showed speculators<U+2019> net long position in copper futures on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange rose over 150% to a record 59,300 contracts in the week to Nov. 8. The data covers the period before the election of Mr. Trump, so next week<U+2019>s figure may show an even more bullish stance among speculators, Commerzbank said. Copper for delivery in three months closed down 0.6% at $5,525 a metric ton on the London Metal Exchange. Write to Ed Ballard at ed.ballard@wsj.com and Ira Iosebashvili at ira.iosebashvili@wsj.com

420.input:
time: null 
 author: Jon Queally | Common Dreams 
 source: mintpressnews.com 
 text: Videos Republican Protester Says He Was Nearly Killed After Trump Says <U+2018>Take Him Out<U+2019> Secret Service whisk candidate off stage as supporters create scare by attacking lone anti-Trump Republican at Nevada rally   Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump speaks during a campaign rally at Laconia Middle School, Thursday, Sept. 15, 2016, in Laconia, N.H. 
So who nearly killed whom in Reno, Nevada on Saturday night? 
A fracas at a Donald Trump rally captured on live television Saturday night saw the Republican candidate whisked off the stage by Secret Service agents and left those watching perplexed by what happened in the front rows as police in military gear appeared on the scene with one man ultimately led away by officials. 
But while one of his sons joined another top campaign aide in <U+201C> irresponsibly <U+201D> and falsely suggesting it was an assassination attempt against Trump, the man at the center of the incident says that all he did was hold up a sign reading <U+201C>Republicans Against Trump<U+201D> before being tackled and beaten by those around him at the rally. 
Speaking with the Guardian following the event, the man, who identified himself as Austyn Crites from Reno, said it was the hysteria of his fellow Republicans at the rally<U+2014>and incitement by the presidential candidate himself<U+2014>which turned a simple gesture of dissent into a much more dangerous situation. Watch protester relives Trump fans<U+2019> attack at Nevada rally: 
<U+201C>I just went with sign that said <U+2018>Republicans Against Trump,'<U+201D> Crites told the Reno Gazette-Journa l . <U+201C>It<U+2019>s a sign that you can find online. I held up the sign and initially people around me were just booing me telling me to get out of there. Then a couple of these guys tried grabbing the sign out of my hands.<U+201D> He said he had no intentions other than to let his opinion be known. He expected to be booed and perhaps led away, but not pummeled nearly to death. 
<U+201C>Multiple people just tackled me down, kicking me choking me and just beating me up,<U+201D> he said. <U+201C>That<U+2019>s when things even got crazier. I was on the ground and people were holding my arms, legs and I kept saying I can barely breathe. I was turning my neck just to get a little bit of air to keep from passing out.<U+201D> The police, he said, intervened just in time. 
According to the Guardian : The 33-year-old <U+2013> who says he has been a registered Republican for about six years <U+2013> said he was kicked, punched and choked, and feared for his life when the crowd turned on him at the gathering in Reno, Nevada . Crites cited Trump<U+2019>s treatment of Mexicans, Muslims and women as the reason he decided to protest again Trump, who he described as <U+201C>a textbook version of a dictator and a fascist<U+201D>. There were panicked scenes at the Trump rally, apparently prompted by shouts from at least one person in the crowd that the protester had a gun. Hundreds of people fled to the the back of the auditorium in panic as Trump was hurriedly rushed from the stage by his security detail. 
As the following clip of the unfolding incident shows, Trump acknowledges someone in the crowd during his remarks, saying, <U+201C>Oh we have one of those guys from the Hillary Clinton campaign. How much are you being paid, $1,500?<U+201D> As the crowd begins to agitate and boo, Trump then says, <U+201C>Okay. Take him out.<U+201D> Just seconds later, as the scuffle appears to intensify, is when agents quickly approach Trump and take him off stage. Watch Donald Trump Rushed Off Stage by Secret Service: After Crites was removed from the event by security and police, Trump returned to the stage and told his supporters. <U+201C>No one said it would be easy.<U+201D> 
Though Republicans and Trump supporters on social media overnight were calling him a <U+201C>thug<U+201D><U+201C>infiltrator<U+201D> and <U+201C>Clinton shill,<U+201D> Crites posted a Facebook message (subsequently deleted) which said he has nothing official to do with the Clinton campaign, though he is supporting the Democratic candidate this year over Trump and has donated to her campaign. 
<U+201C>Take what happened to me tonight,<U+201D> Crites wrote to his fellow Republicans in the post, <U+201C>as a classic example of dictator incitement of violence <U+2014> against your own Republican brother with a stupid sign.<U+201D> This work by Common Dreams is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 International License. Be Sociable, Share!

421.input:
time: null 
 author: Kit O'Connell 
 source: mintpressnews.com 
 text: Videos Should Third Parties Support <U+2018>Vote Pacts<U+2019> To Avoid <U+2018>Spoiling<U+2019> Elections? Unlike other vote swapping schemes which pair a voter in a swing state with a voter in a <U+2018>safe<U+2019> state, a vote pact pairs voters across party lines who each promise to cast their ballots for a third-party candidate instead.   Green party presidential candidate Jill Stein, foreground, meets her supporters during a campaign stop at Humanist Hall in Oakland, Calif. on Thursday, Oct. 6, 2016. 
AUSTIN, Texas <U+2014> Third-party candidates are often accused of acting as <U+201C>spoilers<U+201D> by siphoning votes from the two major parties<U+2019> nominees and potentially tipping the balance in an election. 
Perhaps the most notable example of this is Ralph Nader. The former Green Party candidate is frequently accused of helping George W. Bush win the 2000 presidential election by diverting votes which otherwise would have gone to Democratic nominee Al Gore, although this theory has been disproven many times . 
<U+201C>A lot of people have basically grown to depend on the confines of the two-party system and have a hard time getting their brain around a constructive, strategic path out of it,<U+201D> Sam Husseini, a political activist, told MintPress News. 
Husseini proposed an alternative strategy in which voters form <U+201C>voting pacts<U+201D> across party lines. For example, a Democrat and a Republican might each agree to vote for a third-party candidate of their choice, rather than the two major parties<U+2019> candidates. The strategy reduces the potential for <U+201C>spoiling<U+201D> votes, as long as voting pacts don<U+2019>t cross state lines, because each of the major candidates loses voters equally. 
Husseini operates the website VotePact.org to encourage this method of vote sharing or vote pairing. Letter in Wash Post: <U+201C>VotePact Offers Voters a Sensible Alternative<U+201D> <U+2014> how #NeverTrump & #NeverHillary can pair up: https://t.co/HB3CtnGGdi 
<U+2014> votepact (@votepact) August 30, 2016 
<U+201C>It has the potential for being a catalyst for genuine realignment and perhaps even for a victory for a so-called third party or independent candidate creative enough to use such a strategy,<U+201D> Husseini said. 
Third-party candidates frequently urge voters to follow their conscience rather opt for one of the <U+201C>lesser of two evils<U+201D> selected by the two-party system. As Green Party nominee Dr. Jill Stein frequently says , <U+201C>We need to stand up and fight for the greater good like our lives depend on it.<U+201D> 
Husseini said he<U+2019>d like to see third-party candidates embrace vote pacts instead of dismissing spoiler claims. He suggested they should also urge their supporters to form vote pacts as a way to safely support third-party movement building. Here<U+2019>s how Husseini imagines the idea being pitched by a candidate: <U+201C>There<U+2019>s a way out of this. You feel like you gotta vote for Clinton because you hate Trump. I get that. Lots of people are like that and lots of people are on the other side. Well, they should pair up and both vote for me.<U+201D> 
He continued: <U+201C>I<U+2019>ve never seen any third-party candidate do that, which is why I think they<U+2019>re going to remain in single digits<U+201D> in the popular vote. 
Other forms of <U+201C>vote swapping<U+201D> have been proposed during this and previous elections, usually seeking to pair a voter from a swing state with a voter from a state <U+201C>red<U+201D> or <U+201C>blue<U+201D> state. The voter in the so-called <U+201C>safe state<U+201D> agrees to vote for a third-party candidate in return for securing a vote for their preferred candidate in a state where the election is in play. 
This <U+201C>safe state<U+201D> strategy was especially popular in 2000, when voters sought to trade Nader and Gore votes. That election prompted a court case in which the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that that vote swapping is <U+201C>clearly protected by the First Amendment.<U+201D> 
Last month, Husseini told Bustle<U+2019>s Am<U+00E9>e Latour that the <U+201C>safe state<U+201D> strategy just <U+201C>kicks the can down the road.<U+201D> Third parties often hope to secure 5 percent of the popular vote in presidential races, which would unlock millions in additional federal funding for future elections, but Husseini thinks by embracing vote pacts they could potentially win elections outright. 
<U+201C>The other so-called <U+2018>strategies<U+2019> are basically a way of minimizing the so-called <U+2018>damage<U+2019> of third-party runs,<U+201D> he told MintPress. 
While Husseini said he hopes alternative candidates will someday make vote pacts a key part of their campaign strategy, he also stressed that it isn<U+2019>t too late for voters to embrace the idea in the 2016 election. Vote pacts require mutual trust between political opponents, so he recommends forming them with family members, close friends, and coworkers across party lines. 
He also said voting pacts could spur political change by encouraging people to engage in challenging political conversations across party lines rather than simply shutting out opposing views. 
<U+201C>Instead unfriending that guy who said he might vote for Trump because he hates Clinton, reach out to them.<U+201D> Be Sociable, Share!

422.input:
time: null 
 author: wideawake1 
 source: endoftheamericandream.com 
 text: Voting Machine Problems Are Being Reported All Over America By Michael Snyder, on November 8th, 2016 
After what happened in the last election , people seem to be more alert to signs of potential election fraud this time around. And right now the Internet is buzzing with reports of voting machine problems in some of the most important swing states. In some areas officials were forced to make emergency switches to paper ballots due to voting machine issues, and in other cases voters that intended to vote for Donald Trump were having their votes registered for Hillary Clinton instead. The mainstream media is insisting that these are <U+201C>isolated instances<U+201D>, and hopefully that turns out to be true because the integrity of our elections is of the utmost importance. 
Voting machines are supposed to make voting easier and more efficient, but instead they are once again causing major headaches all over the country. The following summary of technical issues that we have seen so far comes from the New York Daily News <U+2026> 
In Utah, voting machine problems in the southern part of the state forced poll workers to use paper ballots, with some residents sent to alternate voting locations. 
Voters in Colorado received provisional ballots after officials reported computer problems state-wide, though at least one county said that the state electoral system was back up Tuesday afternoon. 
Machine issues were reported in Wilson County, Tenn. <U+2014> and at one point all of the county<U+2019>s machines went down, according to local reports . Voting later resumed manually. 
In Texas, a computer used by election clerks malfunctioned at a polling place, so officials briefly diverted voters to another polling place more than two miles away. 
In Louisiana, some early voters were forced to wait as correct machines were installed. 
In Durham County, N.C., paper poll books were being used Tuesday due to <U+201C>tech problems at a few sites.<U+201D> 
But much more troubling is what has been happening in Pennsylvania. Numerous voters have been reporting that their votes were switched by the voting machines from Donald Trump to Hillary Clinton. The following is an excerpt from one local news report <U+2026> 
<U+201C>Every time I would push a candidate for the Republican party, it would come up for the Democratic candidate,<U+201D> said voter David Drane. 
Election judges in Clinton Township, Butler County confirmed there were issues with two of their eight automated voting machines. Most of the issues came when people tried to vote straight party ticket. 
However, others said they specifically wanted to vote for Republican Donald Trump only to see their vote switched before their eyes to Democrat Hillary Clinton. 
<U+201C>I went back, pressed Trump again. Three times I did this, so then I called one of the women that were working the polls over. And she said you must be doing it wrong. She did it three times and it defaulted to Hillary every time,<U+201D> Bobbie Lee Hawranko said. 
And USA Today is reporting that vote switching is also being reported in Lebanon County, Pennsylvania<U+2026> 
And in one of the few glitches with political overtones, a problem with the calibration of electronic voting machines in Lebanon County, Pa., caused about a half dozen machines to display what voters thought were straight Republican tickets as straight Democratic tickets. Poll workers alerted the county elections bureau, and voters were able to change their ballots, said Michael Anderson, director of the Lebanon County Bureau of Elections. 
If you recall, this exact same kind of thing happened in the all-important swing state of Ohio in 2012 . 
So if Pennsylvania ends up being the difference in a Hillary Clinton victory, this will need to be looked at very, very closely. 
Reports of vote switching in Pennsylvania are already getting so much attention that they are even making television news <U+2026> 
In other parts of the state, a different type of problem has emerged. One African-American voter that tried to vote for Trump was extremely frustrated when the voting machine that he was using remained completely stuck on a selection for Hillary Clinton. This particular voter captured this on video and uploaded the video footage to Twitter <U+2026> this is what I was talking about, they fixed it but it was on some nut shit at first. pic.twitter.com/GO5Y9FCnYN 
<U+2014> <U+00E6>donis | hotep (@lordaedonis) November 8, 2016 
Voter turnout is very heavy all over the nation, and it looks like we may shatter voter participation records all over the nation. 
So that is a good thing. 
And we can get an idea of what voters are thinking by what they are searching for on the Internet <U+2026> 
When looking at searches of <U+201C>Who is ____ voting for,<U+201D> these names are the most popular: 
Taylor Swift

time: null 
 author: Jason Ditz 
 source: antiwar.com 
 text: Both Blame Other Side for Fueling Tensions Along Line of Control by Jason Ditz, November 01, 2016 Share This 
One villager in the area described the situation as like a <U+201C> full blown war, <U+201D> as Pakistani and Indian troops have exchanged a growing amount of fire across the Line of Control in Kashmir. The latest firing began on Friday and has continued to grow ever since. 
Both sides are accusing the other, as usual, of starting the situation, and civilians living along the LoC are being evacuated in growing numbers. Since Friday at least 24 people have been killed in the firing , with the majority of them civilian bystanders. 
This is the latest dust-up along the LoC since September, when militants attacked Indian forces within Kashmir and India responded with raids across the LoC, getting into fights with the Pakistani military on the other side. 
Both sides say the latest firing from the other side was <U+201C>unprovoked,<U+201D> though in reality tensions have been boiling under the surface ever since the September incidents. The focus right now appears to be entirely on shifting blame for starting the fighting, with neither side seeming at all eager to stop firing. Last 5 posts by Jason Ditz
