786.input:
time: null 
 author: Natalie Dickinson 
 source: occupydemocrats.com 
 text: Comments 
With Donald Trump obsesses over Hillary Clinton<U+2019>s e-mail <U+201C>scandal<U+201D>, one wonders why he never mentions the Bush Administration and the April 12, 2007 revelation that the White House had <U+201C>lost<U+201D> 5 million e-mails related to an investigation into the partisan firing of eight U.S. attorneys . Eventually, the true number was found to be over 22 million e-mails. 
Salon reports that: 
The emails had been run through private accounts controlled by the Republican National Committee and were only supposed to be used for dealing with non-administration political campaign work to avoid violating ethics laws. Yet congressional investigators already had evidence private emails had been used for government business, including to discuss the firing of one of the U.S. attorneys. The RNC accounts were used by 22 White House staffers, including then-Deputy Chief of Staff Karl Rove, who reportedly used his RNC email for 95 percent of his communications. 
According to the Washington Post, <U+201C>Under federal law, the White House is required to maintain records, including e-mails, involving presidential decision- making and deliberations.<U+201D> But, of course, these millions of e-mails went missing <U+2014> many of which were important evidence. 
Most troubling, researchers found a suspicious pattern in the White House email system blackouts, including periods when there were no emails available from the office of Vice President Dick Cheney. 
<U+2018><U+201C>That the vice president<U+2019>s office, widely characterized as the most powerful vice president in history, should have no archived emails in its accounts for scores of days<U+2014>especially days when there was discussion of whether to invade Iraq<U+2014>beggared the imagination,<U+201D> says Thomas Blanton, director of the Washington-based National Security Archive. The NSA (not to be confused with the National Security Agency, the federal surveillance organization) is a nonprofit devoted to obtaining and declassifying national security documents and is one of the key players in the effort to recover the supposedly lost Bush White House emails. 
As Rove and others were investigated for the partisan <U+201C>unmasking<U+201D> of Valerie Plame, a CIA black market specialist, it came to light that Rove<U+2019>s server was used for official communications <U+2014> the exact sort required to be preserved under the Presidential Records Act. 
<U+201C>I wouldn<U+2019>t rule out that there were a potential 5 million e-mails lost,<U+201D> White House spokeswoman Dana Perino said at the time. By 2009, it was revealed that Perino<U+2019>s numbers were a little off when 22 million missing e-mails were discovered. 
The partisan nature of this Clinton email investigation is obvious. How is it not relevant that an administration notorious for committing war crimes and crimes against humanity was able to delete millions of emails without a word from Congress? For all their so called concern for our national security, the Republican Party has an appalling double standard.

787.input:
time: null 
 author: Michael C. Bender 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/kaines-role-is-bolstered-by-his-popularity-at-home-1475457046 
 text: Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton introduced her running mate, Sen. Tim Kaine, as a future partner in the White House and hinted at an outsize role he may play in her potential administration. The former Virginia governor already is playing such a part in the campaign by energizing activists in his home state and helping the Clinton campaign save time and money in what once was a Republican stronghold. While Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s recent lead has tightened in other battleground states, she maintains an advantage in this swing state of about 9 percentage points, double the margin before she named Mr. Kaine to her ticket, according to a Real Clear Politics average of polls. <U+201C>There was a lot of excitement leading up to his selection, and the response has been overwhelming,<U+201D> Democratic state Sen. Jeremy McPike said. Mr. McPike said hundreds of supporters are planning a pilgrimage<U+00A0>on Tuesday<U+00A0>to Farmville, Va., where Mr. Kaine and his Republican counterpart, Indiana Gov. Mike Pence, will briefly eclipse the tops of their respective tickets during the only scheduled debate between the vice-presidential nominees. Vice-presidential candidates usually add little significant political value to their running mate<U+2019>s campaign. But it is unusual for a presidential candidate to select her No. 2 from such a consequential battleground as Mr.<U+00A0>Kaine<U+2019>s home state, said Kyle Kopko, co-author of <U+201C>The VP Advantage: How Running Mates Influence Home State Voting in Presidential Elections.<U+201D> <U+201C>There<U+2019>s never been anything this clear,<U+201D> Mr. Kopko said about the importance of the Kaine nomination on the electoral map. <U+201C>I just cannot think of anybody better to have by my side on the campaign trail, in the White House,<U+201D> Mrs. Clinton said about her running mate in July. <U+201C>We are going to take on the challenges that are hurting Americans. We are going to give the middle class a raise. We are going to give tax relief to working families.<U+201D> Even before his addition to the ticket, an influx of new voters had helped loosen Republicans<U+2019> hold on the Old Dominion. The arrival of Latino, Asian-American and college-educated voters to the state<U+2019>s northern suburbs near Washington, D.C., helped deliver the state to Barack Obama in 2008<U+2014>the first Democratic presidential nominee to win there since Lyndon Johnson in 1964<U+2014>and again in 2012. In 2013, Terry McAuliffe <U+2019>s victory in the governor<U+2019>s race gave Democrats control of all three of the statewide constitutional offices<U+2014>governor, lieutenant governor and attorney general<U+2014>and both U.S. Senate seats for the first time in more than 40 years. Still, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump is treating Virginia as a top priority. Either he or Mr. Pence have traveled to the state about once a week since the Republican National Convention in July. His campaign, along with some help from the National Rifle Association, aired about $3 million in TV ads in the state last month. <U+201C>Virginia is a very important state,<U+201D> Mr. Trump told supporters during a Sept. 6 campaign stop in Virginia Beach. <U+201C>We have to win.<U+201D> Corey Stewart, the chairman of Mr. Trump<U+2019>s campaign in Virginia, said the Republican<U+2019>s team will start advertising in the state soon. <U+201C>Virginia is a must-win state,<U+201D> Mr. Stewart said. <U+201C>Our ground game finally, since Labor Day, has started to coalesce. We got a bit of a late start, but it<U+2019>s going to be very strong.<U+201D> Mrs. Clinton, meanwhile, hasn<U+2019>t set foot in Virginia since her convention, spending her increasingly valuable time almost exclusively in Florida, North Carolina, Pennsylvania and Ohio. Her campaign suspended her TV advertising campaign in Virginia in August. Instead, Mrs. Clinton has leaned on visits by her surrogates. Chelsea Clinton, the former secretary of state<U+2019>s daughter, campaigned in Roanoke on Sept. 14. During a campaign stop last week in Fairfax, first lady Michelle Obama criticized Mr. Trump for questioning of her husband<U+2019>s U.S. citizenship and rallied young voters to get out to the polls on Election Day. Mr. Kaine, a fluent Spanish speaker, has been dispatched mostly to Florida, where the campaign is trying to run up the margins with Hispanic voters. But he has also campaigned around Virginia, making stops in Richmond, where he was mayor; in the Richmond suburb of Henrico County; and in Norfolk. He was in Alexandria last week when his campaign won the endorsement of Republican John Warner, a former U.S. senator who credited his three-decade relationship with Mr. Kaine as part of his reason to cross the partisan aisle. Mr. Warner spoke of Mr. Kaine in the kind of patriotic and religious tones usually reserved for fellow Republicans, saying he has a strong <U+201C>family tradition,<U+201D> that he follows <U+201C>church and God,<U+201D> and embodies <U+201C>the principles that have kept this country strong.<U+201D> <U+201C>He exemplifies what this country needs foremost,<U+201D> Mr. Warner told reporters. In Richmond, Mr. Kaine earned a reputation as a moderate for his votes to ban lap dancing and making it tougher to open adult bookstores, in addition to his support of some abortion restrictions. As governor, Mr. Kaine also pursued gun restrictions after the 2007 mass killings at Virginia Tech and won a smoking ban in restaurants. He specialized in housing discrimination lawsuits as a civil-rights lawyer, and he was selected mayor by a Richmond City Council that was mostly African-American. State Sen. Bryce Reeves, a Republican who is running for lieutenant governor, said Mr. Kaine understands the <U+201C>Virginia way of doing business<U+201D> and <U+201C>isn<U+2019>t the type of politician who throws grenades.<U+201D> <U+201C>But make no mistake about it, his colors are on the Clinton side,<U+201D> Mr. Reeves said, adding that that many Virginia Republicans were motivated to keep him out of the White House. <U+201C>Virginians are a microcosm of America, and they<U+2019>re very angry. And Trump has been the voice for those people, not Hillary Clinton.<U+201D> Virginia Democratic Party Chairwoman Susan Swecker said Mr. Kaine<U+2019>s nomination has increased enthusiasm in Virginia for a ticket that is struggling to energize supporters in other battleground states. She said there was a noticeable uptick in volunteers for phone banking and canvassing immediately after he was selected. <U+201C>Tim<U+2019>s attended the community festivals, the forums and we<U+2019>ve gotten to know him,<U+201D> said Walter Tejada, a Democratic consultant in Virginia. <U+201C>Democrats are excited, and even more energized than before.<U+201D> Write to Michael C. Bender at Mike.Bender@wsj.com

 text: 500 rape threats in 4 days: Female MPs face constant abuse <U+2013>... 500 rape threats in 4 days: Female MPs face constant abuse <U+2013> report By 0 41 
Death threats and sexual harassment against female politicians are rife and eating away at democracy, according to a new international study of women MPs. 
A series of interviews with female MPs by the Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU) reveals that more than 40 percent had suffered death and rape threats, as well as intimations of physical violence or abduction, while serving in office. 
Read more 
Most abuse took place online and often included threats to their children also. 
One European MP claims to have received <U+201C>more than 500 threats of rape on Twitter<U+201D> over a mere four days. 
IPU Secretary General Martin Chungong admitted the survey was small but representative. 
<U+201C>It makes clear that the problem is much more widespread and under-reported than we realize,<U+201D> he said. 
<U+201C>The parliamentary community must speak out against sexism and harassment and make clear that it cannot be tolerated as the price to be paid for women<U+2019>s political involvement.<U+201D> 
In May, British politicians launched the <U+2018>Reclaim the Internet<U+2019> campaign to challenge online abuse. 
The scheme came after Labour MP Jess Phillips claimed she once received 5,000 Twitter notifications with users debating whether or not they would sexually assault her. There were more than 600 direct rape threats, she said. 
Hampstead and Kilburn MP, Tulip Siddiq, said she too received regular online abuse including threats on her life. 
One-time Labour leadership hopeful Angela Eagle was the target of homophobic abuse after challenging Jeremy Corbyn earlier this year. Her Wallasey constituency office was also vandalized when someone threw a brick through a window. 
Former Prime Minister David Cameron was once accused of sexist behavior towards Eagle after he told her to <U+201C>calm down, dear<U+201D> during a Commons debate. 
<U+201C>If a woman speaks loudly in parliament, she is <U+2018>shushed<U+2019> with a finger to the mouth. That never happens when a man speaks loudly,<U+201D> a European parliamentarian interviewed by the IPU said. 
Read more 
The IPU study also showed that more than one in five of all politicians quizzed has experienced sexual violence during their term, and one in three had witnessed attacks on colleagues in parliament. 
Almost 80 percent said they had been psychologically abused, causing them to suffer panic attacks or permanent trauma. 
According to the IPU report, female politicians <U+201C>said they must constantly deal with old-school thinking about their appearance, how they express themselves and behave, and the role they should play.<U+201D> 
<U+201C>More generally, their excessively or insufficiently feminine demeanour is a subject of regular and widespread comment, attacks and derision. The same is true of their conjugal status, emotional, sexual and family life, imagined or real,<U+201D> it added. 
Despite this, the majority of women surveyed said the abuse would not stop them from running for another term in office. 
<U+201C>Parliaments need to put their own house in order if they want to lead by example and stop discrimination and violence against women in all walks of life,<U+201D> said Chungong. 
<U+201C>The effectiveness of parliaments, progress toward equality between men and women and the vitality of democracy itself all depend on it. 
<U+201C>The parliamentary community must speak out against sexism and harassment, and make clear that it cannot be tolerated as the price to be paid for women<U+2019>s political involvement.<U+201D> 
Via RT . This piece was reprinted by RINF Alternative News with permission or license.

 author: Marc Caputo 
 source: http://www.politico.com/states/florida/story/2016/10/clinton-leads-by-4-and-rubio-by-6-in-new-florida-poll-106836 
 text: Rep. Patrick Murphy listens as Sen. Marco Rubio answers a question during their Senate debate. | AP Photo/Wilfredo Lee By Marc Caputo 10/27/16 07:21 PM EDT Florida voters appear ready to ticket-split in favoring Democrat Hillary Clinton for president and Republican Sen. Marco Rubio in his reelection, according to a new survey of likely voters from the University of North Florida. In the presidential race, Clinton leads Donald Trump 43-39 when Libertarian Gary Johnson (6 percent) and Green Party candidate Jill Stein (3 percent) were polled by UNF. But Clinton<U+2019>s 4-point lead shrinks to 2 in a head-to-head matchup against Trump. That<U+2019>s well within the 3.8 error margin for the poll of 696 likely voters. Story Continued Below <U+201C>There is almost no change from our poll in early October in which Clinton led Trump by three percentage points, 41<U+2013>38, in the four-way contest, but the head-to-head results have tightened considerably,<U+201D> said Dr. Michael Binder, faculty director of UNF<U+2019>s Public Opinion Research Laboratory. Though Republicans and Democrats each were exactly 40 percent of the poll respondents, Binder wondered if the final election will bring out slightly more Democrats because they<U+2019>re turning out in bigger numbers than usual and casting more early and absentee ballots relative to this point in the election. As of Wednesday morning, 2.5 million people had already voted, with Republicans still holding an edge over Democrats in ballots cast. Republicans accounted for about 41 percent of the pre-Election Day ballots cast compared to the Democrats 40.5 percent. Usually, Republicans have a bigger lead because their voters are more accustomed and adept at casting absentee ballots by mail. But Democrats are catching up and, after this upcoming first full weekend of in-person early voting, many expect the total number of Democratic ballots to exceed Republican ones. <U+201C>If this trend continues through Election Day, Clinton could expand this margin and easily win Florida,<U+201D> Binder said. Most Florida polls this month have shown Clinton ahead. A Bloomberg Politics<U+2019> survey released Wednesday showed Trump winning by 2 points. Unlike the UNF poll that had the same number of Democratic and Republican respondents, the Bloomberg survey had more Republicans than Democrats. But Rubio appears as if he might survive. He leads Congressman Patrick Murphy, 49-43 percent. And he has yet to trail in a Florida poll in months. <U+201C>Rubio is maintaining his six percentage point lead from our poll earlier in the month. Rubio can attribute his lead to support from NPAs and more Democrats willing to cast a ballot for him than Republicans are for Murphy,<U+201D> Binder said. UNF also polled a medical-marijuana initiative and found it received 73 percent support. <U+201C>This is down four percentage points from our last poll, but still well above the 60 percent threshold needed for passage. Interestingly, and just like in our last poll, all age groups and parties support Amendment 2,<U+201D> Binder said. Marc Caputo's must-read briefing on what's hot, crazy or shady about politics in the Sunshine State.

790.input:
time: null 
 author: Ben White Jack Shafer 
 source: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/11/stocks-plunge-trump-2016-presidential-election-231016 
 text: Futures and the peso sank fast as odds maintained by the New York Times swung hard toward a potential Donald Trump win.  | AP Photo Dow opens slightly higher after overnight plunge. By Ben White 11/08/16 10:53 PM EST Updated 11/09/16 10:36 AM EST NEW YORK -- Wall Street regained some of its footing Wednesday morning after Donald Trump<U+2019>s shocking victory in the presidential race sent global markets into a tailspin in the overnight hours. The Dow opened slightly higher then rose around 150 points by mid-morning as investors and traders attempted to digest a political thunder clap with potentially enormous ramifications for the U.S. and global economy. Story Continued Below The New York Stock Exchange took technical steps on Wednesday to try and smooth potential volatility while officials at the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Reserve were closely monitoring trading following the most shocking presidential upset in American history. Trump<U+2019>s remarkable sweep to victory sent stock market futures down by as much as 800 points overnight while the Mexican peso suffered some of its worst ever losses and gold and the Japanese yen soared as investors rushed to safety. But as the initial shock wore off, futures began to recover as Wall Street began to look for positives in Trump presidency including on infrastructure spending and potential individual and corporate tax relief. Trump<U+2019>s low-key victory speech early Wednesday morning also served to calm markets somewhat. Still, investors now expect a period of intense volatility given the emotional nature of the 2016 campaign and the blank slate that a Trump win and complete GOP control of Congress present. <U+201C>My overriding take from the Trump victory is that he has made uncertainty great again,<U+201D> said Douglas Kass, founder and president at Seabreeze Partners. <U+201C>We are going to see intra-day volatility for the next couple of weeks and maybe even longer because there is so much uncertainty about his policies and the degree of cooperation he will get from Congress. His leadership skills and ability to appoint high-quality people are also totally unknown. This is going to be a very emotional time.<U+201D> Donald Trump's full remarks on the election night. 11/09/16 04:24 AM EST As of 11:30 a.m., the Dow, S&P 500 and Nasdaq stock market indices were all slightly higher. Action in the Treasury market suggested uncertainty over the short-term outlook as yields on short-term debt dropped while longer-term yields rose. This appeared to suggest that investors believe Trump will pursue a spending agenda on infrastructure and tax cuts that will require more government borrowing. Investors also looked for positives in the stocks of banks and biotechnology companies that might have suffered under a stricter regulatory regime under a potential Clinton presidency. But investors suggested any kind of Trump rally on Wall Street will likely have to wait until more is known about how he will govern. <U+201C>Investors don<U+2019>t like uncertainty and Trump<U+2019>s presidency embodies uncertainty,<U+201D> BMO Private Bank<U+2019>s Jack Ablin wrote in a note to clients. <U+201C>Emotions will dominate market action over the next several trading days, potentially leading to exaggerated market swings. Foreign markets, particularly China, Japan and Mexico will bear the brunt of investor angst.<U+201D> Market strategists also suggested that Trump<U+2019>s win could cause the Federal Reserve -- widely expected to raise interest rates in December as wages rise and unemployment falls -- to rethink its policy position. <U+201C>While the Fed is independent and therefore does not consider political developments in its rate decisions, it does consider the economic implications of political developments,<U+201D> Manulife Asset Management<U+2019>s Megan Greene wrote in a note on Wednesday. <U+201C>Given the high degree of policy uncertainty and the heightened probability of a US recession under a Trump presidency, we expect the Fed will not hike rates this year.<U+201D> The initial losses on Wall Street following Trump<U+2019>s win came after a big rally Monday as polls appeared to suggest Clinton would cruise to victory. The panic selling initially resembled reaction to the Brexit vote over the summer when the UK shocked pundits by choosing to leave the European Union. As with Brexit, most on Wall Street underestimated the degree to which voters angry with elites and the status quo would take a risk on a candidate that exit polls showed most voters viewed as far less prepared for the White House than Clinton. That left investors badly exposed to the shocking election result. <U+201C>Investors got caught on the wrong foot as the Orange Swan appeared,<U+201D> said Kass, referring to Trump<U+2019>s signature hair color and the <U+201C>Black Swan<U+201D> theory of markets in which widely unexpected events shatter people<U+2019>s view of the world. By Bill Scher By Thomas Wright By Joshua Zeitz By Jack Shafer

 text: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio met with President-elect Donald Trump for more than an hour at Trump Tower Wednesday, saying afterward he told the Republican that many New Yorkers were afraid of his presidency. <U+201C>I let him know that so many New Yorkers are fearful, that more had to be done to show that this country can heal, and that people will be respected,<U+201D> Mr. de Blasio, a Democrat, said outside the Midtown Manhattan tower. Mr. de Blasio, who supported Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton , has long been critical of Mr. Trump , describing him as <U+201C>dangerous<U+201D> and unfit to lead the country. Last year, Mr. Trump called Mr. de Blasio <U+201C>the worst mayor in the U.S.<U+201D> On Wednesday, aides to the mayor said he met alone with the president-elect for 62 minutes in an office on the 26th floor of Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue. Mr. de Blasio described the meeting with Mr. Trump as <U+201C>candid<U+201D> and <U+201C>respectful.<U+201D> A spokeswoman for Mr. Trump didn<U+2019>t respond to a request for comment. The mayor said he <U+201C>tried to provide perspective of the NYPD,<U+201D> as he expressed concerns about Mr. Trump<U+2019>s plans on immigration, telling him deportations would cause a rift between communities and law-enforcement that would make the city less safe. Mr. de Blasio said he told Mr. Trump the city was <U+201C>never going back<U+201D> to the widespread use of the policing tactic known as stop-and-frisk, an approach Mr. Trump has said should be expanded but that critics say unfairly targets minorities. Former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani, a close ally of Mr. Trump who is said to be under consideration for secretary of state , said New Yorkers had nothing to fear. <U+201C>They shouldn<U+2019>t be afraid. They should realize a Trump presidency will make the country safer,<U+201D> Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, said in a phone interview Wednesday. <U+201C>Maybe if they did a little more stop-and-frisk [across the country] they wouldn<U+2019>t have somebody shot every two hours in Chicago.<U+201D> Mr. Giuliani said if Mrs. Clinton had won the presidency, <U+201C>there<U+2019>d be a lot of Republicans that would be afraid of what she would do.<U+201D> <U+201C>I think you have to give the man a chance,<U+201D> he said. Outside Trump Tower on Wednesday, as dozens of tourists and reporters waited outside, aides to Mr. de Blasio said the mayor met alone with the president-elect in an office for 62 minutes. In the days since Mr. Trump<U+2019>s election, Mr. de Blasio has said he would greet the Republican with an open mind and work with him where they had areas of agreement, such as building infrastructure. But he said he would vigorously oppose any of the president-elect<U+2019>s policies he believed hurt New Yorkers. <U+201C>I would be swift to react any time an action was taken that would undermine the people of New York City,<U+201D> he said. As Mr. de Blasio emerged from his meeting with Mr. Trump to dozens of waiting reporters and tourists, he was asked whether he was concerned that security around the tower made it difficult for nearby retailers to do business. <U+201C>I will not tell you that Gucci and Tiffany are my central concerns in life,<U+201D> the mayor quipped in response. The mayor said he would hold a news conference with the police commissioner on Fifth Avenue security on Friday. Write to Mara Gay at mara.gay@wsj.com

 text: By Louis Nelson 10/17/16 09:58 AM EDT Donald Trump<U+2019>s inability to connect with the Hispanic community and anti-illegal immigration rhetoric have put the Manhattan billionaire in a massive hole with Latino voters with just weeks to go until Election Day. An NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll completed last week shows Hillary Clinton with a 50-point lead over Trump among Hispanic likely voters, 67 percent to 17 percent, in a four-way race that also includes Libertarian Gary Johnson and the Green Party<U+2019>s Jill Stein. In a head-to-head matchup with Johnson and Stein removed, Clinton leads Trump 70 percent to 17 percent among Latinos likely to vote. Story Continued Below Trump has struggled to connect with Hispanic voters from Day One of his presidential campaign, when he suggested in his kickoff speech that undocumented immigrants from Mexico were rapists and drug dealers. Trump later suggested that a federal judge could not fairly hear a case against him because of his Hispanic heritage, a remark that House Speaker Paul Ryan referred to as the <U+201C>textbook definition of a racist comment.<U+201D> More recently, Trump defended his past remarks about former Miss Universe Alicia Machado, who the Republican nominee mocked as <U+201C>Miss Piggy<U+201D> because of her supposed weight gain and <U+201C>Miss Housekeeping<U+201D> because of her Hispanic heritage. As Election Day draws closer, Latino respondents to the NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll said they are growing more interested in the White House race. Sixty-nine percent of Hispanic respondents said they are very interested in the presidential election, a 9 percent increase from a poll taken last month. Just 13 percent of Latinos polled said they view Trump favorably, compared with 80 percent who view him unfavorably. The NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll was conducted from Oct. 10-13, contacting 300 Latino registered voters with a margin of error of plus or minus 5.66 percent. Of that group, 255 were determined to be likely voters, with a margin of error of plus or minus 6.14 percent. By Bill Scher By Joshua Zeitz By Thomas Wright By Jack Shafer

797.input:
time: null 
 author: Christine Branch 
 source: occupydemocrats.com 
 text: Comments 
Democrats are better for the economy. This statement is not an opinion, but a fact. According to economist Steven Stoft, who created a series of graphs charting job creation under each party over the last 72 years (during which time Democrats and Republicans have held control for 36 years each), Democrats have created 58 million jobs while Republicans can only claim 26 million . 
For roughly the last century, electing a Democrat has been the better option for the economy, with Dems creating more than double the jobs than that of Republicans, and faster. 
Even when taking the percent change of number of jobs held, or scaling population (to avoid counting an increased population, thus falsely indicating an increase in jobs), Democrats still prove more successful than Republicans in job creation, and by a wide margin. 
Another way of studying job creation is to take unemployment into account. When a Democrat is in the White House, logically unemployment decreases as well. By this rational, of course, when a GOP takes the Oval Office unemployment rises (and has risen under this party) since 1945. 
Indeed, this extends to state and federal levels<U+2014>the top 20 years of national GDP growth have all been under a Democrat. This is not only true for GDP, but for all economic growth in general<U+2014>extending to the stock market, income growth and debt as a percentage of GDP. 
As if you needed more proof that the blue party is better for the economy, simply turn to the numbers over the last 70 years. When it comes time for Election Day, it<U+2019>s a matter of fact that with every Democratic ballot cast, it<U+2019>s almost guaranteed the country will be in a better economic position than if a Republican is sworn in.

798.input:
time: null 
 author: Richard Rubin 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/hillary-clinton-targets-tax-hikes-at-the-very-top-1475863171 
 text: The top-earning 1% of U.S. households<U+2014>and especially the top 0.1%<U+2014>have a lot to lose from Hillary Clinton <U+2019>s tax proposals. The Democratic presidential nominee would concentrate her tax agenda on fewer than 1.5 million households by adding layers of taxation and sealing gaps that let some of their earnings get taxed relatively lightly. She would impose the highest marginal tax rates on top earners since the 1986 revamp of the tax code and boost taxes on business income, investments and estates. She would cap tax breaks while targeting a series of narrower tax-avoidance and -deferral techniques used in the real-estate and private-equity industries. The Democrat sees having the rich pay more as a way to pay for tax breaks and expanded benefits for middle-income families, and she has said households earning less than $250,000 wouldn<U+2019>t see a tax increase. Her proposals add up to about $1.9 trillion in tax increases over a decade, according to the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget. Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s tax proposals, and those of her rival, Republican Donald Trump, are likely to be discussed in Sunday<U+2019>s second presidential debate. She has argued for using the tax system to combat rising inequality, and she returned to that argument in a new ad after Mr. Trump in the first debate said it was <U+201C>smart<U+201D> that he hadn<U+2019>t paid taxes in some years. Mr. Trump has pitched deep tax cuts and a repeal of the estate tax, and he told Mrs. Clinton at the first debate, <U+201C>You are going to drive business out.<U+201D> The Clinton tax plan would advance nearly all of President Barack Obama <U+2019>s unfinished business on taxing high-income households. Then she would adopt Sen. Bernie Sanders<U+2019>s structure for a higher estate tax and tack on a few ideas of her own, such as a 4% surcharge on income over $5 million. More so than the current tax code or Mr. Obama<U+2019>s proposals, Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s policies are targeted specifically at the ultrawealthy. <U+201C>This is skewed very, very heavily toward the top end,<U+201D> said Howard Gleckman, a senior fellow at the Tax Policy Center, a project of the Brookings Institution and the Urban Institute. <U+201C>It<U+2019>s<U+2026>a little bit like shooting a mouse with a machine gun. She really is designing this so it<U+2019>s very hard to avoid tax on your income at the very top.<U+201D> Overall, Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s proposal would add about 4% to federal tax collections over the next decade and push taxes as a share of the economy higher but not past the post-World War II peaks. But the brunt of that impact would fall on a sliver of the population, with nearly 80% of the higher taxes hitting the top 1% of households and more than half hitting the top 0.1%, according to the<U+00A0>Tax Policy Center. The center, using a broader definition of income than is shown on tax returns, sets about $732,000 in annual household income as being in the top 1% and $3.8 million for the top 0.1%. The Tax Policy Center analysis doesn<U+2019>t yet include her most recent proposals, such as taxing unrealized capital gains at death and implementing a 65% tax on estates exceeding $500 million a person. Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s proposals, even if she were elected, would face strong resistance in Congress, where Republicans are almost assured of retaining control of at least the House and where Democrats haven<U+2019>t acted on some of the ideas Mr. Obama tried to advance. The share of U.S. income earned by the top 1% has roughly doubled over the past 30 years, according to estimates by economist Emmanuel Saez and others. The top 1% now get about 17% of the nation<U+2019>s income before taxes and pay 28% of federal taxes as a result of the progressive tax code, according to the Tax Policy Center. That is in part the result of changes Mr. Obama pushed through Congress, which the<U+00A0>White House says<U+00A0>increased average tax rates on the top 0.1% of households by nearly seven percentage points. Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s proposed tax increases, in combination with tax breaks for parents, caregivers and people with out-of-pocket health care costs, would make the U.S. even more reliant on high-income taxpayers than it is now. A proposal to impose a minimum 30% tax rate on households with incomes over $2 million would prevent people from paying low tax rates by getting the majority of their money from investments. Another change would apply the 3.8% tax created in the 2010 health law to active business income. The repeal of what is known as the step up in basis would tax appreciated assets when given as gifts during life or death, applying the income tax in a place it doesn<U+2019>t reach now. Mrs. Clinton also could also use rules, Internal Revenue Service enforcement priorities and narrower proposals to Congress to go after arcane tax-avoidance techniques. <U+201C>Whenever we see them, we are attacking specific loopholes in the tax code,<U+201D> said Michael Shapiro, an economic policy adviser to Mrs. Clinton. Other than the changes in taxation at death, Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s plans don<U+2019>t do much to address the ways wealthy Americans can increase their net worth without reporting taxable income, said Gabriel Zucman, an economist at the University of California, Berkeley. <U+201C>There<U+2019>s a big disconnect between taxable income and the real income of rich people,<U+201D> he said. <U+201C>That requires more fundamental reform of taxation than adding four points on the top bracket.<U+201D> Her proposals send the campaigns back into longtime arguments: What happens to the economy when you cut taxes at the top? Republicans see the growth in the 1980s and the late 1990s growth after capital gains rate cuts as proof that people are more willing to save, work and invest if they can keep more of what they earn. <U+201C>When the pie is as large as possible, then you have the least questions about the distribution of that pie,<U+201D> said Donald Luskin, chief investment officer at Trend Macrolytics. <U+201C>We<U+2019>re not having a serious economically driven conversation about this. We<U+2019>re just having a populist appeal.<U+201D> Democrats and other analysts point to the economic expansions after the 1993 and 2013 tax increases as proof that those links between top tax rates and growth are tenuous at best. <U+201C>When you look at periods of extremely strong growth in the United States, there was a tax system that was more progressive than what we<U+2019>re proposing,<U+201D> Mr. Shapiro said. Write to Richard Rubin at richard.rubin@wsj.com

time: null 
 author: Jameson Parker 
 source: ifyouonlynews.com 
 text: Google Pinterest Digg Linkedin Reddit Stumbleupon Print Delicious Pocket Tumblr 
Just one week before America decides whether or not to elect Donald Trump, one of his supporters decided to help get his message out by torching a black church and defacing its wall with the words <U+201C>Vote Trump.<U+201D> 
<U+201C>When firefighters arrived at Hopewell Missionary Baptist Church Tuesday night, they found it in flames, and the Vote Trump slogan written in silver spray paint on the outside wall of the church,<U+201D> Mark Rigsby of Mississippi Public Broadcasting reports. 
<U+201C>Greenville Mayor Errick Simmons calls this a hate crime <U+2014> an attempt to frighten voters just days before the presidential election.<U+201D> 
Trump has yet to condemn the attack, or even mention it. 
Mississippi has been the host of many decades of violence directed at African Americans. During the Jim Crow era, acts of terror committed against black Mississippians was disturbingly common. It seems for at least one Trump supporter, the term <U+201C>Make American Great Again<U+201D> means returning to that dark time. 
But rather than let this disgusting display of intolerance be the story, Americans got to work. In just hours, a verified GoFundMe account was set up by concerned citizens and thousands of dollars began to pour in to help rebuild. 
It<U+2019>s goal was to raise $10,000. It likely wouldn<U+2019>t be enough to repair all of the damages inside and outside of the church, but it would be a start. Instead, people gave over $150,000. And perhaps even more remarkably, the entire world appeared ready to reject the deplorable racism and bigotry that led to this act. The campaign<U+2019>s organizer updated the campaign by saying that people from all faiths (and none at all) and many countries have contributed: 
Responses have been pouring in from all over the world, and they<U+2019>re truly extraordinary. Christians, Muslims, Jews, Hindus, atheists and many more, from all over the United States and many other countries. 
And according to GoFundMe<U+2019>s VP of Communications and Policy Dan Pfeiffer, this campaign is perhaps the fastest growing in the history of the site. This one right here is verified and one of our fastest growing history https://t.co/E4smWW2s7d https://t.co/xIQWY4ulsV 
<U+2014> Dan Pfeiffer (@danpfeiffer) November 3, 2016 
A slogan that has often been used to counter Trump<U+2019>s message of cynical bigotry comes to mind: Love trumps hate. 
Featured image via GoFundMe

#Cannabis is Non Toxic but #Monsanto will make it toxic by making a GMO version. #SaveCannabis #VoteNoOn64

Altogether, the deals are bigger than the largest single acquisition in the history of Scotts Miracle-Gro, which takes in $160 million of profit on $3 billion in sales annually.

804.input:
time: null 
 author: ERIC LICHTBLAU STEVEN LEE MYERS 
 source: https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/18/us/politics/hillary-clinton-emails-fbi.html?_r=0 
 text: WASHINGTON <U+2014> Documents released Monday in the Hillary Clinton email investigation show intense disagreement last year between the State Department and the F.B.I. over whether some of Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s emails should be considered classified, including a discussion of a possible <U+201C>quid pro quo<U+201D> to settle one dispute. The new batch of documents indicated that in one particular case, a senior State Department official, Patrick F. Kennedy, pressed the F.B.I. to agree that one of Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s emails on the 2012 Benghazi attack would be unclassified <U+2014> and not classified as the bureau wanted. What remained unclear from the documents was whether it was Mr. Kennedy or an F.B.I. official who purportedly offered the <U+201C>quid pro quo<U+201D>: marking the email unclassified in exchange for the State Department<U+2019>s approving the posting of more F.B.I. agents to Iraq. Officials at both the F.B.I. and the State Department said Monday that no deal had been struck, or even offered, over the classification of Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s private emails. They noted that the Benghazi email in question had been made public with a sentence blocked out, meeting the F.B.I.<U+2019>s demand for classification. They also said no additional F.B.I. agents had been posted overseas. There is no indication from the documents that Mrs. Clinton was aware of the discussion. Donald J. Trump and other Republicans nonetheless quickly seized on the new documents as evidence of what Speaker Paul D. Ryan called <U+201C>a cover-up.<U+201D> The F.B.I.<U+2019>s latest release of 100 pages of internal investigative files prolonged the intense public scrutiny of Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s use of a private email server as secretary of state, which has been perhaps more damaging to her presidential campaign than any other issue. The new documents also cast particular attention on the role of Mr. Kennedy, a State Department civil servant for more than four decades, in working to oversee the review and public release of tens of thousands of Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s private emails. One of the F.B.I. reports said State Department employees who reviewed nearly 300 of Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s emails on the Benghazi attacks in early 2015 in response to requests from Congress had <U+201C>felt intense pressure<U+201D> from Mr. Kennedy and other senior State Department officials to complete their review quickly and <U+201C>not label anything as classified.<U+201D> Mr. Kennedy was part of a long-running battle between the State Department and the intelligence agencies over Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s emails. As the emails were prepared for release, officials from the intelligence agencies argued in some cases that information in them should have been marked classified, while State Department officials countered that they contained the routine business of American diplomacy. State Department officials, who argue that the intelligence agencies are overzealous in classifying information, remain sensitive to criticism that they were sloppy in handling the material. In one of the newly disclosed documents, an unidentified F.B.I. employee told investigators that Mr. Kennedy, through another F.B.I. official, had sought in one case <U+201C>assistance in altering the email<U+2019>s classification in exchange for a <U+2018>quid pro quo.<U+2019><U+201D> The F.B.I. had deemed the email classified, but the State Department disagreed. The employee told investigators that <U+201C>in exchange for marking the email unclassified, State would reciprocate by allowing the F.B.I. to place more Agents in countries where they are presently forbidden,<U+201D> according to the F.B.I.<U+2019>s summary of the employee<U+2019>s questioning by investigators. A second F.B.I. interview included in the documents provides a somewhat different version of the dispute over the classification of the Benghazi email, with the suggestion that the F.B.I. <U+2014> and not Mr. Kennedy <U+2014> had offered to make a deal. In the interview, an unidentified F.B.I. official in the international operations division said Mr. Kennedy had complained to him that the F.B.I. classification of the document <U+201C>caused problems for Kennedy<U+201D> and that Mr. Kennedy had wanted to give it a different designation and file it in the State Department basement <U+2014> <U+201C>never to be seen again.<U+201D> The unidentified F.B.I. official said he was the one who then <U+201C>told Kennedy he would look into the email matter if Kennedy would provide authority concerning the F.B.I.<U+2019>s request to increase its personnel in Iraq.<U+201D> The email they were struggling over was sent on Nov. 18, 2012, by William V. Roebuck, who oversaw the department<U+2019>s office for North Africa and is now the American ambassador to Bahrain. In it, he notified five other officials of the arrest of <U+201C>several people<U+201D> in Libya on suspicion they were connected with the Benghazi attack two months earlier. It was subsequently forwarded to senior officials at the department and then to Mrs. Clinton on her private email account by her deputy chief of staff, Jake Sullivan, with a short <U+201C>f.y.i.<U+201D> note. Mark C. Toner, a State Department spokesman, said that no favors had been exchanged in the discussions of Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s emails, and that there had been no change in the number of agents in Iraq as a result of the conversations. <U+201C>The allegation of any kind of quid pro quo is inaccurate and does not align with the facts,<U+201D> Mr. Toner said. The F.B.I. also said there was <U+201C>never a quid pro quo,<U+201D> but it said the accusations had been referred to the bureau<U+2019>s inspection division, which handles internal ethics issues, to investigate. The F.B.I. official who discussed the issue with Mr. Kennedy has since left the bureau, an official said. One of Mr. Trump<U+2019>s foreign policy advisers, Michael T. Flynn, a retired general who headed the Defense Intelligence Agency, said the documents provided <U+201C>undeniable proof<U+201D> that Mrs. Clinton had <U+201C>colluded with the F.B.I., D.O.J. and State Department to cover up criminal activity at the highest levels.<U+201D> Two prominent members of the House <U+2014> Jason Chaffetz of Utah, the chairman of the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, and Devin Nunes of California, the chairman of the Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence <U+2014> called on Secretary of State John Kerry to relieve Mr. Kennedy of his position pending an investigation. In a letter to Mr. Kerry, they accused Mr. Kennedy, the State Department and the F.B.I. of collusion. They charged that the State Department had altered its normal process in reviewing Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s emails, consulting directly with the Justice Department and bypassing the F.B.I.<U+2019>s input. A spokesman for Mr. Trump<U+2019>s campaign, Jason Miller, said Mr. Kennedy should resign. Mr. Toner said Mr. Kennedy would remain in his position with the full support of Mr. Kerry. After the email issue emerged in March 2015, Mrs. Clinton insisted for months that she had never sent or received emails that contained classified information. But she was forced to backtrack, as the F.B.I. concluded this summer that at least 110 emails had contained classified information, even if they had not been marked as such at the time. Correction: October 20, 2016 Because of an editing error, a headline on Wednesday about a former F.B.I. official at the center of the latest controversy over Hillary Clinton<U+2019>s private emails referred incorrectly to comments he made about his involvement. While he said he did in fact offer to trade favors with the State Department about an email classification issue last year, he also said that he quickly dropped the offer once he realized it involved the 2012 Benghazi attacks and Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s emails. He did not admit to a <U+201C>quid pro quo<U+201D> specifically over Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s emails. Find out what you need to know about the 2016 presidential race today, and get politics news updates via Facebook , Twitter and the First Draft newsletter . A version of this article appears in print on October 18, 2016, on Page A1 of the New York edition with the headline: Agencies Split on Classifying Clinton Emails.  text: "Apprentice producer says they have more & worse. So why not release in 2015? In March? Why wait till October?" Cruz tweeted. | Getty In late-night phone calls, Cruz deliberated with advisers about how to deal with the release of a lewd Trump tape. By Katie Glueck and Brent Griffiths 10/09/16 06:53 PM EDT Updated 10/09/16 06:51 PM EDT ST. LOUIS <U+2014> For Ted Cruz, the timing couldn<U+2019>t have been worse. Two weeks after Cruz offered a reluctant and belated endorsement of Donald Trump, the Republican nominee had finally gone too far for the rest of the party. Following the release of a lewd tape in which Trump was overheard bragging about sexually assaulting women, a cascade of Republican lawmakers were jumping ship. Story Continued Below But Cruz had just endorsed, and risked further shredding the reputation he has long sought to cultivate <U+2014> that of a principled conservative <U+2014> by backtracking as soon as others in the party did, especially after upsetting a slice of his supporters by endorsing Trump in the first place. In phone calls with advisers Saturday that stretched well into the night, he debated whether to rescind his endorsement or to try simply changing the subject by going on offense against the media, according to a Cruz source with knowledge of the conversations. Cruz spokeswoman Catherine Frazier denied that there was discussion of any strategic pivot to attacking the media. Still, on Sunday morning, Cruz tweeted, <U+201C>NBC had tape 11 yrs. Apprentice producer says they have more & worse. So why not release in 2015? In March? Why wait till October? #MSMBias<U+201D> The question of whether to rescind the endorsement had been tabled. <U+201C>NBC had tape 11 yrs,<U+201D> Cruz tweeted. <U+201C>Apprentice producer says they have more & worse. So why not release in 2015? In March? Why wait till October? #MSMBias<U+201D> But while Cruz has thus far kept his endorsement in place, sources haven<U+2019>t ruled out the possibility of his eventually recalling it. The conversations broke up Saturday night with no conclusions reached, a source said. 2016 By John Bresnahan and Burgess Everett <U+201C>Access Hollywood,<U+201D> whose former host Billy Bush eggs on Trump in the video, began searching through its archives last week after an Associated Press story quoted former staffers and cast members from <U+201C>The Apprentice<U+201D> who said Trump was <U+201C>lewd and sexist.<U+201D> But before "Access Hollywood, which is owned by NBC, and the network<U+2019>s news division could run their stories, footage of Trump and Bush on a bus in 2005 was leaked to The Washington Post, and the story blew up on Friday. It broke exactly two weeks after Cruz finally endorsed Trump under considerable pressure from supporters and party leaders, after holding out all summer. Following a bitter primary fight in which Trump called Cruz<U+2019>s wife ugly and linked his father to John F. Kennedy assassination theories, Cruz spent months refusing to endorse Trump even as most of his party <U+2014> and certainly his supporters home in Texas <U+2014> got in line. At Trump<U+2019>s Republican National Convention, Cruz took the stage and urged attendees to vote their consciences, rather than support the man the delegates were there to nominate. But pressure mounted on Cruz following the convention and going into the post-Labor Day stretch. Republican activists back home were furious that their senator wasn<U+2019>t doing everything he could to prevent Hillary Clinton from being elected, and major donors had made their displeasure clear. In a move that several of his top advisers and friends opposed, Cruz issued a Facebook post on Sept. 23 in which the senator pointed to Trump<U+2019>s assurances that he would appoint conservative Supreme Court justices, and underlined his commitment to stopping Clinton. But since then, Trump<U+2019>s fortunes have taken a hit, and prior to the release of the lewd audio, Cruz found himself in the awkward position of boosting Trump following both a disastrous first debate performance and a week in which the GOP nominee spent much of his time feuding with a former Miss Universe. By Gabriel Debenedetti When the audio of Trump making deeply derogatory remarks about women, Cruz condemned the content. <U+201C>These comments are disturbing and inappropriate, there is simply no excuse for them,<U+201D> he tweeted. <U+201C>Every wife, mother, daughter <U+2014> every person <U+2014> deserves to be treated with dignity and respect.<U+201D> On the campaign trail, Cruz himself had taken issue with Trump<U+2019>s long history of denigrating remarks about women, and had often championed his own wife, Heidi <U+2014> a Goldman Sachs executive <U+2014> and his mother, who had a career as a computer programmer at a time when few women worked in that field. People who know Cruz said he was genuinely and deeply bothered by Trump<U+2019>s remarks. There may well be more cause to re-evaluate the endorsement: A former producer of Trump<U+2019>s reality-TV show tweeted that <U+201C>far worse<U+201D> is yet to come out about the Republican nominee. <U+201C>As a producer on seasons 1 & 2 of #theapprentice I assure you: when it comes to the #trumptapes there are far worse. #justthebegininng,<U+201D> Bill Pruitt tweeted on Saturday. Burgess Everett contributed to this report. By Bill Scher By Joshua Zeitz By Thomas Wright By Jack Shafer

806.input:
time: null 
 author: noauthor 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/consumer-choices-reflected-the-nations-political-divide-1480415404 
 text: The divides that emerged in the 2016 presidential campaign reach beyond the red and blue of the Electoral College map. They extend to the shopping, entertainment and lifestyle choices of each party<U+2019>s members. People in the counties where President-elect Donald Trump performed best are likely to watch Country Music Television and the Hallmark Channel. Those in the counties where Hillary Clinton did best tend to tune into HBO and Showtime. People in Mr. Trump<U+2019>s top counties prefer Samsung smartphones, while those in Clinton counties like Apple<U+2019>s iPhone. The Trump counties turn to Fox News for information, while Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s look to CNN and the New York Times . Pictures of the widely disparate consumer worlds of Trump and Clinton voters come from data provided by Simmons Research , a consumer-research firm, for the 25 counties where Mr. Trump drew the highest percentage of the vote and the 25 where Mrs. Clinton drew her largest shares of the vote. The data covered only counties with populations of 20,000 or more. To be sure, the data show correlations between political leanings and consumer habits, not causal behaviors. There are Trump voters who prefer CNN as a news source and Clinton voters frequently tune in to the Hallmark Channel. Much of the consumer divide is tied to the kinds of places Trump and Clinton voters tend to live. Some of the differences arise from geography<U+2014>some retail chains are more prevalent in Republican-leaning than Democratic states, for example.<U+00A0>Others reflect differences in income, population density and local culture between red and blue regions. <U+201C>The differences are astounding,<U+201D> said Tamara Barber, senior manager for custom analytics at Simmons. <U+201C>They are crystal clear. The levels of diversity. The size of the counties. Where they shop. There is not a lot of crossover.<U+201D> When they go for fast food, people in Trump<U+2019>s top 25 counties favor Sonic Drive-In or Hardee<U+2019>s, while those in Clinton<U+2019>s top 25 prefer Chipotle and Panera Bread. The differences are reflected in leisure activities, as well. Mr. Trump<U+2019>s top counties are partial to archery and woodworking, while Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s counties lean toward yoga and martial arts. The racial diversity and other demographic characteristics of Trump and Clinton counties vary widely. Among Mr. Trump<U+2019>s top 25 counties, only one has a white, non-Hispanic population below 70%. Among Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s top 25, only one had a white, non-Hispanic population above 70%. In none of Mr. Trump<U+2019>s 25 counties did 30% of the adult population have a bachelor<U+2019>s degree, while in 18 of Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s top 25 counties, more than 30% of the adult population has a bachelor<U+2019>s. The Clinton counties also tend to feature higher incomes and bigger populations. Manhattan, San Francisco and Washington, D.C. are all on the list of places that gave Mrs. Clinton the largest share of their votes, while Mr. Trump<U+2019>s contain a collection of smaller, mostly Southern counties, such as Winston County, Ala., and Gray County Texas. As niche marketing and segmentation have come to dominate consumer culture, America<U+2019>s political divides are tied to ground-level differences that may make it harder to create political unity.<U+00A0>Coming up with a message to reach both the Trump and Clinton counties is a difficult challenge, Ms. Barber said. <U+201C>I<U+2019>d say you need to have very different strategies for these two groups, maybe different products,<U+201D> she said. John Besmer, a principal at Planet Propaganda, an advertising firm in the swing-state of Wisconsin, said he sees some chances to bridge the divide. <U+201C>I don<U+2019>t think people wake up thinking, <U+2018>I want to be an awesome Democrat today.<U+2019> People are all seeking happiness,<U+201D> he said. He said, however, that the people living in the top Trump and Clinton counties could have very different ideas of what makes happiness. A few activities seem to draw equal interest both from Trump and Clinton counties, the Simmons data suggest. Among them: playing football and bowling. And more than 60% in both groups say they enjoy listening to music. Just don<U+2019>t ask what<U+2019>s playing in their headphones. Trump<U+2019>s counties favor country and western. Clinton<U+2019>s like urban adult contemporary. Write to Dante Chinni at Dante.Chinni@wsj.com

807.input:
time: null 
 author: JANE PERLEZ 
 source: https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/25/world/asia/donald-trump-china-trade-security.html?_r=0 
 text: BEIJING <U+2014> As a presidential candidate, Donald J. Trump talked about China almost solely in the context of trade, such as when he promised to slap punishing tariffs on cheap Chinese imports that he argued had ruined the lives of working-class Americans. But as he begins to feel the weight of office on his shoulders, there are signs that his focus in the Asia region may have shifted toward security <U+2014> specifically, the problem of North Korea and its expanding nuclear arsenal, which experts say already threatens America<U+2019>s regional allies, Japan and South Korea. During his visit to The New York Times this week, Mr. Trump referred obliquely to a <U+201C>big problem for the country<U+201D> that President Obama had mentioned during their 90-minute meeting at the White House after the election. Well-placed American officials believe that reference was to North Korea. Any solution to that problem must involve China, North Korea<U+2019>s patron, American and Chinese officials agree. Mr. Trump acknowledged as much during the campaign, saying on one occasion that China should do more to bear down on the North. So which tack will Mr. Trump take with China? Will he seek its support for a deal on North Korea, or will he start a trade war, putting such cooperation in doubt? American officials briefed the Chinese several months ago on their assessment that the North <U+2019>s nuclear capabilities had sharply increased , according to two Americans with knowledge of the briefings, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the matter. But even before then, nuclear scientists from China and the United States had agreed for some time about the danger posed by the North<U+2019>s ambitions, said Siegfried S. Hecker, an American nuclear scientist at Stanford University who was the last outsider to visit the country<U+2019>s plutonium processing plant at Yongbyon, in November 2010. Several years ago, the Chinese tended to play down the North<U+2019>s nuclear capabilities, Dr. Hecker said in an email exchange. But since the mercurial Kim Jong-un, a young leader who has declined to listen to China and has provoked the United States, took over the country, the assessments of the two powers have been <U+201C>pretty much in line,<U+201D> he said. Dr. Hecker and other scientists estimate that North Korea might develop the capacity to strike the West Coast of the United States with a nuclear warhead in about five years. But the real problem is here and now, in Asia, he said. <U+201C>The greatest and most urgent threat comes not from a North Korean nuke being able to reach the U.S., but rather what they have already,<U+201D> he said. Specifically, Dr. Hecker wrote in a recent article , the North is now probably able <U+201C>to put nuclear weapons on target anywhere in South Korea and Japan and even on some U.S. assets in the Pacific.<U+201D> Worse yet, he wrote, North Korea may have developed a <U+201C>false sense of confidence<U+201D> from a recent spate of successful nuclear and missile tests <U+2014> one that could lead it to grave errors of judgment. By the end of this year, Dr. Hecker estimated, the country is likely to have enough fissile material for about 20 bombs. The danger would be exacerbated if the North decided <U+201C>to field tactical nuclear weapons as its arsenal expands and its confidence in its nuclear arsenal grows.<U+201D> In short, Dr. Hecker said, more and better bombs make a catastrophic miscalculation by North Korea more likely. How much of this Mr. Trump knew before his victory is unclear, but he was certainly aware of the problem. Early on, he expressed a mixture of awe and dismay toward Mr. Kim. <U+201C>If you look at North Korea, this guy, I mean, he<U+2019>s like a maniac, O.K.?<U+201D> he said at a rally in Ottumwa, Iowa, in January. <U+201C>And you<U+2019>ve got to give him credit. How many young guys <U+2014> he was like 26 or 25 when his father died <U+2014> can take over these tough generals?<U+201D> Mr. Trump was referring to Mr. Kim<U+2019>s execution of several generals, including his uncle, Jang Song -t haek , who was the main conduit between North Korea and China. <U+201C>We can<U+2019>t play games with him,<U+201D> Mr. Trump said at the time, referring to Mr. Kim. <U+201C>Because he really does have missiles, and he really does have nukes.<U+201D> Such considerations <U+2014> and briefings that Mr. Trump presumably has received or will receive on the North<U+2019>s capabilities <U+2014> could compel the new president to prioritize security over trade in his dealings with China. With the right approach, he could find a willing partner in Beijing, said Yang Xiyu, a former Chinese official who oversaw the so-called six-party talks on the North<U+2019>s nuclear program that collapsed in 2008 . But Chinese officials say that approach would require removing a thorn in Beijing<U+2019>s side: an advanced missile defense system that the United States plans to install in South Korea. The Chinese view that system, known as the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense System, as an effort to contain its ambitions in Asia, though Washington and Seoul say it is intended purely to defend South Korea against the North. In the past year, China has rebuffed many of Washington<U+2019>s requests for sharper measures against North Korea, and the missile system is one reason. Whether Mr. Trump would consider scrapping it is another unknown. Washington and Beijing did cooperate on United Nations sanctions against the North this year <U+2014> an encouraging sign, analysts said, though many doubt that economic punishment alone will be a deterrent. And on Friday, the Chinese state-run news media reported that Beijing would support a new round of sanctions being considered by the Security Council that would close loopholes allowing North Korea to sell coal. Mr. Yang, the former official, said the Trump administration must take into account Beijing<U+2019>s worst fear, where the North is concerned: a collapse of Mr. Kim<U+2019>s totalitarian regime, followed by refugees from the North pouring into China and a unified Korean Peninsula under the protection of the American military. As president, Mr. Trump must understand that Mr. Kim<U+2019>s government has to stay, Mr. Yang said. <U+201C>Remove the bombs, not the regime, is the key to a peaceful solution,<U+201D> Mr. Yang said. If the United States shares that goal, he said, <U+201C>we can cooperate sincerely and substantively.<U+201D> Yufan Huang contributed research. A version of this article appears in print on November 26, 2016, on Page A14 of the New York edition with the headline: Will Trump Rethink a China Showdown?. Order Reprints | Today's Paper | Subscribe

 author: Natalie Dickinson 
 source: occupydemocrats.com 
 text: Comments 
Legendary Star Trek actor turned LGBT activist George Takei has been very vocal this election season. He joins much of America in being so utterly appalled by Republican nominee Donald Trump that he cannot stay silent as Trump unravels our democracy further and further with each passing day, and has a perfect response to those asking him to stop being so negative: People have asked me to tweet something positive about Trump. Okay, so be it: I am POSITIVE that Trump is a national disgrace. 
<U+2014> George Takei (@GeorgeTakei) October 28, 2016 
There is nothing positive to be said about Trump, except that the revelations of his long record of sexual assault is creating a national conversation about the abuse of women at the hands of powerful rich white men. 
Otherwise, Trump has been a walking manifestation of the ugliest parts of America, exposing our dirty laundry for all the world to see. Perhaps its what we needed to exorcise those demons <U+2013> but it cannot be denied that it will take years to recover from the wounds this election has opened.

809.input:
time: null 
 author: Riva Gold Corrie Driebusch 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/banks-insurance-stocks-lead-markets-higher-bond-yields-rise-1479458257 
 text: Major U.S. stock indexes retreated Friday as the election-fueled rally moderated this past week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite all posted weekly gains that were smaller than those just after the election. The Dow industrials, for example, added 0.1% after the previous week<U+2019>s 5.4% rise was its best since 2011. The more-muted moves masked some sector shifts. <U+201C>The movement in the overall market really belies the turbulence that<U+2019>s been going on below the surface,<U+201D> said Jack Ablin, chief investment officer at wealth manager BMO Private Bank. The blue-chip index slipped 35.89 points, or 0.2%, on Friday to 18867.93 as investors<U+2019> rush into industrial companies abated. Such firms helped boost the Dow industrials after Donald Trump<U+2019>s election sparked expectations of infrastructure spending. The S&P 500 slipped 5.22 points, or 0.2%, on Friday to 2181.90 but was up 0.8% over the week. Financials continued to rise, buoyed by bets on rising interest rates and loosened regulation after the election, adding 2.2% for the week. Through Friday<U+2019>s close, the S&P 500 was up 2% from the Nov. 8 election. Excluding financials, the S&P 500 would be up 0.6% in that period, according to S&P Dow Jones Indices. Health-care stocks, some of the best performers right after the election, pulled back. The sector was the biggest decliner of the week in the S&P 500, shedding 1.2%. Biotechnology companies had jumped as some investors expected drug-pricing restrictions would be less likely under Mr. Trump than they would have been under Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton. The Nasdaq Biotechnology Index rose 14% for the week ended Nov. 11, and followed that with a weekly loss of 1.1%. In the days immediately following Mr. Trump<U+2019>s win, shares of large technology companies tumbled and the performance gap between the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite and the Dow industrials widened. From the close on Nov. 8 through Nov. 14, Amazon.com <U+2019>s stock dropped 8.7%. In recent sessions, however, these companies<U+2019> shares have rebounded slightly. Amazon.com<U+2019>s stock closed the week up 2.9%. Tech stocks in the S&P 500 rose 1% for the week, and the Nasdaq Composite posted a 1.6% weekly gain. Early Friday, the Nasdaq hit a new intraday high before pulling back. The index fell 12.46 points, or 0.2%, on Friday to 5321.51. Oil companies also were big gainers as crude prices rebounded. U.S. crude for December delivery increased 5.3% during the week to $45.69 a barrel, snapping a three-week losing streak , as hopes grew that major oil producers would reach agreement to cut output. In the week ended Nov. 16, financial, health-care, biotechnology and industrials sector funds all registered new weekly inflow records, as did U.S. equity funds, while emerging-market bond funds had their biggest-ever outflow, according to Cameron Brandt, global director of research at fund-tracker EPFR Global. <U+201C>Investors are just looking at what<U+2019>s in front of them today: The economy is improving, U.S. interest rates are going to be rising, and we<U+2019>ll get some infrastructure spending next year<U+2014>that<U+2019>s a very positive message in the short term,<U+201D> said Colin Graham, chief investment officer at BNP Paribas Investment Partners . Earnings reports swung some individual stocks Friday. Abercrombie & Fitch <U+2019>s stock fell $2.33, or 14%, to $14.60 after it posted its third consecutive quarter of declining same-store sales. Gap<U+2019>s stock declined 5.10, or 17%, to 25.61 as the apparel maker reported a drop in quarterly profit . Write to Riva Gold at riva.gold@wsj.com and Corrie Driebusch at corrie.driebusch@wsj.com

time: null 
 author: Chelsey Dulaney 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/dollar-rises-as-investors-await-central-bank-meetings-u-s-election-1477924001 
 text: The dollar slipped Monday as investors weighed U.S. economic data, upcoming central-bank meetings and the looming U.S. presidential election. The WSJ Dollar Index, which measures the U.S. currency against 16 others, was recently down 0.1% to 88.55. The British pound rose 0.5% to $1.2245 after Bank of England Gov. Mark Carney said he would remain in his post until 2019. Investors are watching economic data closely for signs that the U.S. economy is strong enough to handle an interest-rate increase this year. Data out Monday was mixed. A report showed that consumer spending rose a better-than-expected 0.5% in September, a sign of resilience among households amid steady job creation. Separately, a report measuring business activity in Chicago fell to a five-month low in October. The Federal Reserve will release its latest interest-rate decision at the close of its two-day meeting on Wednesday, but few expect the central bank to raise borrowing costs ahead of the Nov. 8 presidential election. <U+201C>The Fed will be closely watched given expectations that the Fed will signal its intent to hike rates in December,<U+201D> wrote analysts at TD Securities in a research note. <U+201C>We look for changes to the language that indicate <U+2018>further evidence<U+2019> of progress but do not expect an explicit discussion of a hike next month.<U+201D> Fed-funds futures, a popular tool for betting on central-bank policy, show that investors assign a 73% likelihood of a rate increase in December, according to CME Group data. Analysts say the next test for the dollar will be Friday<U+2019>s U.S. jobs report, which many see as the best read on the health of the U.S. labor market. The Japanese yen slipped ahead of the Bank of Japan <U+2019>s policy announcement, expected overnight. Expectations for further stimulus are muted. The dollar was up 0.1% to <U+00A5>104.8. The Mexican peso rebounded 0.6% against the dollar after data showed the Mexican economy expanded in the third quarter. The peso sold off sharply Friday after new evidence in the investigation of Hillary Clinton <U+2019>s emails cast uncertainty on the U.S. presidential election. The Mexican currency has been highly vulnerable to developments in the election as investors worry that Republican candidate Donald Trump <U+2019>s plans to build a wall between the two countries and to renegotiate trade agreements could damage Mexico<U+2019>s economy. Write to Chelsey Dulaney at Chelsey.Dulaney@wsj.com

811.input:
time: null 
 author: Telis Demos 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/which-tech-ipo-has-surged-1-271-it-isnt-who-you-think-1479734191 
 text: The best-performing IPO of a U.S. technology company since the financial crisis doesn<U+2019>t make electric cars or run a social network<U+2014>it sells mortgage software, but it has taken a tumble in the aftermath of the U.S. election. Ellie Mae Inc. <U+2019>s shares have gained 1,271% since an initial public offering in 2011, outpacing the likes of Tesla Motors Inc., Facebook Inc. and LinkedIn Corp. among U.S. listings. Its customers are the small mortgage lenders that have surged in the past five years thanks to low interest rates and big banks<U+2019> pullback from the housing market. But with the election victory of Donald Trump and a Republican sweep of both houses of Congress, that period may be coming to an end<U+2014>along with Ellie<U+2019>s days as a highflying stock. Mortgage rates have started rising , and investors are betting that big banks may soon be unshackled from some of the most onerous regulations and poised to recapture market share for mortgages. Ellie Mae<U+2019>s shares have dropped 23% since the election, while bank stocks and broader stock-market benchmarks have rallied. The Pleasanton, Calif., company was founded in 1997 by Sig Anderman and Limin Hu. It attracted investment from venture-capital funds and mortgage-industry giants including Fannie Mae. (Unlike other <U+201C>Mae<U+201D> firms, Ellie Mae has no relationship to the U.S. government. The name is a shortening of <U+201C>Electronic Mortgage Affiliates.<U+201D>) The company<U+2019>s software automates the mortgage process by helping a lender collect and compile appraisals, titles, income history and other documents. Customers pay monthly subscription fees of about $75 per user, plus additional fees for loans beyond a certain volume or other services and data. That software plus the resurgence of independent mortgage companies and a new boom in home lending, sparked by historically low rates, lifted Ellie Mae<U+2019>s business and stock. <U+201C>It was the perfect trifecta to drive growth,<U+201D> said Saket Kalia, an analyst at Barclays PLC. The stock is now reacting to the rise in 10-year U.S. Treasury yields since Election Day, Mr. Kalia said. <U+201C>One part of the story has arguably changed,<U+201D> he said. But he also cautioned that new home purchases weren<U+2019>t as rate sensitive as refinances. Like its customers, Ellie Mae was hit hard by the collapse of the housing market in 2008. Its founders slashed costs dramatically, but then filed to go public in 2010 as it sought to raise capital to expand a new software business focused on lenders, rather than brokers. At the time, few new investors were willing to bet much on a housing recovery. The IPO priced at $6 a share, despite aiming to sell for as much as $11. That left its initial market value below $150 million, requiring it to switch its listing from the New York Stock Exchange<U+2019>s big board to the junior market. Ellie Mae<U+2019>s shares started rising in 2012, allowing the company to move up to the NYSE big board. The company quickly gained dominance among the many small nonbank lenders. Ellie Mae<U+2019>s stock closed Friday at $82.26, and its market value now stands at $2.76 billion. Nonbank lenders account for more than half of all home loans , up from less than 10% in 2009, according to Inside Mortgage Finance. The majority of them are small players, which are more likely to outsource technology. Now, however, events may be moving against Ellie Mae, with rising rates depressing mortgage-refinancing volumes, and the potential loosening of some new rules that have forced many small firms to upgrade their processes. <U+201C>The election results are great for the old-line phone and fax originators,<U+201D> said Vishal Garg, founder of online mortgage firm Better Mortgage Inc. <U+201C>But it doesn<U+2019>t change the fact that [consumers] want something different from a mortgage company.<U+201D> Before the election, Ellie Mae had already been forecasting higher mortgage rates that could cut refinancing volume even as home purchases increased, said Chief Executive Jonathan Corr. Under looser regulations, Mr. Corr said, there would still be market pressure to adopt stringent lending guidelines that software is needed to manage. And banks might buy more mortgages from smaller lenders who are Ellie Mae customers rather than make more loans on their own. <U+201C>We<U+2019>re still going through a secular change to embracing automation,<U+201D> Mr. Corr said. <U+201C>We can still grow 25% a year for the foreseeable future.<U+201D> Write to Telis Demos at telis.demos@wsj.com
