930.input:
time: null 
 author: Josh Dawsey 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/bill-de-blasio-goes-his-own-way-1477258456 
 text: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio solicits the opinions of many confidants before making decisions. Then he often disregards their counsel, forging ahead in ways that his inner circle sometimes describes as politically imprudent. This year, Mr. de Blasio, a Democrat, has sought to curtail the horse-carriage industry , escalated a fight with one of the city<U+2019>s most prominent newspapers and declined to release his emails with five longtime advisers who work outside of government<U+2014>all positions that many in his inner circle oppose. <U+201C>If he<U+2019>s convinced he<U+2019>s making the right decision, he won<U+2019>t back down,<U+201D> said Karen Hinton, a former press secretary to Mr. de Blasio who left the administration in June . <U+201C>Depending on your perspective, it<U+2019>s his best or worst quality.<U+201D> According to people close to him, Mr. de Blasio, 55 years old, often bristles when aides disagree with him, and some of them said they have never worked for a more stubborn person. Mr. de Blasio has told those close to him that they are giving him conventional wisdom or listening too much to his critics, these people said, and should instead focus on the <U+201C>mission,<U+201D> or what he calls his administration<U+2019>s work. Eric Phillips, who succeeded Ms. Hinton as press secretary, said Mr. de Blasio has a <U+201C>clear-eyed vision<U+201D> to improve the city. <U+201C>He won<U+2019>t compromise that mission by conforming to some outdated or past mayor<U+2019>s concept of the job,<U+201D> Mr. Phillips said. Earlier this month, Mr. de Blasio called the New York Post a <U+201C>right-wing rag<U+201D> and <U+201C>a negative presence in our city<U+201D> and declined to answer questions from the news outlet. Some of his advisers have winced at the fight, saying they don<U+2019>t believe Mr. de Blasio benefits from attacking the newspaper. The mayor has told allies that print media is fading, social media is rising and that people will agree with his criticisms of the Post. Asked for comment, a spokeswoman for the Post referred to the newspaper<U+2019>s front page earlier this month depicting the mayor as a baby crying in a high chair. The Post and The Wall Street Journal are both owned by News Corp. In September, two media outlets sued the mayor over his administration<U+2019>s decision not to release emails between Mr. de Blasio and five advisers. People close to Mr. de Blasio have recommended releasing the emails, but the mayor has doubled down, with aides and lawyers huddling at Gracie Mansion earlier this month to discuss fighting the lawsuit. <U+2018> If he<U+2019>s convinced he<U+2019>s making the right decision, he won<U+2019>t back down. <U+2019> The mayor<U+2019>s trip last winter to Iowa to campaign for Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, even though he wasn<U+2019>t invited by Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s campaign, was widely opposed by his advisers. Many of the mayor<U+2019>s allies disagreed with Mr. de Blasio<U+2019>s 2015 decision to delay his endorsement of Mrs. Clinton for six months. Mr. de Blasio told his allies he wanted to push Mrs. Clinton to the left and he coveted a bigger voice on the national stage. He said this month he had <U+201C>no regrets,<U+201D> even as leaked emails from Mrs. Clinton<U+2019>s campaign showed some of her aides were frustrated by the mayor<U+2019>s actions. This year, the mayor<U+2019>s aides mocked Mr. de Blasio<U+2019>s proposed limits on horse carriages, according to emails reviewed by the Journal. Even after the proposal fell through, Mr. de Blasio told aides he wanted to try to revive it, drawing resistance from some of his staff. On many mornings, Mr. de Blasio travels from Gracie Mansion on Manhattan<U+2019>s Upper East Side to a gym in Brooklyn, a 12-mile midmorning trip that has attracted protests and has become the subject of jokes around City Hall among people close to the mayor. Mr. de Blasio has said he has no plans to change his gym routine. Those close to Mr. de Blasio said the mayor<U+2019>s governing approach is deeply rooted in his experience working for former Mayor David Dinkins in the 1990s and his own come-from-behind victory in the 2013 mayoral race. Have something to say about an article in Greater New York? Email us, along with your contact information, at gnyltrs@wsj.com . Letters will be edited for brevity and clarity. Please include your city and state. Mr. de Blasio believes Mr. Dinkins was unfairly attacked as a liberal Democrat. In 2013, as a candidate for mayor, Mr. de Blasio shunned all sorts of advice as he floundered early on in the polls during the primary . Bill Hyers, Mr. de Blasio<U+2019>s 2013 campaign manager, said many people urged Mr. de Blasio to change course during the primary. But Mr. de Blasio <U+201C>stuck to his guns, stayed disciplined on the change and inequality message<U+201D> and ultimately won, Mr. Hyers said. To the dismay of some close to him, the mayor has said he isn<U+2019>t interested in attending events his predecessors have traditionally gone to<U+2014>such as parties in Manhattan<U+2014>if he doesn<U+2019>t believe they jibe with his ideological mission or if he disagrees with their corporate sponsors. <U+201C>Whether you like the mayor<U+2019>s politics or not,<U+201D> said Mr. Phillips, the mayor<U+2019>s spokesman, <U+201C>we think New Yorkers respect that he<U+2019>s not trying to be anything other than himself.<U+201D> Write to Josh Dawsey at joshua.dawsey@dowjones.com

932.input:
time: null 
 author: Thomas Gryta 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/in-reply-to-fcc-at-t-says-zero-rating-benefits-consumers-1479767200 
 text: AT&T Inc. Monday said its practice of exempting its own streaming video services from data-usage caps for its wireless customers complies with the law and benefits consumers, in a response to concerns from a federal regulator. The Federal Communications Commission sent a letter to AT&T almost two weeks ago over worries the practice, known as zero-rating, <U+201C>may obstruct competition and harm consumers.<U+201D> <U+201C>These initiatives are precisely the kind of pro-consumer challenges to cable that the Commission heralded in approving AT&T<U+2019>s acquisition of DirecTV,<U+201D> wrote Robert Quinn, AT&T<U+2019>s policy chief, in a letter to the agency Monday. AT&T acquired satellite-TV operator DirecTV last year. The Dallas telecom giant, which agreed to buy Time Warner Inc. for $85.4 billion last month, began zero-rating its DirecTV video app in September. Mr. Quinn said nearly three million consumers used the app in the first four weeks after its launch. AT&T plans to offer the same treatment for its over-the-top service DirecTV Now launching this month. The FCC contends the practice could deter consumers from accessing existing and future mobile video services not affiliated with AT&T. The company has said that it offers any company that wants to be zero-rated the same payment terms available to DirecTV. An FCC spokesman said the agency is reviewing the response and declined to comment further. The agency sent the letter a day after President-elect Donald Trump <U+2019>s victory and last week Republican congressional leaders asked the FCC to stop taking controversial regulatory actions until the new administration is on board. That suggests that the FCC may not be able to take any further steps on the AT&T matter. While critics regard zero-rating as a way of skirting net-neutrality rules that require internet-service providers to treat all traffic the same, AT&T said it <U+201C>faithfully adhered<U+201D> to those rules in starting the program, which is <U+201C>consistent with decades of commission precedent.<U+201D> Mr. Quinn said any FCC position to the contrary would be a <U+201C>radical departure from established law.<U+201D> AT&T began allowing companies to pay for zero rating in 2014, but so far no major streaming providers have done so. Verizon Communications Inc. doesn<U+2019>t charge its customers for data for its National Football League games or its go90 mobile video app. T-Mobile US Inc. <U+2019>s <U+201C>Binge On<U+201D> program allows any video provider to be exempt from data caps without paying the carrier, although the video is delivered at lower quality. It also allows customers and content companies to opt out. <U+2014>John McKinnon contributed to this article. Write to Thomas Gryta at thomas.gryta@wsj.com

933.input:
time: null 
 author: noauthor 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/watch-out-for-terrors-first-incubators-1480008041 
 text: The Nov. 12 suicide bombing at a NATO air base outside Kabul, Afghanistan, which killed four Americans, should remind President-elect Donald Trump of the need for a decisive victory in Afghanistan against jihadist extremism. Although Afghanistan was barely mentioned during the recent campaign, it is where the 9/11 attacks were planned and where the U.S. first went to war to eliminate global terrorism waged in the name of Islam. While Islamic State in the Middle East constitutes a compelling threat, Afghanistan, with Pakistan, remains the world<U+2019>s most-active incubator of terrorism. It is also where the next administration must learn from the errors of the past. During the George W. Bush administration, from the end of 2001 through 2008, there were 625 U.S. military fatalities sustained during the Afghanistan combat mission known as Operation Enduring Freedom, according to the Defense Casualty Analysis System in the office of the Secretary of Defense. By the end of that period, when Barack Obama was elected president, al Qaeda was presumed to have been considerably weakened and its remnants forced to relocate to other countries. The Taliban, now operating from havens in Pakistan, were deemed an irritant, not a serious challenge to U.S. or global security. In hindsight, what happened next was a strategic miscalculation. The Obama administration initially increased the number of U.S. troops stationed in Afghanistan with a <U+201C>surge<U+201D> intended to bolster Afghanistan<U+2019>s security forces while sending a message to Pakistan to crack down on Taliban sanctuaries on its side of a porous border. But in the first of several mistakes, the additional troops were sent into Afghanistan with a withdrawal timeline for U.S. forces. This led the Taliban and their Pakistani backers to believe they could sit out Mr. Obama<U+2019>s deadline for leaving their region. So instead of forcing the Taliban into surrender, the withdrawal timetable led to their resurgence. During the six years from the beginning of 2009 to the end of 2014, when the Operation Enduring Freedom combat mission officially ended in Afghanistan, the Defense Department reported 1,761 American military fatalities<U+2014>more than double the number killed during seven years of the Bush administration. Another key mistaken belief was that the U.S. and NATO allies could train an Afghan army and other security forces within a few years before leaving the country. Afghan soldiers showed courage in fighting the Taliban, but they still needed competent and experienced commanders, which take decades to produce. For this plan to work would have required the retention of U.S. advisers, if not large numbers of American field fighters. For that reason alone, the December 2016 deadline set by Mr. Obama for withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan could not be met. Another presumption, inherited from the Bush administration, was that in dealings with Pakistan, incentives such as economic and military aid, and reimbursements for expenses incurred in fighting terrorists, would change Pakistan<U+2019>s strategic calculus from backing the Taliban. Yet nuclear-armed Pakistan sees itself very differently from how the world does. For the generals in Islamabad, and many civilian leaders, Pakistan<U+2019>s competition with India justifies breaking promises with the U.S. and continuing support for jihadist terrorism, from the Taliban to the Haqqani network, as part of its plans for regional influence to match India<U+2019>s. So $21 billion in funding under the Obama administration could not change Pakistan, just as $12.4 billion given to Pakistan under the Bush administration failed to shut down its terrorism incubators. Under President Obama, the U.S. did manage to hunt down Osama bin Laden in his safe house in Pakistan, without Pakistan<U+2019>s permission. The Trump administration will have to embrace similar unilateralism if and when needed, in addition to the almost inevitable downgrading of Pakistan from its current status as a major non-NATO ally. But getting Pakistan policy right<U+2014>including a review of the predicates for any aid<U+2014>remains the key to U.S. victory in Afghanistan. Until the rise of ISIS in Syria and Iraq, Afghanistan and Pakistan were the principal training grounds for Islamist terrorists. Virtually all of the al Qaeda terrorists convicted in Britain since 2001, including the July 7, 2005, London Underground bombers and Dhiren Barot, the so-called <U+201C>Dirty Bomber,<U+201D> got trained in Pakistan. Former French Investigating Magistrate Jean-Louis Bruguiere observed in his 2009 book, <U+201C>What I Could Not Say,<U+201D> that almost every terrorist apprehended by European security services over the last two decades has either studied and trained or passed through Afghanistan or Pakistan. Currently ISIS is vying with al Qaeda-linked groups for recruits in Afghanistan and Pakistan. The rise of global jihadism was made possible by America<U+2019>s preoccupation with current news while the Soviet bloc crumbled during the first couple of years of the 1990s. This time, the U.S. should not ignore the Afghanistan-Pakistan theater because the brutalities of ISIS, and its proximity to Europe, are the immediate cause of concern. Mr. Haqqani, the director for South and Central Asia at the Hudson Institute in Washington, D.C., was Pakistan<U+2019>s ambassador to the U.S. from 2008-11.

 text: 45 Views October 28, 2016 GOLD , KWN King World News 
Today former U.S. Treasury Secretary, Dr. Paul Craig Roberts, warned about the Matrix of lies and exposed what the elite are about to do.

939.instruction:
You will be responsible for explaining the veracity of a particular news story. During this process, you will receive a news text material. Your task is to provide the label of the news without any explanation.

Here is the news text material:
939.input:
time: null 
 author: JESS BIDGOOD SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 
 source: https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/07/us/the-drama-down-the-ballot-2016s-other-wild-races.html?_r=0 
 text: Campaign 2016 is nearly over, to the relief of many Americans exhausted by the contentious, crazy and very consequential race between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump . But the year of outlandish politics is not limited to the top of the ticket. Consider these contentious, crazy and somewhat less consequential races. A tale of two Donalds, neither on the ballot The candidate is a self-funding billionaire and resort owner who vows to shake up the political establishment. He is accused of not paying taxes, and is not one to mince words. When his opponent ran an ad he did not like, he had this to say: <U+201C>That<U+2019>s complete dog snot!<U+201D> No, it is not Mr. Trump. The candidate is Jim Justice, a mining company executive and owner of the Greenbrier resort, now running as a Democrat for governor. And he is drawing unfavorable comparisons to a second Donald: Donald Blankenship, his fellow West Virginia coal baron. Like Mr. Blankenship, convicted this year of violating mine safety standards, Mr. Justice has also been accused of shoddy mine management. An investigative report by National Public Radio described him as <U+201C>the nation<U+2019>s top mine safety delinquent,<U+201D> and also found his companies owed $15 million in delinquent taxes and mine safety penalties <U+2014> allegations a spokesman for Mr. Justice dismissed as the product of <U+201C>the political silly season.<U+201D> Despite all of this, The Charleston Gazette endorsed him over Bill Cole, the Republican candidate and the president of the State Senate. But it was hardly a ringing endorsement. It called Mr. Justice <U+201C>the best of a questionable lot.<U+201D> Do you like your Tea (Party) organic? When is a Tea Party candidate not a Republican? When he runs as a Democrat. Pennsylvania<U+2019>s Ninth Congressional District, in the central and southwestern part of the state, has long been a safe Republican seat. Bud Shuster held it from 1973 to 2001; his son, Bill, has held the seat since then. That is more than four decades of single-family Republican control. Some members of the party <U+2014> including Art Halvorson, a retired Coast Guard captain who calls himself a <U+201C>conservative Christian, Tea Party-backed Republican<U+201D> <U+2014> are unhappy about this. Mr. Halvorson lost to Mr. Shuster in a primary, but 1,069 ticked-off voters wrote his name in on the Democratic side. So the Tea Party Republican is the Democratic nominee. <U+201C>I call it organic because I didn<U+2019>t even ask for it,<U+201D> Mr. Halvorson said , after the primary<U+2019>s surprise. Voters are confused. <U+201C>Some of Halvorson<U+2019>s own voters may abandon him, because they can<U+2019>t stomach voting for a Democrat,<U+201D> said David Wasserman, who tracks House races for the nonpartisan Cook Political Report. <U+201C>But he<U+2019>ll win some Democrats, who don<U+2019>t know he<U+2019>s a Tea Party candidate.<U+201D> Nine political lives, and counting A defense lawyer, Joseph D. Morrissey, 59, lost his law license for most of the 2000s after a series of reprimands and suspensions over ethics and conduct issues. And in 2014, Mr. Morrissey was sentenced to jail time <U+2014> he spent nights there for three months <U+2014> after having a sexual relationship with a teenager employed in his law office. The woman, now 20, became his wife. Mr. Morrissey, a former Virginia state lawmaker, is running for mayor of Richmond. He has been able to draw from a strong base of support among black and working-class voters, driven by his charisma and familiarity, and is a top contender in a crowded field. <U+201C>You start to say, my gosh, how does this guy keep coming out of the ashes?<U+201D> said Dan Palazzolo, a professor of political science at the University of Richmond. But accusations have piled up. Late last month, The Richmond Times-Dispatch reported that Mr. Morrissey was accused of exposing himself to a client of his law firm in February. (Mr. Morrissey said they exchanged <U+201C>flirtatious text messages<U+201D> but denied further impropriety.) And Democratic officials filed complaints against him over sample ballots mailed to voters by his campaign that seemed, erroneously, to suggest he is their preferred candidate. But Richmond<U+2019>s odd election rules could favor a candidate with localized support, which Mr. Morrissey has. A candidate must win five of the city<U+2019>s nine districts to declare victory on Election Day. If that does not happen, there is a runoff. <U+201C>It<U+2019>s astounding,<U+201D> Mr. Palazzolo said. <U+201C>He could be our mayor.<U+201D> 3.6 million YouTube views <U+2014> but how many votes? The wife of a candidate for county commissioner in Travis County, Tex., looked at the camera dryly as her husband nattered incessantly about details of county policy. <U+201C>Please re-elect Gerald<U+201D> to get him out of the house, pleaded Charlyn Daugherty. <U+201C>Please.<U+201D> It was a wink at the wonkiest kind of public service, and the video garnered millions of views on YouTube and Facebook, marking a surreal turn for an obscure local race. It was a strategic gambit for a down-ballot Republican in unfriendly territory, since Travis County, which contains Austin, is reliably Democratic. Before the ad, <U+201C>even people who vote for him couldn<U+2019>t point him out of a crowd,<U+201D> said Brandon Rottinghaus, a professor of political science at the University of Houston. Mr. Rottinghaus said early voting in Travis County has already smashed its record from 2012. The question now is whether Democratic voters will cross party lines for Mr. Daugherty. But if he loses, he can still talk politics with (or at) his wife. <U+201C>You know,<U+201D> he says in the ad, as she rolls her eyes, <U+201C>I think I like helping around the house here.<U+201D> The millionaire and the ex-beauty queen After a wealthy venture capitalist moved to Indiana and immediately began running for Congress, the big question echoed from The Indianapolis Star newspaper , like a rhyming couplet from Dr. Seuss: <U+201C>And, by the way, who is this new Hoosier who calls himself Trey?<U+201D> The new Hoosier is Joseph Albert <U+201C>Trey<U+201D> Hollingsworth III, 33, who grew up in Tennessee and is worth at least $58 million, according to the newspaper. Last year, he moved to Jeffersonville, Ind., and began lending himself nearly $2 million to run for the open seat in the reliably Republican Ninth District. Mr. Hollingsworth prevailed over a crowded field of primary opponents and is now up to $2.77 million in total loans. He faces Shelli Yoder, a former Miss Indiana and current council member in Monroe County, Ind., for the general election. The partisan demographics may help Mr. Hollingsworth, but Ms. Yoder has made it a close race by playing up the carpetbagger theme. <U+201C>It<U+2019>s a Hoosier District,<U+201D> reads Ms. Yoder<U+2019>s website, <U+201C>and it can<U+2019>t be bought.<U+201D> A gloves-off race It was a normal Beast Fest in Bladenboro, N.C.: The car show, the craft vendors, the Howl-O-Ween dog costume contest. But, the festival, as the local paper put it , <U+201C>brought out the beast in two attendees.<U+201D> The attendees in question? The Democrat, Tim Benton, and the Republican, Brenden Jones, running for the State House<U+2019>s 46th District, whose encounter ended in claims of fisticuffs. <U+201C>He sucker-punched me in the face,<U+201D> Mr. Jones told WLOX . Mr. Jones, who believes his opponent was angry about an advertisement comparing him to Mrs. Clinton, filed a criminal summons against Mr. Benton. Mr. Benton said he was falsely accused, and accused Mr. Jones in turn: <U+201C>He assaulted me, and I defended myself.<U+201D> No matter who wins their race, the two candidates could meet again <U+2014> in court. Find out what you need to know about the 2016 presidential race today, and get politics news updates via Facebook , Twitter and the First Draft newsletter . A version of this article appears in print on November 7, 2016, on Page A16 of the New York edition with the headline: The Drama Is Not Only at the Top of the Ballot. Order Reprints | Today's Paper | Subscribe

941.input:
time: null 
 author: Rob Taylor 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/australian-cattle-barons-make-counterbid-for-kidman-1477209591 
 text: SYDNEY<U+2014>Four of Australia<U+2019>s wealthiest farming barons have launched a counterbid to prevent Chinese investors from buying the country<U+2019>s largest cattle farm, S. Kidman & Co. The BBHO consortium<U+2014>comprising the families of influential Australian outback ranchers Tom Brinkworth, Sterling Buntine, Malcolm Harris and Viv Oldfield whose interests span livestock, grain and transport<U+2014>said on Sunday it had secured financing to offer 386 million Australian dollars (US$294 million) for 100% of Kidman<U+2019>s shares in what would be one of the country<U+2019>s biggest agribusiness deals on record. A spokesman for the consortium said the bidders have notified the S. Kidman board of their intentions and plan to formally lodge the offer <U+201C>within the next few days.<U+201D> The all-Australian bid trumps a rival offer by Chinese property conglomerate<U+00A0>Shanghai CRED Real Estate Stock Co. and mining billionaire Gina Rinehart, who teamed up earlier this month offering A$365 million for the vast farming operation which straddles an area larger than Ireland. <U+201C>We have developed a compelling and superior proposal to that recently supported by the Kidman board which will see Kidman 100% Australian owned,<U+201D> said Sterling Buntine, the spokesman for the BBHO consortium. Mr. Buntine said the new offer, unlike the rival bid, wouldn't require approval from the Foreign Investment Review Board, which advises the Australian government on corporate takeover bids from abroad. The regulators and Treasurer Scott Morrison earlier this year blocked an offer for Kidman headed by a China-based consortium, which would have put 80% of the century-old cattle empire in Chinese hands. At the time, the government said the deal wasn 't in Australia<U+2019>s interest , in a signal of rising official concern about offshore investment in the country<U+2019>s agricultural trophies. The Kidman cattle empire includes the world<U+2019>s largest cattle ranch: Anna Creek Station, located beside a strategic missile range. Farm takeovers by overseas investors have become increasingly sensitive in Australia, with some politicians opposing deals they say represent threats to food and water security at a time of rising global demand. Investment by China<U+2014>now the biggest investor in Australia<U+2019>s agricultural sector<U+2014>has become especially contentious. The BBHO consortium said on Sunday it wants to preserve the heritage and brand name of Sidney Kidman, who is a national icon in Australia. With leases stretching across four states and an average herd size of 185,000 cattle, the Kidman business is Australia<U+2019>s biggest beef producer, exporting to the U.S., Japan and Southeast Asia. The landholding went on sale almost 18 months ago. Mr. Buntine said the Australian bidders intend to maintain and expand a Kidman-branded cattle marketing and export operation, representing the families<U+2019> combined herd which is in excess of 500,000 cattle. <U+201C>The Kidman story and legacy of Sir Sidney Kidman is in the DNA of our cattle industry,<U+201D> Mr. Buntine said. <U+201C>This initiative would more than treble the size of the herd currently marketed under the Kidman name.<U+201D> Surging Chinese investment in housing and trophy agriculture assets is triggering a backlash in major economies from Europe to the U.S., as well as Australia. The government has repeatedly stated the country<U+2019>s openness to foreign, and specifically Chinese, investment, but Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has faced pressure from within his conservative coalition and from fringe lawmakers to oppose any foreign farm takeovers. The government blocked last year an offer from Shanghai Pengxin Group Co. of China to buy Kidman outright, arguing that the deal covered too much land, which also overlapped the Woomera missile test range. In May, Treasurer Scott Morrison ruled that an offer from China-based Dakang Australia Holdings and Australian Rural Capital Ltd. was against the national interest. In August, Canberra blocked two rival bidders ,<U+00A0>from Hong Kong and mainland China, from taking a controlling stake in Ausgrid, the country<U+2019>s largest electricity network. The state government of New South Wales said Thursday that it had agreed to lease the Ausgrid network to two Australian pension funds for A$16 billion. Write to Vera Sprothen at vera.sprothen@wsj.com and Rob Taylor at rob.taylor@wsj.com

time: null 
 author: Austen Hufford 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/home-depot-sales-and-revenue-rise-as-customers-spend-more-per-transaction-1479209406 
 text: Home Depot Inc. on Tuesday posted continued sales growth in its third quarter, another indicator that the housing market continues to grow. Shares, which have fallen 6.9% over the past three months, rose 1.6% to $129.65 in premarket trading. For 2016, the company now projects earnings per share of $6.33, adding to its previous guidance by two cents. It continues to expect sales to increase 6.3%. The Atlanta-based company has continued to report rising sales as the housing market grows and Americans become increasingly willing to spend on home-improvement projects. Superlow mortgage rates have kept higher prices within reach of many borrowers and prices have shot up in many U.S. housing markets over the past couple of years. But Donald Trump <U+2019>s victory has led to a surge in bond yields and, in turn, mortgage rates, potentially impacting housing prices . Mr. Trump has also made increasing infrastructure investments over the next decade one of his first priorities as president, potentially boosting companies like Home Depot. During the most recent quarter, sales at Home Depot stores open at least a year grew 5.5%. Analysts were expecting 4.5% growth. In all, Home Depot reported a profit of $2 billion, or $1.60 a share, up from $1.73 billion, or $1.35, a year prior. Revenue climbed 6.1% to $23.15 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had projected earnings of $1.58 a share on $23.04 billion in sales. At the quarter<U+2019>s end, Home Depot operated 2,276 retail stores in all 50 states, Canada and Mexico. The company<U+2019>s sales per square foot rose 4.3% as the amount the average customer spent rose 3%. Write to Austen Hufford at austen.hufford@wsj.com Corrections & Amplifications: Home Depot reported its third quarter Tuesday. An earlier version of this article incorrectly stated it reported its second quarter

 text: Originally appeared at Anti-Media 
As Russia and the United States approach arguably the most dangerous crossroads in history <U+2014> and as Western media continues to crucify Russia for its actions within Syria <U+2014> a closer look at the rationale Putin used for intervening in the Syrian war paints a sane explanation of how we ended up at this juncture of a global conflict. 
Unsurprisingly, the explanation comes from the Russian president himself and was actually offered over 3 years ago. As expected, the Western corporate media and the Obama administration chose to ignore Vladimir Putin<U+2019>s explanation for Russia<U+2019>s stance on Syria and continued a number of policies that have completely exacerbated the conflict. 
In a live interview with RT in June 2013, Putin was asked for an explanation regarding Russia<U+2019>s support for Bashar al-Assad in Syria, even though this support has made some people very angry at Russia. Putin<U+2019>s response was that Russia does not support the Assad government or Assad himself, but before defining Russia<U+2019>s official position, he explained what Russia does not want to do within Syria or across the Middle East: 
<U+201C>We do not want to interfere into the internal schism of Islam, between Shias and Sunnis. These are internal issues of the Islamic world. We have very good relations with much of the Arabic world, Iran for example, and others.<U+201D> 
However, according to Putin, what worries Russia can be identified by having a look <U+201C>at what is going on in the Middle East in general.<U+201D> 
<U+201C>Egypt is not calm. Iraq is not calm <U+2013> and it is not assured in its continued existence as one state. Yemen is not calm; Tunisia is not calm. Libya is witnessing inter-ethnic, inter-tribal conflict. So the entire region has been engulfed, at a minimum, into a state of conflict and undecidedness. And now Syria, down the same path.<U+201D> 
In Putin<U+2019>s eyes, these events are no accident. As he puts it, these events happened for a reason: 
<U+201C>Some people, from the outside, think that if they can <U+2018>comb<U+2019> the region to how they see fit <U+2013> some of them call this <U+2018>democracy<U+2019><U+2013> then the region will come into calmness and order. That<U+2019>s not how it is. Without taking into account the history, the traditions, religious particularities, you must not do anything in the Middle East, especially as an outsider.<U+201D> 
Russia found this out the hard way when its military intervened in Afghanistan in the 1980s, a war many historians believe to be one of the main reasons for the fall of the Soviet empire. According to Robert Gates , director of the CIA under Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush and Secretary of Defense under both George W. Bush and Barack Obama, the U.S. began arming and funding jihadists in Pakistan and Afghanistan six months prior to the Soviet invasion with the express goal of luring the Soviets into a quagmire. 
Similarly, and not by accident, the tactic used to draw Russia into Afghanistan is the same tactic being used today in Syria. In fact, Obama warned Putin that Russia<U+2019>s adventures into Syria would result in the same quagmire the Soviets met in Afghanistan. 
Unsurprisingly, supporting radical militant groups to overthrow regimes in the Middle East has been a key hallmark of Obama<U+2019>s foreign policy. As Putin notes: 
<U+201C>So they interfered in the internal affairs of Libya. Whether the [Gaddafi] regime was good or bad <U+2013> but Libya used to have the highest standard of living in the Middle East. And what<U+2019>s happening there now? There<U+2019>s a war for resources; an endless inter-tribal war. How is this all going to end <U+2013> nobody knows.<U+201D> 
What happened to Libya resonated strongly with Russia due to the fact that in that situation, the West convinced Russia and China not to use their veto power at the U.N. Security Council level <U+2014> they were told regime change was not part of NATO<U+2019>s agenda in Libya. As it turned out, however, this was one of the first things that happened as soon as authorization was granted for NATO to bomb Libyan territory. Putin immediately questioned why NATO was attacking Muammar Gaddafi directly despite their promises they would not do so. 
Putin has therefore drawn the following conclusion: 
<U+201C>What worries us is that if the same is done in Syria, then it will be in the same state as Libya. Is it not enough that we already have a small lawless territory between Afghanistan and Pakistan? Nobody governs the area, it<U+2019>s just groups of rebels. This is very close to our borders, do we want another?<U+201D> 
The role of al-Nusra in the Syrian conflict continues to be the main issue today, as Russia has repeatedly asked for the United States to differentiate between terrorist groups and moderate groups on the ground in Syria. 
As Putin said: 
<U+201C>You know what [the Americans] can<U+2019>t answer us? The key armed opposition group<U+2026>al-Nusra<U+2026>Yes, this organization is one of the key ones in the armed opposition [against Assad]. The U.S. State Department has confirmed it is a terrorist organization linked to al-Qaeda. Al-Nusra does not hide that fact. And <U+2013> what are [the Americans suggesting]? For al-Nusra to be in the future parliament?<U+201D> 
<U+201C>Or, here<U+2019>s another example. They support certain organizations that are fighting against Assad in Syria, yet those same countries [who support them in Syria] fight against these organizations in Mali.<U+201D> 
Putin<U+2019>s reference to fighters in Mali is a direct attack on France<U+2019>s role in the war on terror. France has been actively bombing Mali since 2013, though this is rarely covered by the mainstream media. As Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov has noted , the fighters France supported in Libya to overthrow Gaddafi were the same fighters they have supposedly been fighting in Mali. 
<U+201C>Often, not only are they the same organizations <U+2013> they are the same individuals,<U+201D> Putin added. 
<U+201C>They simply leave Syria and go to fight in Mali <U+2013> where western states do not support them. Then the same people go back to Syria and there they are supported.<U+201D> 
<U+201C>Where is the logic? How will it all end? These are not just empty words.<U+201D> Did you enjoy this article? - Consider helping us! Russia Insider depends on your donations: the more you give, the more we can do. $1 $10 Other amount

945.input:
time: null 
 author: No Author 
 source: lewrockwell.com 
 text: American Thinker October 27, 2016 
You<U+2019>re probably appalled at the American media<U+2019>s shameless whoring for Hillary Clinton, asking yourself why they would so thoroughly debase their much-touted journalistic ethics. President Obama has answered that question. 
As reported by Agence France Presse, during a recent speech in Pittsburgh he postulated: 
<U+201C>We are going to have to rebuild within this wild-wild-west-of-information flow some sort of curating function that people agree to. 
<U+201C>There has to be, I think, some sort of way in which we can sort through information that passes some basic truthiness tests and those that we have to discard, because they just don<U+2019>t have any basis in anything that<U+2019>s actually happening in the world.<U+201D> 
Set aside the outrageous, un-American gall in proposing that any central authority should <U+201C>curate<U+201D> information put out to the public, and walk with me for a minute down a meandering path of speculation. 
It is, or course, the World Wide Web in which Obama<U+2019>s informational <U+201C>wild-wild west<U+201D> exists. This is the realm of Breitbart, Cybercast News Service, the Drudge Report , World Net Daily , American Thinker , and other non-establishment outlets that persist in making the president uncomfortable. 
And what has happened recently to affect the World Wide Web? The U.S. government has handed over control to ICANN (Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers), the nonprofit agency that assigns website domain names. 
Is it in the president<U+2019>s mind that ICANN might someday assume the <U+201C>curating function<U+201D> he sees as necessary to insure <U+201C>truthiness<U+201D> in web-based news reporting? 
Well, according to ICANN Board Chair Stephen D. Crocker, diverse membership in the organization makes such a thing unthinkable. Quoted by the tech site C/NET, Crocker said: 
<U+201C>This community validated the multistakeholder model of internet governance. It has shown that a governance model defined by the inclusion of all voices, including business, academics, technical experts, civil society, governments and many others is the best way to assure that the internet of tomorrow remains as free, open and accessible as the internet of today.<U+201D> 
His confidence is echoed by the Internet Governance Coalition, a group of technology firms that includes Facebook, Google, Microsoft, and Verizon, among others. They issued a statement that lauds ICANN<U+2019>s <U+201C>strong accountability measures<U+201D> and upholds <U+201C>the bottom-up approach that embodies the very nature of the open internet we experience today.<U+2026><U+201D> 
Pardon the skepticism to which I<U+2019>ve become increasingly prone, but this sounds very much like the <U+201C>collaborative<U+201D> concept of governance that prevails in the academic world. 
If you<U+2019>ve ever applied for a position at a college or university, you know that what a search committee wants most urgently to know about you is whether you have a <U+201C>collaborative style<U+201D> of working. 
What exactly is a <U+201C>collaborative style,<U+201D> as understood in today<U+2019>s academic world? It means that you won<U+2019>t do anything to contradict the orthodoxy in thought and procedure reigning on campus <U+2014> in other words, that you are <U+201C>politically correct<U+201D> in your outlook.

946.input:
time: null 
 author: Eddy Lavine 
 source: worldtruth.tv 
 text: posted by Eddie Treasures may be found everywhere for those who have eyes to see<U+2014>a perfect example of this being Shilajit, one of the most prized medicines throughout Asia for the last few thousand years. In its <U+201C>wild habitat<U+201D> you could be forgiven for simply thinking that it was a tar-like substance. oozing from the cracks in between rocks high up in the Himalayan Mountains. And the locals did for many thousands of years; however, in ancient times one had to look for clues from nature to better understand their natural habitat<U+2014>particularly what was safe and what was poison. Upon seeing packs of native chimps snacking on the Shilajit tar and further observing that those who did seemed to be the strongest, most intelligent and long-lived of the bunch, the indigenous people began ingesting the night-black mineral pitch themselves. When they too began experiencing the benefits:<U+2014>a rapid restoration of their health and enhanced cognitive and physical abilities<U+2014>they knew they had stumbled on a great discovery. Oral tradition has it that this is how Shilajit was originally discovered. Maybe so, maybe not, but either way decades of intense scientific analysis and study have revealed that Shilajit is one of the most nutrient-dense substances on the planet. And what<U+2019>s more, is that the nutrients it contains, such as naturally occurring humic and fulvic acids<U+2014>two of nature<U+2019>s most potent detoxifiers of heavy metals and other pollutants that disrupt the natural function of the body, and are quite rare to boot. Known euphemistically as the <U+201C>destroyer of weakness,<U+201D> much can be learned about the incredible properties and benefits of Shilajit by understanding the process of how it is created. Over the course of millions of years, the lush primeval vegetation that once blanketed Asia was decomposed by the forces of nature, eventually becoming highly compacted under the weight of the mountains, which later formed as continental plates collided. Over 6,500 different species of ancient plants spent many millennia in a sort of geological alchemy that created a thick, black, resin-like substance trapped deep within the Himalyan, Caucasus, and other famous mountain ranges in the region. The relentless monsoons and ever-increasing pressure eventually caused this <U+201C>tar<U+201D> to begin seeping from cracks in rocks in the sides of the mountains. <U+201C>Intense scientific analysis and study have revealed that Shilajit is one of the most nutrient-dense substances on the planet.<U+201D> Laboratory analysis of Shilajit reveals a complete spectrum of every essential mineral on the planet in ionic form<U+2014>the most easily absorbable and assimilated by the human body. Scientists also found amino acids, fulvic and humic acids, ellagic acid, fatty acids and plant sterols, which tend to have a harmonizing effect on the hormonal/endocrine system, among many others. purified ladakhi shilajit resin from a tenth-generational family of herbal alchemists, considered by many to be some of the world<U+2019>s best shilajit. it can be cut with a knife and is similar in texture to a hard candy, although more pliable. photo: lerina winter Although shamans and medicine men of the time could not possibly have understood its complex and unusual composition, they could easily discern the beneficial effects Shilajit was having on the people they treated, which was a massive restoration of health and wellbeing. The Benefits of Shilajit Shilajit acts on many different systems in the body, earning it a place among the prized natural medicines known as adaptogens, meaning it helps to restore balance to one<U+2019>s system, whether that is through reducing excess (stress and cortisol, for example) or nourishing deficiencies (promoting sound sleep and giving endurance, strength and stamina) within the body<U+2019>s various systems. One of the primary ways it does this is through its action on the endocrine system. As the master controllers of the body<U+2019>s thousands of delicately tuned processes, hormones<U+2014>or the lack thereof<U+2014>have a very large influence on your health. They control mood, libido, sleep-wake cycles, hair growth, cognition, energy, consciousness and much more. Therefore it should come as no surprise that Shilajit has long been valued for its ability to restore sexual function, promote cognitive abilities, reduce anxiety and stress, improve mood and generally extend one<U+2019>s lifespan. Quite impressive, to be sure. However, Shilajit<U+2019>s beneficial medicinal properties are not solely limited to the endocrine system. It has also been shown to reduce pain and inflammation, making it one of the most sought after remedies for those suffering from arthritis. It also has a healing effect on the digestive tract, with the notable ability to repair ulcerated intestines and keep harmful bacteria in check. And, of course, it is also a great remineralizer and detoxifier, removing heavy metals and replacing them with those the body needs for health and wellbeing. It has also been used to treat allergies, malnutrition, anemia, and broken bones. It<U+2019>s kind of like water: life is just better when you consume it regularly. Selecting Quality Shilajit Shilajit can be found seeping wildly in many mountain ranges across Asia, although each culture tends to have its own name for the substance. In Western and Central Asia it is typically referred to as Moomiyo, but in the areas in and around the Himalayas, it is referred to as Shilajit. While this may seem semantical, it is an important distinction due to the fact that, depending on the source, Shilajit/Moomiyo will have different compositions. Generally speaking, the best quality Shilajit is believed to originate from the Himalaya area. shilajit is harvested in remote regions of the himalayan mountains. However, because Shilajit is somewhat rare and difficult to collect, as well as the fact that the world<U+2019>s supply originates in developing countries, the quality varies widely in the products currently available through various health food stores and websites worldwide. The most sought after and rare form is the night-black mineral resin, with only a handful of companies selling it worldwide. It is a sticky, wet-looking <U+201C>tar<U+201D> that is an intensely concentrated and purified form of Shilajit. It can be pricey, although a little goes a long way, making even a small amount last for months, even at higher dosages. That being said, there are many excellent, more affordable Shilajit products that come in a powdered form<U+2014>though they will generally be slightly less concentrated and potent than the pure resin. The primary benefits of the powder are the ease of use, price, and the ability to measure precise amounts, if needed, as the resin itself is quite sticky. When using a powder discernment is needed, as not all brands are equal. (In the section that follows we recommend some high quality, potent and high integrity Shilajit powders that are not adulterated). The vast majority of products available worldwide are actually diluted Shilajit powders. Pure Shilajit resin is composed of approximately 2% to 10% naturally occurring humic and fulvic acids with the remaining portion composed of minerals and other medicinal substances. However, adulterated products are typically 10% to 30% actual Shilajit powder and about 70% to 90% extracted humic and fulvic acids, which can be produced cheaply in a lab and added afterwards. While not dangerous, the adulterated Shilajit powders do not posses the same powerful medicinal properties. Authentic, quality Shilajit always has a distinct, strong piercing tar-like odor that is unmistakable. If the product you have does not have a noticeably intense smell or seems <U+2018>faint<U+2019>, then it is likely old or diluted Shilajit. Shilajit is not grown like most herbs and foods, so there are no organic or conventional distinctions. If authentic and unadulterated, Shilajit is wildcrafted, which is truly what lends it such incredible healing properties. source:

Your answer should follow the following format: Label: real/fake 
Here is the news text material:
947.input:
time: null 
 author: Mark DeNicola 
 source: collective-evolution.com 
 text: <U+201C>Adulthood<U+201D> comes to all of us at different times in our life. It has nothing to do with the legal age we can drink, or drive a car, or get married, and it<U+2019>s not signified by the job we have or the car we drive. It<U+2019>s a state of mind, a way of operating in the world.
Being a pretty well behaved teen, I often had people tell me from as young as 13 that I was incredibly mature for my age. In some respects, I could not argue with them. I would look at the behaviour of many of my friends and quite easily distinguish that I, for the most part, handled many things far more <U+201C>responsibly<U+201D> than they did. But even now, at the ripe old age of 28, I question when and if I ever truly matured.
I may have always acted appropriately, taken school seriously, and respected those around me, but did that qualify me for full-blown adulthood? I certainly thought it did, until about a year ago, when I concluded that the true sign of maturity is when an individual takes full responsibility for their life.
As part of identifying this conclusion (which I know is entirely subjective), I<U+2019>ve reflected a lot on what comes with this fundamental step in life. Here is my list of 7 seemingly harsh realities that kick in when you decide to take full responsibility for your life :
1. The World Doesn<U+2019>t Revolve Around You As much as we may like to think it does, the truth is, we are but a tiny fish in a massive soup of collective consciousness. Does this mean that we are ultimately powerless to create anything that will impact the masses? Absolutely not. But it does mean that we can no longer expect the world to cater to us.
Long gone are the days when parents, teachers, or any other caregiver is going to sit us down and remind us that everything is going to be okay. We need to find that strength within ourselves and go against the grain to create whatever it is that we are passionate about.
2. Your Reactions Are Everything In the moment, things may happen to us <U+2014> some far more challenging, scary, or unwanted than others <U+2014> but regardless of what that thing is, it<U+2019>s our reaction to it that dictates how much it is going to impact our lives.
For example, there is nothing intrinsically insulting about being called an asshole <U+2014> we can choose to take it personally, or we can choose to let it roll off our backs. This is why some of us are able to let it go in one ear and out the other while carrying on with our day, while others take it as a punch to the gut and a reason to change their behaviour moving forward.
3. We Can<U+2019>t All Be Famous We live in a time when instant fame has never seemed more attainable. The laughing mom in the chewbacca mask is all the evidence we need of this phenomenon. But fame still isn<U+2019>t in the cards for all of us.
While I<U+2019>m not suggesting that we stop trying to achieve success, or even that kind of astonishing overnight success, it seems that with maturity we recognize it<U+2019>s not only not worth pinning our hopes on, but also not really that desireable.
4. We<U+2019>ve Been Distracting Ourselves a Lot We all have things to do <U+2014> emails we avoid writing, conversations we avoid having, and issues we avoid addressing <U+2014> yet we consistently choose to distract ourselves instead. Whether it be by glorifying how <U+201C>busy<U+201D> we are, or by choosing to turn to Netflix instead, part of taking responsiblity for our lives is acknowledging our tendency to distract ourselves.
The more we acknowledge it, the more uncomfortable it becomes, and eventually, it will become so uncomfortable that we finally decide to just take action, and wonder why we didn<U+2019>t do it before.
5. Haters Gonna Hate Even if you go out of your way to be a people pleaser (which I would never suggest), there will always be someone or many someones who do not support you. While this is certainly the case throughout all of our lives, it usually isn<U+2019>t until we enter maturity that we acknowledge this as not only common but acceptable.
In the end, it<U+2019>s far better to be your true self and let some people hate that, than change who you are and have a bunch of different people hate you anyways.
6. Blaming Doesn<U+2019>t Get You Anywhere <U+201C>He/she did it!<U+201D> It<U+2019>s the infamous line we<U+2019>ve heard so many children say while pointing their finger in the direction of the person they believe should take the fall for whatever happened.
It may have worked, on occasion, throughout our childhood, but part of taking responsibility for your life is actually, you know, taking responsibility for your life . As much as we may feel like victims to certain things, playing the victim card rarely gets us anywhere and instead tends to prolong whatever situation or conflict we<U+2019>re trying to escape.
7. You Are the Reason Why You Aren<U+2019>t Where You Want to Be This one certainly goes hand in hand with the one before it, and is equally as true. If you want to own a multi-million dollar company that earns money for you even while you sleep, you have to start it and stick with it!
Your life is what it is right now because of the collection of decisions you<U+2019>ve made up to this point. So now is as good a time as any to start making ones that align with what you actually want. You just need to make sure you<U+2019>re tough enough to handle the fears, challenges, and emotions that are bound to come along the way, and remember, no matter how hard things get, <U+201C>this too shall pass.<U+201D>
A book that I found to be particularly helpful in me taking full responsibility for my life was Tony Robbins<U+2019> Awaken the Giant Within : How to Take Immediate Control of Your Mental, Emotional, Physical and Financial Destiny!

The latest batch of hacked emails from Clinton<U+2019>s campaign chair, John Podesta, have been released.

There are a number of communications found in the email pertaining to the Clinton campaign<U+2019>s close relationship with mainstream media and her private email server.
One email from September 9, 2008 shows Chris Lu, the Deputy Secretary of the Department of Labor, discussing a virtual data room where <U+201C>policy promises<U+201D> and other private communications will be uploaded:
General room <U+2013> there is a general room that we<U+2019>ll upload all of the policy promises, as well as legal documents like expense reimbursements and contribution forms. All of the principals on this list will have access to this room<U+2026> Regarding policy promises, from now on, we<U+2019>ll email out the first drafts when they<U+2019>re done, but we won<U+2019>t email out revisions. The latest version will always be stored in the <U+201C>general<U+201D> data room.
 

Another email thread from May 11, 2015, discussing Lanny Davis, former attorney for Bill Clinton, we see Clinton<U+2019>s senior advisor, Philippe Reines, pose the following question:
<U+201C>[Hillary Rodham Clinton] is anxious to move forward <U+2014> with the commitment that I will keep him focused and in line. Do you guys need to run any more traps on your end or can I reach out to enlist him?<U+201D>
Human Abedin writes back saying, <U+201C>She just called me about this. She wants Lanny.<U+201D>
John Podesta cryptically responds, <U+201C>In the land of he blind, the one-eyed man is king.<U+201D> Delivered by The Daily Sheeple

949.instruction:

Here is the news text material:
949.input:
time: null 
 author: Daniel Strauss Josh Gerstein Madeline Conway Annie Karni Michael Grunwald 
 source: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/hilary-clinton-fbi-democrats-230473 
 text: Sen. Dianne Feinstein called the FBI's actions "appalling."  | Getty Republicans are also rethinking their opinion on the FBI director. By Daniel Strauss 10/28/16 08:18 PM EDT Democrats have soured on James Comey. In July, they praised the FBI director's decision not to recommend charges against Hillary Clinton over her use of a private email server while serving as secretary of state. But on Friday, top party officials turned on Comey <U+2014> ripping him not only for taking new steps into an investigation they hoped was over, but also for the way he announced them. Story Continued Below Comey sent a letter to several congressional leaders to inform them that the FBI had come across new emails pertinent to its Clinton investigation and would take additional steps to look into them, adding that the FBI did not yet know if the emails were significant and that he did not yet know when the additional review would be finished. The letter set off a political firestorm. And while Republicans pounced, Democrats fumed. <U+201C>Already, we have seen characterizations that the FBI is 'reopening' an investigation but Comey's words do not match that characterization,<U+201D> Clinton campaign manager John Podesta wrote in a statement. <U+201C>Director Comey's letter refers to emails that have come to light in an unrelated case, but we have no idea what those emails are and the Director himself notes they may not even be significant.<U+201D> By Josh Gerstein and Madeline Conway Podesta also expressed frustration at the timing of the letter from Comey to lawmakers, informing them of the new evidence. "It is extraordinary that we would see something like this just 11 days out from a presidential election,<U+201D> he wrote. <U+201C>The Director owes it to the American people to immediately provide the full details of what he is now examining. We are confident this will not produce any conclusions different from the one the FBI reached in July." And Sen. Dianne Feinstein, Vice Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, took perhaps the strongest shot at Comey: "The FBI has a history of extreme caution near Election Day so as not to influence the results. Today<U+2019>s break from that tradition is appalling." Elijah Cummings, the top Democrat on the House Oversight Committee, was also displeased: "Frankly, I was surprised that the FBI sent this letter given how obvious it was that Republicans would immediately misconstrue and mischaracterize it. The FBI Director did explain in his letter that none of this information may even be significant, but that did not stop Republicans from hyperventilating and making wild accusations. I can understand the FBI's concern about being attacked for not keeping Republicans informed of any possible development --no matter how small--but I believe the FBI now has an obligation to make public as much information as possible as soon as possible to eliminate any inaccuracies or confusion about these issues." But in July, Democrats had warmer things to say about Comey when he decided not to bring charges against Clinton and her staff. Cummings, at a House Oversight Committee hearing in July, lavished praise on Comey in the face of strong criticism from Republicans. 2016 By Annie Karni "I don't know whether your family's watching this, but I hope that they are as proud of you as I am, because you are the epitome of what a public servant is all about. Sacrificing over and over and over again, trying to do the right thing, sometimes coming under ridicule, but again still doing the right thing," Cummings said. Similarly, after Comey announced that he would not call for Clinton to be prosecuted over the secret email server in July, Feinstein praised the director for coming to the "proper" conclusion. "After months of painstaking work, FBI Director Comey today announced that charges against Secretary Clinton for her use of a private email server would not be appropriate and that <U+2018>no reasonable prosecutor<U+2019> would pursue a case," Feinstein said in a statement on July 5. <U+201C>While Secretary Clinton admitted the private server was a mistake, it<U+2019>s clear there was no intent to violate laws governing the handling of classified information, so this is the proper conclusion." But it's not just Democrats who changed their perspective on Comey after his agency's moves Friday. One Donald Trump, perhaps the greatest beneficiary of the decision, seemed to warm to an official who had previously ranked among his favorite foils. At a rally in July, after Comey did not recommend charges, Trump criticized Comey's decision and told supporters: "We have a rigged system, folks." But at a rally Friday, the day's news seem to have changed Comey's stance. "The FBI, I think they<U+2019>re going to right the ship, and they can save their great reputation by doing so,<U+201D> Trump told rally attendees in New Hampshire. <U+201C>It might not be as rigged as I thought." By Michael Grunwald By Bill Scher By Thomas Wright By Joshua Zeitz

time: null 
 author: Steve Watson 
 source: infowars.com 
 text: Store Guardian Front Page: <U+201C>A 16-Year-Old Migrant Cries<U+2026><U+201D> This image of a "16-year-old" migrant crying <U+2013> which is currently plastered on the front page of The Guardian <U+2013> is nothing short of laughable Chris Menahan | Information Liberation - October 27, 2016 Comments 
Won<U+2019>t you take pity on this poor, innocent little child? 
This image of a <U+201C>16-year-old<U+201D> migrant crying <U+2013> which is currently plastered on the front page of The Guardian <U+2013> is nothing short of laughable. 
<U+201C>A 16-year-old from Ethiopia cries while he awaits registration at a processing centre in the makeshift refugee camp near Calais,<U+201D> the photo<U+2019>s caption reads. The image is placed under a headline reading: <U+201C>Councils resist pressure to take children from Calais.<U+201D> 

This crying <U+201C>child<U+201D> is supposed to make Brits feel guilty and demand their government allow <U+201C>children<U+201D> like him into their nation. 
The image is not a fake, nor is it being used satirically. It comes from the Associated Press<U+2019> Emilio Morenatti , you can see four pictures of the man for sale on their website . 
The <U+201C>child migrant<U+201D> is clearly in his 40<U+2019>s, yet their editors evidently believe their readers are so incredibly stupid they<U+2019>ll actually believe they<U+2019>re looking at a 16-year-old boy. 
A look at Emilio<U+2019>s twitter shows one person appears to have actually bought the lie: @morenatti2004 Imposible no hacernos mirar y luego, un nudo en la garganta. pic.twitter.com/A7zvz5440q 
<U+2014> Luj<U+00E1>n Artola Paulos (@rowley_bel) October 25, 2016 
<U+201C>Impossible not make us look, then, a lump in the throat,<U+201D> the tweet reads. 
Incidentally, Ethiopia is not even a war zone, so I<U+2019>m not sure how this 45-year-old man can even be considered a <U+201C>refugee.<U+201D> NEWSLETTER SIGN UP

952.input:
time: null 
 author: Kristina Peterson 
 source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/charles-schumer-takes-on-role-of-democrats-main-defender-1478819391 
 text: WASHINGTON<U+2014>When President-elect Donald Trump takes office next January, Democrats<U+2019> last line of legislative defense will be run by a brash New Yorker of their own: Sen. Charles Schumer. A veteran deal maker and famously nonstop political strategist, Mr. Schumer is expected to be elected by his colleagues on Wednesday to replace retiring Minority Leader Harry Reid (D., Nev.) In his new post, Mr. Schumer will assume command of the Senate wing of a party contending not only with a White House soon held by Mr. Trump, a Republican, but also Democrats<U+2019> own internal divisions, which could be reinforced by their losses in this week<U+2019>s election. Mr. Trump<U+2019>s stunning victory, fueled by a wave of discontent with the political status-quo, is expected to empower Democrats<U+2019> liberal wing, whose skepticism of trade deals and Wall Street shared some overlap with Mr. Trump<U+2019>s populist message. Longtime liberal Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D., Mass.) and Sen. Bernie Sanders (I., Vt.), who enthralled many of the party<U+2019>s younger voters in the Democratic presidential primary, will likely have new sway in Democrats<U+2019> internal deliberations. <U+201C>If we have learned nothing else from the past two years of electioneering, we should hear the message loud and clear that the American people want Washington to change,<U+201D> Ms. Warren said in a speech Thursday. <U+201C>The American people have called out loudly for economic and political reform. For years, too many Republicans and too many Democrats have refused to hear their demands.<U+201D> Mr. Schumer, in an interview this week, played down the party<U+2019>s divisions, saying that House Republicans<U+2019> internal strife has blocked more legislative action than Democrats<U+2019> disagreements. <U+201C>Our party is far less divided than the Republicans,<U+201D> he said. <U+201C>We have some differences in our caucus, but they don<U+2019>t prevent us from being unified and getting things done.<U+201D> Mr. Schumer, whose New York constituents include many in the financial industry, may be reluctant to let the party<U+2019>s liberal wing pull its policy too far to the left. Many of the more centrist Senate Democrats will be up for re-election in 2018<U+2014>including Sens. Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, Joe Donnelly of Indiana, Joe Manchin of West Virginia and Jon Tester of Montana<U+2014>and defending them is likely to be a priority. <U+201C>There are a lot of Democrats who would have a really difficult time defending a progressive agenda,<U+201D> said Greg Valliere, chief global strategist at Horizon Investments. <U+201C>They would seem out of step<U+201D> from their conservative-leaning states. In addition, Mr. Schumer has a long record as a savvy deal maker in the Senate, and Republicans will have new incentives to work across the aisle next year. In 2017 Republicans will control the House majority, but hold only 52 seats in the Senate, where 60 votes are needed to pass most legislation. Democrats have been divided in the past over issues including energy regulations and how to overhaul the business tax code, topics that Republicans and Mr. Trump are likely to revisit next year. Bipartisan efforts to pare down environmental regulations won<U+2019>t sit well with the party<U+2019>s liberal wing. <U+201C>The challenge we face with global warming is equivalent to an asteroid aimed directly at the Earth,<U+201D> Sen. Jeff Merkley (D., Ore.), the only senator to endorse Mr. Sanders during the primary race, said Thursday. In some ways, Mr. Schumer<U+2019>s job next year will be easier as the leader of the minority party in the Senate and one that doesn<U+2019>t control the White House. Had Democrats won the White House and Senate majority on Tuesday, Mr. Schumer would have been responsible for clearing Hillary Clinton <U+2019>s nominees through the chamber. Liberal groups were already bracing for a fight over potential cabinet appointments and other nominees they viewed as too cozy with Wall Street. That could have been tricky for Mr. Schumer, who has advocated for some legislation benefiting the financial industry, including the reauthorization of a federal terrorism insurance program important to real-estate developers in New York City. He also hasn<U+2019>t been as sharp a critic of banks as others in the party<U+2019>s left wing, not signing some letters written by Democrats after the Wells Fargo scandal over its sales tactics. The responsibility of passing legislation now rests on Republicans, who have pledged to repeal and replace the 2010 health-care law, the pitfalls of which have been a political albatross for Democrats. <U+201C>The burden on health-care policy shifts<U+201D> to Republicans, Sen. Chris Murphy (D., Conn.). Instead of Democrats debating whether they could establish a government-run insurance option, known as the public option, he said, <U+201C>the fight is going to be about what they think will magically insure 20 million people other than the Affordable Care Act.<U+201D> Democrats said they hope to find some common ground with Mr. Trump, citing his campaign stances to improve the country<U+2019>s infrastructure and change the tax treatment of carried interest, private-equity managers<U+2019> share of profits from others<U+2019> investments. And Mr. Trump<U+2019>s split with Republicans on some fiscal issues<U+2014>he doesn<U+2019>t want to change or cut Social Security<U+2014>could align him with Democrats at times. But Democrats said they wouldn<U+2019>t hesitate to use their toehold of power in the Senate to block Mr. Trump if he tries to implement some of his more contentious campaign proposals, including building a wall along the border with Mexico or deporting all illegal immigrants. On these issues, Mr. Schumer is likely to face little internal disagreement. <U+201C>Where the Trump agenda is going to go after vulnerable people<U+2014>immigrants, Muslims, women, the poor<U+2014>he<U+2019>ll be able to unify the caucus and be the firewall between the worst of Trump<U+2019>s instincts and a compliant Republican Congress,<U+201D> said former Schumer aide Jim Kessler, a senior vice president at Third Way, a centrist Democratic think tank. Write to Kristina Peterson at kristina.peterson@wsj.com

953.input:
time: null 
 author: Alex Isenstadt Kyle Cheney Shane Goldmacher Jake Sherman John Bresnahan Jack Shafer 
 source: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/priebus-declares-rnc-standing-behind-trump-229568 
 text: Reince Priebus spent much of the call trying to defuse what he described as a series of false <U+201C>rumors<U+201D> from the weekend that the committee would be shifting its focus to down-ballot races. | AP Reince Priebus says the committee went dark all weekend to let the nominee explain himself. By Alex Isenstadt , Kyle Cheney and Shane Goldmacher 10/10/16 07:29 PM EDT Updated 10/10/16 07:26 PM EDT With Donald Trump<U+2019>s campaign in a historic free fall, Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus declared Monday that the party is standing behind its presidential nominee. <U+201C>First of all, I want to make it very clear that the RNC is in full coordination with the Trump campaign, and we have a great relationship with them. If there<U+2019>s any takeaway from this call, that<U+2019>s the takeaway,<U+201D> Priebus told RNC members during an emergency conference call, which POLITICO obtained a recording of. Story Continued Below <U+201C>Nothing has changed in regard with our relationship and we remain very much involved and together in all levels of making these decisions with how to run this operation across this country.<U+201D> <U+201C>Everything is on course,<U+201D> Priebus said. <U+201C>I want you to understand that.<U+201D> The call came amid mounting questions about whether the Republican Party was preparing to abandon Trump amid revelations that he had once bragged about sexually assaulting women. On Monday morning, House Speaker Paul Ryan announced that he would no longer defend Trump and would instead focus on protecting the majority in his congressional chamber. The announcement represented an extraordinary break as the highest-ranking elected Republican said he was no longer standing with the Republican nominee. Priebus spent much of the 14-minute call trying to defuse what he described as a series of false <U+201C>rumors<U+201D> from the weekend that the committee would be shifting its focus to down-ballot races. He dismissed talk that staffers had left the RNC and the Trump campaign, and said there had been no discussion of finding a new nominee <U+2014> something he described as impractical. <U+201C>There<U+2019>d been obviously in the last 24 hours, the last 36 hours, a lot of false rumors that we didn<U+2019>t want to engage in before the debate last night, which was very important,<U+201D> he said. <U+201C>So here we are.<U+201D> Since the release of the bombshell 2005 tape, many RNC officials expressed frustration about not being able to get answers from the committee. Some of them said they spent the weekend trying to get in touch with RNC leaders but received <U+201C>radio silence.<U+201D> One party chair, Robert Graham of Arizona, offered a sharp criticism of the RNC on Monday <U+2014> pointing specifically to the committee<U+2019>s decision to temporarily halt over the weekend production of some political mail boosting Trump. <U+201C>Leadership is more than stopping political mail, not campaigning for someone or making statements condemning a person<U+2019>s comments made nearly a dozen years before,<U+201D> said Graham, who is expected to wage a campaign to be the next RNC chairman. <U+201C>Leadership is making the tough decisions, digging in and sacrificing for beliefs and ideas greater than one person.<U+201D> By Jake Sherman and John Bresnahan During the call, Priebus said he and Trump campaign officials had reached the conclusion that they wanted to let Trump explain the video without any <U+201C>cross-talk,<U+201D> which could have obscured the apology he planned to deliver during the debate. The chairman said Trump had demonstrated contrition on Sunday evening in St. Louis, delivering an apology that was <U+201C>heartfelt.<U+201D> <U+201C>I am happy that Donald apologized a few different times about it. He apologized to the American people, he apologized to his family,<U+201D> he said. <U+201C>He was embarrassed, he was ashamed. And honestly, I can tell you it was very heartfelt because I<U+2019>ve seen it one on one with him over the weekend. And it wasn<U+2019>t something that wasn<U+2019>t just said at the debate. It<U+2019>s something that he feels, as Gov. [Mike] Pence says, in his heart.<U+201D> Priebus promised to update RNC members with another conference call in around a week. He ended the call without taking questions. By Thomas Wright By Bill Scher By Joshua Zeitz By Jack Shafer
